Your Offering:
75th Vyasa Puja - The Appearance Day of our Beloved Spiritual Master
 Srila Radhanath Swami Maharaj
 
 In Srimad-Bhagavatam, in the Uddhava Gita 11.17.27: acaryam mam vijayinam, Krsna Himself declares that the acarya is non-different from Him.
 
 Srila Vishwanath Chakravarti Thakura also proclaims in his Gurv-astaka, “The spiritual master is to be honored as much as the Supreme Lord because he is the most confidential servitor of the Lord.
 
 This is acknowledged in all revealed scriptures and followed by all authorities”. In the Padma Purana, Lord Siva tells Parvati “Of all types of worship, worship of Lord Vishnu is the best, and better than worship of Lord Vishnu is the worship of His devotee, the Vaishnava.
 
 One who performs worship of Lord Govinda but fails to worship His devotee should be understood to be not a devotee of the Lord but simply a victim of false pride”.
 
 So, we are doubly bound, by an injunction as well as a prohibition to celebrate this Most Blessed event, Sri Vyasa Puja. To further demonstrate by His own example, Lord Caitanya Himself instituted this auspicious celebration – Sri Vyasa Puja as chronicled in the Caitanya Bhagavata, Madhya Khanda Chapter 5. That inaugural Vyasa Puja happened in the year 1509 in Srivasa Aangan. “Srivasa Pandit, the head priest of the function, gave Lord Nityananda a flower garland to offer to a painting of Vyasadeva. Holding the garland in His beautiful lotus hand, Nityananda Prabhu hesitated and began glancing here and there as if he was looking for someone. Then to everyone’s surprise Nityananda offered the garland to Sri Caitanyadeva instead...”. Lord Gauranga is the guru of Sri Nityananda Prabhu. This is the basis of the worship performed by Lord Nityananda. Therefore, the worship of Vyasa-deva, is factually the worship of Lord Gauranga in the form of the present acarya.
 
 Expression churns and reinforces emotions. The celebration of Sri Vyasa Puja - The Most Blessed Event is an expression of the gratitude that a disciple feels for the spiritual master. And that gratitude is reaffirmed when a disciple expresses one’s own gratitude and hears other disciples’ express their gratitude. During the course of our devotional life, Sri Vyasa Puja affords us an annual opportunity to set aside our mind’s wanderings on the trivialities that occupy our consciousness and single-pointedly bring our attention to the matchless gift, the causeless mercy that our spiritual master has brought into our lives and into the lives of those he has touched.
 
 It is a special day to deeply contemplate how the spiritual master is acting personally in the lives of so many and how we/they are receiving his innumerable gifts and how we/they are acting in that prime relationship. It is a day to focus on his glories and not get caught up in our own insecurities, our inadequacies, failings.
 
 Srila Bhakti Vinod Thakura perfectly captures our condition and the indispensable and merciful role our spiritual master plays in our life. In one of his Saranagati Songs, Emona durmati, he writes “Oh Lord! Such a wicked mind has brought me into this world, but one of Your pure and elevated devotees has come to bring me out of it. He saw me so fallen and wretched, took pity, and came to me saying, O humbled soul, please listen to this good tiding, for it will gladden your heart.
 
 Sri Krsna Caitanya has appeared in the land of Navadvipa to deliver you. He has safely conducted many miserable souls such as you across the sea of worldly existence. To fulfill the promise of the Vedas, the son of a brahmana bearing the name Mahaprabhu of golden complexion, has descended with His brother the avadhuta Nityananda. Together They have overwhelmed all of Nadia with divine ecstasy. Sri Caitanya, who is Krishna Himself, the son of Nanda, has saved the world by freely distributing His own holy name. Go also and receive your deliverance.”
 
 We cannot go to Lord Caitanya directly and receive our means of deliverance but we can do so through our spiritual master, who is sevaka Bhagavan, the servitor God, who himself engages in the service of the Sevya Bhagavan, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Caitanya and is eager to re-connect the wandering soul with the Lord through devotional service. Sri Guru epitomizes who he represents. As a matter of fact, he follows the mandate of Lord Caitanya. In Caitanya Caritamrta, Lord Caitanya instructs “Instruct everyone to follow the orders of Lord Śrī Kṛṣṇa as they are given in the Bhagavad-gītā and Śrīmad-Bhāgavatam. In this way become a spiritual master and try to liberate everyone in this land.”
 
 How does the spiritual master see Sri Vyasa Puja? In one sense, it is one of the most difficult services for them. I have heard so from HH Srila Bhakti Caru Swami as well. There is also a very profoundly beautiful Vyasa Puja address to his disciples by Srila Bhakti Siddhanta Saraswati Thakura in this connection. As we understand from Srila Bhakti Siddhanta Saraswati Thakur’s teachings, receiving worship and adulation is unnatural for the pure devotee Vaishnava spiritual master, as in his heart, he reserves that exclusively for his guru, other sadhus and Krsna. However, he receives such worship and adulation following the mandate of Krsna as we understood earlier. So, even this, as much as it goes against his nature, he receives it as a service unto the guru parampara, his Lord and his disciples. He remembers and meditates upon the mercy and love he himself has received from his guru and he sees how his guru and even his disciples are engaging him in service to Krsna. He remains humble and reaffirms his commitment to the guru parampara, his Lord and his disciples.
 
 The spiritual master is not just a conveyer of Krsna’s will: he is the gateway to Krsna, he is the bearer of the descending mercy flowing from Krsna through the guru parampara and ushers it into our life and in return he also receives our devotional service in various ways and delivers it to Krsna up the parampara, the celebration of “his” Sri Vyasa puja being one of our services he delivers. So, if we understand this essential fact as to how he is the gateway to Krsna, how can we do anything but fall at his lotus feet and meditate upon his limitless glories.
 
 Finally, I want to share one example of the deep spiritual attachment a spiritual master has with his disciples and vice versa. Srila Prabhupada had such an attachment for his disciples and his disciples have for him. Beyond the externalities of Sri Vyasa Puja, in many ways the event has the potency to re-kindle such a relationship.
 
 By the mercy of the spiritual master is the mercy of Krishna accessed. So potent and transformational is the spiritual master’s mercy that the sincere disciple feels and remains indebted, lifetime after lifetime. The disciple strives to express that gratitude by dedicating one’s life to the spiritual master’s service.
 
 So, Sri Vyasa Puja is a reminder for us as to why we are a part of this ISKCON movement, to prosecute pure devotional service and to share it with others.
 
 Finally, on this auspicious Sri Vyasa Puja day, let me offer my prostrated obeisances unto the divine lotus feet of HH Srila Radhanath Swami Guru Maharaja, who is a confidential associate of the Senapati Bhakta of Lord Caitanya’s army, Srila Prabhupada. I offer my obeisances to the devotees who commissioned me for this service for my own purification despite having many disqualifications to render this service. I seek the blessings of my god-brothers and god-sisters and their forgiveness as well if my words were inappropriate.
 
 Your insignificant servant of the servants
 - Batu Gopal Das

In the month of January this year, my mother was facing some health challenges and was hospitalized. During those days, I found myself constantly brooding over our situation, lamenting that I did not have the means to help her as I wished. In that state of helplessness, I began praying intensely — even yearning to become wealthy — forgetting what my real aspiration in life should truly be. Honestly speaking, Guru Maharaj, I confess that I do have the habit of praying like this at times.

One day, while I was in the hospital, in one of your lectures which I was hearing you narrated a pastime that touched and instructed my heart deeply. It was exactly what I needed to hear at that time, and I had never heard that pastime before. You spoke about a poor South Indian Dravidian brahmana who was living in such abject poverty that his relatives and society had abandoned him. He was extremely thin and sickly due to starvation, unable to obtain even his daily food. Overcome by hunger and despair, he went to Jagannatha Puri and stood before Lord Jagannatha, praying that if the Lord did not make him wealthy, he would end his life. The next day, he came again before the Lord and vowed that if Lord Jagannatha did not make him wealthy within seven days, he would end his life.

Three days passed, yet nothing changed. Again, he approached the Lord and repeated his threat, giving Him four more days. But even after that, his condition remained the same. Finally, in utter hopelessness, the brahmana went to the ocean, resolved to end his life by drowning.

As he was about to enter the water, he suddenly beheld a majestic personality emerging from the sea — so vast and resplendent that the sight left him speechless. As this divine figure approached the shore, His form gradually became smaller, apt for this age. Filled with awe and curiosity, the brahmana approached him and tried to speak, though initially, the personality gave only brief and distant replies. Eventually, as the brahmana poured out his heart about his misery and intention to end his life, the personality became compassionate and told him that the only solution for his suffering was to see the smiling face of the Lord.

The divine personality then revealed himself — He was Vibhisana. He said, "I am going to take darshan of the Lord. You can come along." And they walked towards Totagopinath temple where Lord Caitanya was with His associates. The brahmana was astonished and said that Lord Jagannatha, the Lord of the Universe, resided in the temple, but where were they going. Upon seeing Vibhisana, Lord Caitanya became filled with joy and affectionately called Him near, seemingly ignoring the poor brahmana. The two conversed lovingly, and during their exchange, Lord Caitanya told Vibhishan that this other brahmana who was sitting a little distance away and he spoke loud enough so that that brahmana could hear him. 'He's starving. He's suffering from terrible poverty and he's been rejected by everyone. Why? It is due to his past sins. Whatever comes upon us is due to our own karma. And this fool, he is blaming God for his miseries. That is the condition of people in this world today,' Lord Caitanya said, 'They want to blame God for what they have brought upon themselves. And whatever good they get, whatever successes, they want to take the credit and forget Krsna altogether. Is this not the situation of people in this world? Whatever goes wrong, why is God doing this to me? And whatever goes right, see what I have done. But the pleasures and the pains, the happiness and distress that comes upon us in this world, it is all the reactions of our past karma. We are responsible. But this miserable soul is simply blaming the Lord. Not only blaming the Lord, but he has come to Jagannath Puri to harass Lord Jagannath. To make ultimatums to Lord Jagannath. But I tell you, Vibhishan, you should save him. And you should give him immense glory.'

'As you say, my Lord,' said Vibhishan. Lord Caitanya said, 'Bring him back to South India and give him great wealth, real wealth.' Vibhishan offered his obeisances and they walked out. And the brahmana walked out with him.

That brahmana, he asked Vibhishan, 'Who was that? Who is that sannyasi giving you orders, calling you Vibhishan? And that order he gave you, very nice, but who was he giving you that order?' And Vibhishan said, 'You are such a fool. That was Lord Jagannath.'

The brahmana said, 'You told me you were going to bring me to Jagannath and you just brought me to the sannyasi's house and you didn't even go to Jagannath's temple at all.' He said, 'You're a fool. That is Lord Jagannath. He has assumed the beautiful golden form of Sri Gauranga Mahaprabhu to give what no other incarnation has given, pure love of God, the greatest wealth.'

So the brahmana, he said, 'That's Lord Jagannath, so humble, so kind, so merciful. Please bring me to him. Bring me to him.' So Vibhishan came back. And Lord Caitanya asked, 'Why have you returned?' And he said that this brahmana wants to say something to you.

And the brahmana with tears in his eyes fell at the lotus feet of Lord Caitanya and surrendered and said, 'I am such a selfish person. I am such a fool. I'm diseased and I was asking you for a diet of food that was only going to increase the miseries of my disease. And I was not willing to ask you for the proper medicine. You are the supreme physician. I am an ignorant soul. But now I have come to take shelter of your lotus feet and accept the real medicine that you have given.'

Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu told him, 'Whatever your karma may be, don't mind the happiness and distress because even if you have wealth that does not in any way guarantee that you will not suffer as much as a poor man, and even if you're poor, that does not mean you will not enjoy as much as a rich man. That is the way this world is. So tolerate both happiness and distress, which will come by their own arrangement. And fix your mind on the Lord and take the medicine of the chanting of the Holy Name. And you follow in the footsteps of Vibhishan and he will give you the greatest wealth, the wealth that your heart is longing for, and what is that wealth? The purushartha siromani, the greatest of all treasures, the treasure of love of God, Krsna-Prema.'

When I heard this pastime from your lotus lips, Guru Maharaj, it shook me deeply. I was amazed and humbled by its perfect timing. Through your vani, you rescued me from my self-centered desires and reminded me of the true purpose of life — to serve, to surrender, and to depend upon the mercy of the Lord. You gave me solace when I needed it.

Since that day, this pastime has remained engraved in my heart. It continues to inspire and guide me whenever worldly anxieties arise, especially concerning money. I am endlessly grateful to you, Guru Maharaj, for giving me shelter through your divine vani.

I pray that I may continue to hear your instructions attentively, purify my heart, and in some small and insignificant way, be of service to my Godbrothers and Godsisters who are sincerely assisting you in fulfilling the mission of Srila Prabhupada. Just as the brahmana received the mercy of the Lord through the association of Vibhisana, I too pray that I may always remain in the association of sincere Godbrothers and Godsisters — which is, in truth, your mercy. In their association, may I transform my heart for good and learn to serve with genuine humility.

At your lotus feet,
Your insignificant son,
Caitanya Purushottam das

 I am eternally grateful for this opportunity to offer my humble obeisances to my beloved spiritual guide, His Holiness Radhanath Swami Maharaj, a beacon of devotion and wisdom in the Gaudiya Vaishnava sampradaya.
 
 Maharaj, on this most sacred day, we offer our prayers and our deepest gratitude. Let us meditate on how you practically embody the teachings of our ācāryas. While there are countless examples of your divine compassion and grace, we humbly choose to recall a few specific incidents. Your life is the perfect commentary on the śikṣāṣṭakam, teaching us what it truly means to be a servant of Kṛṣṇa.
 Our purpose in recounting these is twofold: firstly, to glorify your transcendental qualities which effortlessly attract the hearts of all living entities; and secondly, for our own purification, as reflecting upon your perfect character inspires us to sincerely follow your instructions.
 
 1. Radical Humility and Universal Respect
 Maharaj, one of the most profound qualities that illuminates your personality is your profound humility tṛṇād api sunīcena. You do not merely preach respect; you live it by honoring every soul, regardless of their external designation or religious background. This was exemplified during your treatment in Kerala, when you consistently offered pranāms to your Muslim driver, concluding with full daṇḍavats at the airport.
 This act speaks volumes. The elderly driver, accustomed to serving the world’s most powerful kings and sheikhs, broke down in tears, stating that no one had ever shown him such profound respect. In that moment, you demonstrated that your vision is purely spiritual, transcending material designations of caste, creed, or wealth. It inspires me to cultivate the necessary humility to practice mānadena in all my interactions.
 
 2. Unwavering Absorption in the Holy Name Verse 1: ceto-darpaṇa-mārjanaṁ...
 Maharaj, Your life is a profound example of dedicated absorption in kīrtana and japa which is the foundational instruction of the Śikṣāṣṭakam ceto-darpana-marjanam.
 Reports from your close servants confirm that they have observed you chanting throughout the night on many occasions, yet you still begin your morning program the next day without fail. Furthermore, before yatras travels or important engagements, you are known to sit alone with a harmonium and sing for four or five hours. This demonstrates that your "head and heart are always dedicated to Kṛṣṇa." The accounts of your tireless dedication to the Holy Name, chanting through the night, motivate me daily.

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 I am in deep thought, probably too much. I was reminded by the story of you sitting on that rock on the verge of the river Ganges. You decided to meditate in deep and contemplative prayer for a considerable time. While you were looking for a relationship and deeper purpose with God, I wonder now: were you wrestling with this same question of how deep the purification must go?
 
 I sometimes feel like I am that being from the Beatles' Yellow Submarine. He's a real nowhere man - existing but not fully present, creating but disconnected from the creation, contemplating endlessly without resolution.
 
 “In the Beatles' animated film Yellow Submarine, the song "Nowhere Man" is performed by the Beatles as they encounter the character Jeremy Hillary Boob Ph.D. in the "Sea of Nothing," also known as "Nowhere Land." The lyrics, "He's a real Nowhere Man, Sitting in his Nowhere Land, Making all his Nowhere plans for nobody," are sung about Jeremy, who lives in isolation and is described as a "nowhere man" due to his lack of direction and purpose. Jeremy is portrayed as an eccentric, flamboyant being with a blue face, pink ears, and a fluffy tail, who speaks mostly in rhyme and is deeply engrossed in creating art and writing books, though he claims never to read his own reviews. The song was originally written by John Lennon for the Rubber Soul album in 1965 and later featured in the film, where it serves as a thematic introduction to Jeremy's character. The character's name, Jeremy Hillary Boob Ph.D., is a whimsical creation that reflects the song's theme of existential detachment.”
 
 As Krishna conscious as I try to be, and for many years, I have for quite some time been looking at what my mind and intelligence are doing and what Krishna and you have been trying to guide me into. As you know, I have always had a strong calling to fulfill instructions given to me years ago to serve in devotee care. In doing so, I have taken it upon myself to study deeper the aspects of our mind and body and what causes us to become triggered. I have even written a book about it, and it is currently being reviewed. I have received encouraging feedback.
 
 These internal dives are necessary. I am drawn now to the thoughts and emotions you may have experienced while sitting on that rock overlooking the Ganges, day after day. At that time, I believe you must have been asking in so many ways: who is God and what is my purpose?
 
 I too am asking now: how deep do Krishna and you wish to take me? What have I done to end up in this position? I know I have committed all kinds of sins and offenses, and yet here I am. The discovery and purification are both enlightening and challenging, where I must pull myself into focus as to what is rising to the surface and what is being revealed, avoiding traps of illusion and the blind spots that I, devotees, and the wider society have been subjected to. It seems ongoing because I have wanted to uncover this. However, I am too naive and feel very much like a neophyte devotee because I do not consider myself so learned in the sastras. I do feel like I have understood the essence of Krishna consciousness, though. I am perhaps running before I can walk, though as I present at the end, I have felt an increasing urgency to deepen my prayers and help myself and devotees avoid the pitfalls of the mind and senses further. In doing so, I am hoping we will be able to strengthen our ability to avoid offenses and serve as Srila Prabhupada wanted us to do in his instructions and writings.
 
 It may be questioned why a devotee is put into such tribulation by the Personality of Godhead. The answer is that this kind of arrangement by the Lord is just like a father sometimes becoming unkind to his sons. Please read this section to the end - Krsna Book Ch 88 - The Deliverance of Lord Siva.
 
 As devotees, we are covered in our awakening.
 Early on, not long after joining the movement, I understood you, other sannyasis, and great surrendered souls go through so much purification. Some may think that your life in this world is floating on a cloud with an entourage of disciple followers and well-wishers.
 Though I know for you it's more about having to tolerate and endure all the attention. All eyes are on you, and so many expectations are made upon you. On one level, you have perfected life, and that is what we are all aiming for, to follow in your footsteps, but to live the life that you do, I believe I have many more lives to attain such Krishna consciousness.
 
 I don't fully realize, Maharaj, what you go through, and yet I know you have endured limiting and ongoing health issues. And it's that sixth portion of our karma that often rings in the back of my mind that you take on board from each disciple, and you have so many disciples.
 
 Maharaj, you've seen it all before, and the Vietnam war draft. As you are aware, the world governments have put out alerts that there may be a third world war. They are goading it to happen, of course. It is inevitable, as these are reactions to the accumulative reactions to animal slaughter.
 
 This external chaos mirrors something of the internal work required. Thankfully, I understand the medical aspects of brain fog, which causes these deep and challenging thoughts and emotions. So, this is both an existential battle and a biological reality happening simultaneously. The two are not separate; the purification process operates through both channels. Therefore, I am not going to get overly alarmed, though it has been lack of sleep over years that has intensified it and the stress that comes from it.
 
 What do you do, Maharaj, when all these emotions rise to the surface and feel overwhelming? Perhaps I may be answering my own question as to what you'd say? And that is to take continued shelter of Krishna and the holy name.
 That I'm doing, Maharaj. But I am putting into writing what I truly need: would you watch over me and help me navigate this period where the biological and spiritual purification are converging so intensely? I'm not a nowhere man, though it feels that way when the world seems so cruel and the internal work so demanding.
 This might not be the place to present such details, though these are grave concerns I have for the position of the movement right now and my service, and what I should best direct myself in.
 
 My heartfelt prayers for your extensive services to gloriously continue and for the care and support for your good health.
 Your servant,
 Chaitanya Jivan Das

 Lord Chaitanya descended out of His causeless mercy
 To bestow what no incarnation had offered before to all the unworthy—

 Unless one is favored by a pure devotee, they cannot attain Krishna Bhakti.
 I have only been saved from material existence by your śakti.
 The only way to not succumb to our lower nature is to take full shelter of pure devotees—
 Otherwise our material senses can be carried away by the breeze.
 You are such a liberated Vaiṣṇava, but you are more than that.
 Bhakti Charu Mahārāja said you are an eternally liberated associate of the Lord, and that is a fact.

 To touch his feet and told you to sit with him on the stage.
 You have descended to help him liberate all of us from our material cage.
 The story of Ghanashyam Baba in The Journey Home reveals
 One of your most primary teachings and important appeals:
 “tṛṇād api sunīcena” — more humble than a blade of grass.
 You have taught us to imbibe this verse as our first test in class.
 We have to become more tolerant than a tree
 If we want to be a devotee and have the key
 To chant Hare Krishna constantly — we need to wear this verse around our neck
 And know that in Krishna’s creation we are but a tiny speck.
 You say:
 
 “A humble heart is one that gives no resistance to the natural flow of grace,
 It is similar to how small we feel in relation to the ocean when we stand in that beautiful place.”
 
 You teach us that:
 
 “We all have infinite importance because God loves each of us,
 And we only need to be grateful for His love” and decide to discuss
 His loving pastimes and glories and chant His Name,
 And live in harmony with His will, making that our life’s aim.
 
 A tree bears the sun in the summer and gives its shade.
 You have sacrificed more for us, and your love will never fade.
 You want us to respect others and never desire to be respected—
 I see this teaching you, yourself, have perfected.
 Everywhere you go in the world, people praise you,

While I have accompanied devotees to outdoor locations like Wembley Central Station, Wembley Ealing Road and many other locations, including Monthly Sankirtan Festivals, Prema Vilasini devi dasi has rendered service at the book table in the Sri Krishna Haveli. I continue to perform my Monday midday service washing pots and cleaning up after The Raj Bhaga offering at the Manor. Prema Vilasini devi dasi continues to help pujaris cook for the Deities at Bhaktivedanta Manor and the Soho Temple, while continuing her fortnightly service in the pujari room at the Manor and Soho temples.

Looking back at our lives since we came to London in 1996, we feel Sri Krishna is guiding us in our lives, giving us the opportunity to associate with devotees, to learn the essence of devotional service and to render selfless service. By being close to the Manor 10 minutes away by car, we feel privileged to be able to regularly visit the Manor for darshan, to attend courses by School of Bhakti and to render devotional service.

Although we do not deserve the causeless mercy that has somehow been showered upon us, we remain sincerely grateful for this incredible mercy and the wonderful association of devotees that remains our mainstay and support. Our eternal gratitude to our Founder-Acarya who laid the foundation of the ISKCON movement and under whose umbrella we remain committed servants. It is through the mercy of Srila Prabhupada that we came to know of the life and teachings of Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu, the combined form Sri Sri Radha-Krishna.

The beautiful Holy month of Kartik has just ended during which we had the opportunity to render more service, chant and read more. This incomparable month is truly blissful and provides great impetus for us to be sincere in our devotional practices.

In line with your instructions, we are endeavouring to remain the servants of the servants of the servants, rendering service to one and all without any expectation of praise or reward.

As we are both over 70 years of age, we have naturally slowed down. Nevertheless, we remain determined to render service on a regular basis. We humbly beg you to bless us that we continue to serve the Vaisnavas with love and affection.

We both look forward to having your association next month at the Festival of Gratitude at Govardhan ECO Village on 7 December 2025.

In gratitude, we remain, your eternal servants,
Chandra Caitanya das
Prema Vilasini devi dasi
London UK

Hare Krishna,
 
 Guru Dev, for the last one year, our community of god brothers and god sisters residing here in Sri Vrindavan Dham, have been coming together every fortnight to relish “JOURNEY HOME” through your recorded recitation – a precious gift of yours to all of us. In these meetings, we try to hear one or two chapters and then, based on that, we share our reflections.
 
 I can confidently admit that it has been extremely nourishing association for each one of us. Hearing your inner thoughts in your own voice, with deep emotions from your heart, has gifted us your cherished divine Sanga and such connectivity that cannot be expressed in words.
 
 This has not only helped us to unite as a god family, but has also helped us to grow together in our understanding through your struggles, what it means to be a sincere, devoted, and surrendered disciple. Sure enough, I am far from being such a follower, but yes, Guru Maharaj, I am gradually realizing the significance of carrying the responsibility of being faithful to our Guru and to the entire parampara.
 
 By Sri Sri Gaur Nitai, Sri Sri Krishna Balaram, and Sri Sri Radha Shyamsundar’s blessings, I feel so fortunate to be amongst our Sanga group all your wonderful children in Sri Vrindavan Dham to celebrate your 75th divine appearance day.
 
 Guru Dev, your godly qualities are innumerable, and to choose and glorify any one is beyond my capacity. However, by regularly hearing from you, your amazing experiences about your inner journey has highlighted for me one specific trait of your divine personality.
 
 In your search for God, you met with many people with different behaviors and spiritual practices, from an ordinary person to highly elevated souls. And from every interaction, you tried to take only that which could help you in your longing to know God and love Him. Impressed by the purity of your desire, you attracted everyone’s heart, and you made many friends during your travels. So much so that even after accepting Srila Prabhupada your most beloved Guru Maharaj’s shelter, those acquaintances, from whom many had become your lifelong friends, they fondly look forward to being with you.
 
 “The deepest *vapu* is actually when we surrender to the *vani*. We can truly experience the presence of our beloved Gurus according to our willingness to surrender with love to please them.” These profound words from your opening lecture during the Govardhan Yatra this time say it all.
 
 While describing the episode about Vajranabha, the great grandson of Krishna trying to excavate Vrindavan’s lost holy places, you said, “Actually, when I read this story in *Gopal Champu*, I was remembering when Srila Prabhupada came to Butler, Pennsylvania, in New York City, and he was trying so hard to do the mission of his Guru Maharaj, but everything seemed to be failing, and it seemed to be hopeless, and it seemed so helpless.” I was wondering… such absorption where Guru and Krishna become inseparable.
 
 This amazing quality of yours has made me realize that the deeper we connect with God through our Guru’s *vani*, more and more we are freed from the externals and dualities of this world, and we are able to appreciate the essence in all without being entangled by the superficialities of the material world. With that maturity of fine balance, we can be of different sects, following a specific *sampradaya*, still, we can be welcoming and be sensitive towards other beliefs, and without being disloyal to our own Guru and Acharyas, we can offer our heartfelt respects to others.
 
 Guru Dev, I gain a lot of strength in my own spiritual practice from observing how you are always in the company of Srila Prabhupada’s *vani* – his every word, impressions, desires are your life and soul, what to speak of his instructions. The depth of your knowledge of his books is so thorough; you ponder on every word and scrutinizingly study each line, and very carefully, you take pains to train us in the same way.
 
 Srila Guru Dev, I humbly pray that instead of trying to imitate you and endanger my spiritual life, let me honestly follow in your footsteps, adhering to the teachings of our parampara, and become fixed up in the *siddhanta* of our philosophy, and not get carried away by the flowery words of the shallow world. And hopefully, one day I may also develop this maturity of seeing everything and everyone in connection with you and Krishna.
 
 On this most auspicious birthday day of yours, I humbly beg for your compassionate blessings upon myself and all of us as followers of Srila Prabhupada, that we remain fully loyal to him and to our parampara, and at the same time, do not judge or criticize others or even look down upon others, bringing pain to Srila Prabhupada and Krishna.
 
 Your insignificant servant,
 Chandrika Radha Devi dasi

In the desert of my restless mind,
You became the cooling rain,
Each drop of Your compassion fell
To wash away lifetimes of pain.

Your silence too was filled with grace,
A sacred, healing art.

Your footsteps carve the path of love,
So gentle, yet so strong;

Is life’s most glorious song.

Just service pure and sweet;

Behind Your lotus feet.

Dearest Gurudeva,
 
 On the most auspicious occasion of your 75th Vyasa Puja, I take a few moments to appreciate your profound, glorious, transcendental, divine and yet deceivingly human-like qualities that take the form of an acronym RADHA:
 
 R – Relentless Consistency
 A – Anchored yet Adaptable
 D – Diligent Hearing
 H – Helpless Dependence, Thoughtful Action
 A – Absorption in what Truly Matters
 
 1 Relentless Consistency:
 This time in the Kartik Yatra 2025 at Govardhan, a senior counselor from Radha Gopinath temple asked me, "Do you know what's the evidence that Maharaja wants us to attend the Kartik yatra? The proof is in the action, the hard efforts which Maharaja puts in at the age of 75 to come and speak for 3 hours everyday, lead an energetic blissful kirtan for another hour and informally speak to devotees for another hour." It struck me and when I contemplated this line of thought, I couldn't agree more. Gurudev, we see how you prepare meticulous notes for your evening kathas and ensure your presence in the pandal despite poor health, sometimes even when you're on the verge of collapsing due to bodily sickness. The depth of your chanting is clearly visible and audible during the kirtans, especially when you stop in between and request us to cry out with all sincerity from the core of our hearts, one million, billion and trillion times louder. You especially emphasize auspicious days such as Srila Prabhupada's disappearance day when you personally come and sing the prayer for departed Vaisnavas Je anilo prema dhana with utmost intensity, gravity and prayerfulness. If this is not evidence that demands our reciprocation, what else is? All that we need to do is to be conscious attendees, striving to hear, contemplate and absorb every word and action that is demonstrated by you. But sometimes we fail to fulfill even this simple expectation. We must not think that we can skip the Kartik yatras because it's getting too congested with so many attendees or because we've now been around for several decades! Your consistency in every aspect of devotional service is simply mind-blowing and an outstanding example for us to emulate. Particularly your consistency in yourself leading Kartik yatras since 1986 seeing it grow from 12 to 12,000 attendees in 40 years is inspirational, given that you could easily choose to retire from the grueling yatra schedules, asking your competent senior disciples to lead instead. But you personally lead us even now because you care for us, our spiritual nourishment, upliftment and togetherness as a community united for a common cause. If there is one takeaway for me this Kartik yatra, it is, "Never miss a Kartik Yatra as long as the legacy continues!"
 
 2 Anchored yet Adaptable: Recently I have been contemplating another beautiful quality that you exhibit and which was glorified by an esteemed godbrother of yours. He said, "Radhanath Swami is the most uncompromising yet completely open-minded person I have ever seen!" This one sentence captures how you have expertly balanced fidelity to the parampara and flexibility in contemporary outreach, evident in your talks and dealings both on and off the vyasasana. In one of the evening talks in the Kartik yatra this year, you mentioned that we must be very careful to be kind and accommodating to each other and at the same time keep the ideal of pure devotional service intact. You said that most of us, being conditioned souls, are so far from that ideal that if we are not careful to keep track, we may end up never achieving that lofty goal of Krishna Prema. Generally, we tend to gravitate to extremes of compromise or rigidity and thus end up falling prey to criticism or envy. Through your example and words, though, we learn the art of fine balancing that is the very defining thread of Bhakti.
 
 3 Diligent Hearing: Another quality I'm trying to imbibe is to develop deep appreciation for your classes and instructions which can easily be missed if one is not attentive. For example, in your recent Kartik Yatra class this year, you mentioned that Madhavendra Puri, despite being embarrassed about Krishna personally coming to serve him with a pot of milk, did not allow that shame to become an obstacle in his service of excavating Gopal deity and installing him on Govardhan. This is a subtle but very critical point that shows us how devotional service is not about us our bad or good times but about pleasing the Lord and His devotees, a totally different realm and paradigm, far removed from this material world. Your diligence in hearing Srila Prabhupada's classes is evident as you so often quote from them in your classes, remembering the exact year, location, and theme of the class.
 In this connection, I recall a beautiful contemplation by HG Vrajabihari pr, which I paraphrase here: "Radhanath Swami has two aspects: a social Radhanath Swami and a spiritual Radhanath Swami. While the social Radhanath Swami blesses couples, gives names to babies, smiles lovingly at devotees and cares for their all-round holistic well-being, the spiritual Radhanath Swami pours out his heart, life, and blood into his classes, kirtans, and instructions for our spiritual progress, which he hopes we will deeply imbibe. Radhanath Swami, being a pure representative of the parampara, has not come to make our material lives better but rather to give us the greatest treasure, nothing less than pure devotional service." Generally, we look forward to and relish, cherish, and reminisce about the interactions of the social Radhanath Swami, but often fail to take your classes and kirtans seriously. We must strive to go beyond a superficial perspective and take deep shelter of your vani, which is kindly made available by RG Media in so many forms. You once said to a Belgaum mataji who had lovingly prepared Khichdi for you but you had to leave for the airport, "You are feeling bad that I'm not eating your Khichdi, but I'm feeling sad that my disciples don't hear my talks, which I have cooked with so much love and concern!" This is my prayer to you, Gurudev, that I can move forward from being a superficial to a substantial sadhaka and take advantage of the "personal instructions" in your love-cooked classes and kirtans.
 
 4 Helpless dependence, thoughtful independence: Another nuanced quality you exhibit, Gurudev, is treading the fine balance between helpless dependence and thoughtful independence in Krishna Consciousness. This means that we must practice deriving strength and nourishment in the association of devotees while simultaneously preparing to stand on our own feet based on the nourishment received in Satsanga without always depending on the physical association of devotees for every small detail. We see examples from your life in the Journey Home book, one of which happened at Mashed, Iran. Here you expressed a desire for solitude to Jeff and Ramsey and sat alone reading from the Quran in front of the holy mosque. From this, I gather that we must not fall prey to laziness and complacency in the name of dependence on Satsanga. In our own lives, by the force of circumstances beyond our control, we may be located in remote corners of the world without devotees, or in places where the existing ISKCON setup is plagued with infighting, power politics, and weak leadership. In these situations, instead of backing down and staying aloof, we must stand strong, preach, safeguard ourselves while respectfully cooperating with the local authorities to the best extent possible. This does not in any way undermine the importance of Satsanga but strives to remind us that there are times when we will be alone and we must be prepared for it. In fact, the time of death with the Paramatma accompanying us is largely a lonely journey, and we must prepare for it while we're alive and healthy. As Srila Prabhupada beautifully summarizes in the purport to SB 1.15.50, "When flying an airplane, one cannot take care of other planes. Everyone has to take care of his own plane, and if there is any danger, no other plane can help another in that condition. Similarly, at the end of life, when one has to go back home, back to Godhead, everyone has to take care of himself without help rendered by another. The help is, however, offered on the ground before flying in space. Similarly, the spiritual master, the father, the mother, the relatives, the husband, and others can all render help during one’s lifetime, but while crossing the sea one has to take care of himself and utilize the instructions formerly received." As we spend years in the movement, we must learn to spend time absorbed in the Holy Name and sharavanam to develop our unique personal individual relationship with you and our "private Paramatma," as you beautifully put it in one of your classes.
 
 5 Absorption in what truly matters: Gurudev, on your 75th birthday, when senior counselors asked you what gift they can offer, you mentioned 5 things that will please you:
 1. Go deep into hearing, chanting, and service.
 2. Cultivate the mood of pleasing Krishna.
 3. Strive to be united as a community.
 4. Practice enthusiasm to share Krishna Consciousness.
 5. Never forget that Bhakti is not about quantity but about pleasing Guru and Krishna.
 
 And you added, "This is the answer I will give whether it is the 25th, 50th, or 75th birthday. Never compromise quality for quantity and infuse quality into quantity." What a gift, Gurudev! It is easy to say "Radhanath Swami Ki Jai," but not as easy to be a devotee of substance rooted in hearing and chanting. I pray for the strength to follow these five instructions and particularly the first one of going deep into hearing, chanting, and service, which is the only means to stay connected with you on the spiritual platform perpetually in favorable or adverse circumstances and thus to the entire Gaudiya Vaishnava Guru Parampara, which you represent.
 }}
 Your Servant,

गुरु महाराज जी के श्री चरणों में अनंत कोटि प्रणाम निवेदन करता हूं।
महाराज, आपकी अनुकंपा से महाराष्ट्र के छत्रपति संभाजी नगर में इस्कॉन का केंद्र है। मेरा आदि बसस्थान कोलकाता में है। फिर भी मुझे इस्कॉन के बारे में, श्रील प्रभुपाद जी के बारे में कुछ भी विशेष जानकारी नहीं था। इस अधम, पतित जीवात्मा छत्रपति संभाजी नगर में 2008 के गौर पूर्णिमा के नगर संकीर्तन में पहली बार इस्कॉन से जुड़ा था।
***उसके बाद, आपकी महान शिष्यों के संग के कारण, भक्तों के संग के कारण मुझे जगद्गुरु श्रील प्रभुपाद जी के बारे में, हरे कृष्ण महामंत्र के बारे में, भगवान श्री चैतन्य महाप्रभु के बारे में, और अंतर्राष्ट्रीय कृष्णभावनामृत संघ के बारे में इस मनुष्य जीवन में जानने का सौभाग्य मिला है।***
मेरे माता-पिता ने मुझे जन्म दिया है, मुझे जो भी जरूरत की चीज है, सब कुछ प्रदान किया है। उसके बाद, परम पूज्य गुरु महाराज, आपकी अनुकंपा से भगवान को जानने का सौभाग्य प्राप्त हुआ है। श्री भगवान की सेवा करके इस मनुष्य जन्म को सफल करने का सौभाग्य मिला है।

**आपके जन्मदिन पर इस दास का, आपका सेवक का निवेदन है कि आपके चरणों में आश्रय मिले और भगवान की सेवा में निरपराध भाव से अंतिम सांस तक सेवा कर पाऊं, यह आशीर्वाद दीजिए।**

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my humble obeisances.
 All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 I have long desired to be in your association since the time when the Vaisnava community was celebrating your 50th anniversary. I always carried this aspiration within my heart, and even while being physically distant and unable to offer you my prostrated obeisances, I prayed for the mercy of Srila Prabhupada, through which I hoped to attain devotional service under your guidance and thus become qualified to be a servant of the servants of the servants of His Divine Grace.
 
 You teach us to live each stage revealed in the Śrī Śikṣāṣṭakam, transforming the feeling of separation from Śrī Vṛndāvana into an opportunity to manifest the Lord’s abode thousands of miles away from Vraja-bhūmi. In this way, the forests of Vrindavan conceived on the banks of the Vaitarna River are compared to the fully matured fruit of your intense meditation. Accompanied by the loving service of thousands of devotees of Śrī Śrī Rādhā-Madana-Mohana, this meditation reveals to people in general how you teach us to relish the highest stages of Kṛṣṇa-bhakti: “adarśanam marma-hataṁ karotu vā.”
 
 Upon returning to the United States, when you began to reside within the Vṛndāvana manifested in the heart of Srila Prabhupada, your beloved spiritual master taught you the art of serving in separation, transforming the hills of Marshall County into the sacred dhāma where the prema-bhaktas gather. By establishing Vṛndāvana near the Ohio River, His Divine Grace taught us to understand that Śrī Śrī Rādhā–Vṛndāvana-candra are the Supreme manifestation who allow sincere devotees, even in this very lifetime, to enter into relationship with the eternal associates of the Divine Couple. For this reason, in his commentary on Akṣepa Regret by Śrīla Narottama dāsa Ṭhākura, Srila Prabhupada emphasizes: “Krishna means Krishna with His devotees. Krishna is never alone ... Krishna Consciousness means to keep association with the devotees of Krishna.”

You respect everyone and demand no respect for yourself, allowing your fully matured tree of bhaktir-ahaitukī to bear fruits that sow love for the Divine Couple in the hearts of innumerable devotees. Inspired by your example, hundreds of thousands of beads forming the garlands of the Saṅkīrtana Movement have been distributed throughout the world. Through these sacred beads, the devotees teach us that humility and tolerance are the true wealth required to attain the sublime position of servant of the servant of the servant of Śrī Śrī Rādhā–Gopīnātha.
 
 With the garland around our necks, you teach us to plunge into the waters of the ocean of bhakti-rasa. Separated from you by the ocean of material existence, I lament the lack of association with the devotees who serve you for the highest welfare of humanity. These devotees are my greatest inspiration in the service of Śrī Śrī Guru and Gaurāṅga. Keeping them in my mind, I hope that one day I may overcome the lack of courage that prevents me from attaining the association of those souls who, under your guidance, learn to discover and preserve the true treasure of human existence.
 
 When will the day come when I may awaken to my original state of divine consciousness and thus become an instrument in your hands? When that day arrives, I will have secured my place as the servant of the servants of the servants of the Guru-paramparā of Śrī Caitanya Mahāprabhu.
 Your aspiring servant,
 Gaura Chandra das

Hare Krishna Dear Guru Maharaj,
Please accept my humble obeisances at your lotus feet.

On your very auspicious 75th appearance day, I would like to highlight one of the prominent qualities you have exhibited in your spiritually absorbed journey in this world.

You have many times in your lectures shared that the root of all virtues and good qualities lies in one quality which is gratitude. We have seen that you have spent your entire life expressing gratitude to everyone you came across. You have always remembered and highlighted the good qualities that your mother taught you in your early days. Once when you presented a beautiful rose to your mother on her birthday, which was grown and nourished by your mother herself, you shared the beautiful lesson that your mother taught you – it’s not the gift that matters, it’s the thought that matters – the thought of expressing gratitude.

In one of the vyaspuja ceremonies held in Mumbai in 2008, from deep within your heart you expressed gratitude to your father, recollecting his words he told you when you were in your teens – "I am with you my son in whatever you do. I will never leave you." You mentioned how you tested this promise of your father beyond his imagination and how the promise given by your father never wavered.

The gratitude that you have for Srila Prabhupada in your heart is oceanic. In all your classes you mention your gratitude towards Srila Prabhupada. In fact, it is impossible to find or hear such a class wherein you don’t express your deep gratitude to Srila Prabhupada. The first session in all Kartik yatras held so far, you glorify Srila Prabhupada by discussing the struggles he went through in giving us this rare gift of KC. In one of your Vyas Puja offerings in 2021 during covid times, you gave a beautiful definition to the word "Founder Acharya" – you said:
Founder Acharya is the acharya who found you and your Godbrothers/Sisters and all the devotees is the Founder Acharya. It is indeed our great fortune that we were found by Srila Prabhupada through you Guru Maharaj.
Gurudev, your love for Srila Prabhupada is evident with your knowing and understanding the mood of Srila Prabhupada from every little detail of his life. Your love for Srila Prabhupada is also seen in how you show your love, care, and affection to all your godbrothers and godsisters.

The biggest gift you have given to Srila Prabhupada is the restoration of the Bhaktivinod Bhaithak at the Ultadanga junction along with Srila Prabhupada’s birthplace in Kolkata. The place wherein the seed of ISKCON was sown is now accessible to devotees across the world.
GeV, the Bhaktivedanta Hospital, and now a new hospital in Barsana are now inspiring thousands in India and across the world to take up the teachings of Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu.
Just like you express your gratitude for Srila Prabhupada, you never miss expressing your gratitude towards all the disciples, followers, and well-wishers in your classes.
You renamed your vyaspuja celebration as the "Festival of Gratitude," considering this as a wonderful opportunity wherein everyone can openly express their gratitude towards their spiritual master, and you also express deep gratitude towards Srila Prabhupada and all our previous acharyas. In my view, this whole event is Prabhupada and Acharya-centric, as you keep yourself out of the limelight. In the last Festival of Gratitude, you didn't even take a vyas asan to give the address. You accepted a simple chair to sit wherein you were not seen at all.
In your quest for finding the Supreme Absolute Truth, you came across so many saints and babas – like Tat Wala Baba, the baba who gave you saintly robes in Rishikesh, Naga Babas, Ramesh Baba in Barsana, and many others. You learned from each one of them, remembering their teachings till date and expressing your gratitude towards them in your "Journey Home" book. Your heart was full of love and gratitude while you were eagerly making a request to the Sikh gentleman to allow you to enter India from the Ferozepur border.

The profound statement you gave in one of your lectures – "A heart full of gratitude is the abode of the Lord" – has personally touched me a lot. By your mercy, I started sharing the teachings of BG through the online Geeta Jivan sessions. It’s been 34 continuous weeks, and about 8-10 people join the classes, and a couple of them have started chanting. I am also regularly hearing the daily SPORT sessions taken by HG Mukundanand Pr Ji. On this auspicious occasion of your 75th Vyas Puja, I beg at your lotus feet and pray that I develop deep feelings of gratitude and realize the pains you have taken to give us the shelter of SP and Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. That I realize the importance of this human form of life and utilize my time in the best possible way. I also beg forgiveness for my shortcomings and mistakes that I’ve made so far. Please bless me and my family so that we remain sincere in the path of Bhakti by following your instructions and remain grateful to you throughout life.

Yours in Service,
Gaurang, Shweta &
Gaurav Mahajan

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 Recently I listened to HG Vraj Bihari Prabhu’s offering for your 75th Vyasa-Puja. He shared how, in a recent counselors’ meeting, everyone asked you what gift should be offered to you on your 75th Vyasa-Puja day. And you replied that not just for this Vyasa-Puja, but anytime in the future, if anyone asks what gift you desire, your answer will always remain the same — and that answer includes the five points below.
 
 These are not only your instructions for us — they are qualities you have personally lived as a true acharya, one who teaches by example. You never ask anyone to do anything that you yourself have not practiced in your own life. You always walk your talk. And I wanted to express in this offering that the same five “gifts” you expect from us are the very same gifts you yourself have been offering to Srila Prabhupada throughout your life.
 
 Before expanding on each of them, I humbly delineate the five gifts you desire:
 
 1. Go deep into hearing, chanting, and service
 2. Cultivate the mood of pleasing Guru and Krishna
 3. Remain united as a community
 4. Maintain enthusiasm to share bhakti
 5. Never compromise on the quality of bhakti
 
 1. Go Deep Into Hearing, Chanting & Service
 
 Your early brahmachari years in New Vrindavan are a living example of this instruction. You were constantly engaged in service, and in the brief moments between aratis you would dive into Srila Prabhupada’s books with great relish.
 
 I especially remember one Janmashtami night around 2002 or 2003, close to 1:30 a.m., when you joined a small gathering of us and lovingly shared how those few minutes of reading in between aratis were among the sweetest moments of your spiritual life.
 
 You always sat in the same spot near Hanumanji, surrounded by brahmacharis, chanting with such intensity that the entire atmosphere of the temple transformed.
 
 Your festival lectures — consistent year after year — revealed how deeply you had studied and realized those pastimes. And after hearing Srila Prabhupada’s lecture in the morning, you would eagerly share the essence with the brahmacharis the very same afternoon, sometimes even making it the theme of the next Sunday Feast class.
 
 From you we learned that true depth in bhakti comes only through steady hearing, sincere chanting, and tireless service.
 
 2. Cultivate the Mood of Pleasing Guru and Krishna
 
 Over the years, we have seen how you always strive not only to please Guru and Krishna, but also to please your God brothers.
 
 You taught us that pleasing Guru includes loving Krishna, following instructions, imbibing Guru’s mood, dedicating one’s life to Guru’s mission, and understanding and supporting Guru’s projects.
 
 I remember you once telling the brahmacharis, “I have given you all you need. Now it is your responsibility to carry on the legacy — temple, congregation, projects…”
 
 Gauranga Prabhu once narrated that Srila Prabhupada had said that in the early years ISKCON consisted mostly of Westerners, and therefore there was a need to preach to Indians. Today the situation has reversed. Understanding Srila Prabhupada’s balanced mood, you are once again successfully attracting Western seekers — especially through Govardhan Eco Village and the Bhakti Center in New York.
 
 And even with these expanding projects, you have never compromised your principle of “people over projects.”
 
 3. Remain United as a Community
 
 Unity has always been your core teaching.
 
 When you were with the brahmacharis, you would genuinely glorify the Grihasthas — their hard work, donations, and participation in temple programs. And when you were with the Hrihasthas, you would glorify the brahmacharis — their simplicity, sacrifice, and renunciation.
 
 Within ISKCON, you consistently taught us to respect every devotee — Prabhupada’s disciples and disciples of other Gurus.
 
 I vividly remember your instruction to Bhagavatam speakers: never say “my Guru Maharaj,” and not even casually say “Maharaj.” We had to say “Radhanath Swami says…” so that no listener — even if not your disciple — felt excluded or disconnected.
 
 Except during Vyasa-puja, we were strictly prohibited from publicly chanting your pranam mantra or saying “Radhanath Swami Maharaj ki jai,” even in your absence. This sensitivity demonstrated your deep concern for unity.
 
 During book distribution marathon, you would say: “Distribute more than last year — but let Chowpatty come last — so that other temples distribute even more and Srila Prabhupada’s mission expands.”
 
 Your humility and awareness taught us that unity must always take precedence over prestige.
 
 4. Enthusiasm to Share Bhakti
 
 When I served in guest reception, I constantly saw your enthusiasm in meeting newcomers — whether in your small room, in the temple hall, or whenever special guests arrived.
 
 I took great pleasure in bringing guests to meet you, and you never refused — even when you were not feeling well. My greatest joy was seeing the warmth and satisfaction on your face when I introduced someone new.
 
 And we have all witnessed how this same enthusiasm extends across the world — how you travel extensively wherever you are invited to teach and share Krishna consciousness. You speak in corporates, temples, universities, parliaments, television interviews, meetings with celebrities, politicians, dignitaries, and also the simplest common people. Your compassion never discriminates. Your eagerness to share bhakti never diminishes.
 
 5. Never Compromise on the Quality of Bhakti
 
 Srila Prabhupada said, “Now is the time to boil the milk” — to focus on training and caring for the devotees we already have.
 
 Bhagavad-gita teaches the same principle: Krishna accepts the quality of devotion, not the quantity “patram pushpam phalam toyam”. And from your New Vrindavan days until today, we have seen that wherever there is genuine quality, Krishna naturally brings quantity.
 
 My Prayer:
 
 On your 75th Vyasa-puja, I sincerely pray:
 – For your good health
 – For unlimited empowerment in uplifting and inspiring Western audiences
 – And for your mercy, so that I may cultivate these five gifts in my own life and offer them to you not only on Vyasa-puja day, but every single day
 Your servant,
 Gokulananda Das

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my humble obeisances.
 All glories to Srila Prabhupada!
 
 Wish you a very happy 75th appearance day!
 My primary connection with you has been through your vani, but as we approach this momentous milestone, my heart this year reminisces all the occasions where I have been lucky to have a personal audience and interaction with you. I ponder the lessons you taught silently in those cherished moments.
 
 1
 I first saw you in the Pune yatra 2008,
 And immediately got this message straight
 Of how much mutual love
 And cooperation meant to you,
 By seeing how you treated your god-brothers
 And sisters with all the love and care due,
 And through your asking us to form
 Many small circles around
 To dance together happily
 During the enchanting kirtan rounds.
 
 It was also my first chance
 To hear from you the trinadapi sunichena verse,
 Of being more tolerant than a tree
 And more humble than a blade of grass.
 A virtue that you practice yourself and emphasize
 Again and again in almost every class.
 
 2
 I first approached you in New Vrindaban,
 With the innocent impudence of a neophyte,
 To seek your mercy and blessings for
 Our newly conceived maiden child.
 You sweetly responded with a brimming heart
 That you would pray with all your might.
 So much love shown to a stranger,
 Leaving her fully satisfied.
 
 3
 Then you came to our home
 For lunch the one and only time,
 And taught many lessons
 By your gestures and actions pristine.
 
 Instead of ordering your preferences,
 You asked where we wanted you to sit.
 Such a humility and service attitude,
 Totally incomprehensible to our wit.
 
 You offered due prayers
 Before honoring prasad,
 Giving a peek into your
 Surrendered and grateful heart.
 
 And then when I mentioned
 That I hailed from Nainital,
 You immediately brought up
 Neem Karoli Baba and Kainchi dham.
 Hidden behind this simple exchange
 Was a beautiful virtue at its best,
 Of never forgetting those who played
 A role in your spiritual quest.
 
 4
 Then when you gave me my first initiation
 In Sri Sri Radha Kalachandji dham,
 Your servant of the servant mood
 Was the first thing that touched my heart.
 You accepted us all on behalf of
 The guru parampara and Srila Prabhupada.
 
 The next was how much love and respect
 You showed to your godbrothers at that time.
 You generously glorified Srila Gurudev,
 HH Bhakti Sundar Goswami Maharaj
 And Urjasvat Prabhu's qualities sublime.
 
 And to see you sharing the vyasaasan
 Lovingly during the fire sacrifice
 With HH Bhakti Sundar Goswami Maharaj,
 Oh, what a feast it was for our hearts and eyes!
 
 And, of course! Your all-encompassing instructions
 Given to us at that auspicious time
 Are all that I would ever need
 To succeed in my spiritual life—
 
 Understanding our true eternal self
 As a servant of the servant of Krishna’s servant,
 And surrendering to His limitless love,
 An ocean for all of us individually meant.
 
 The three pillars of naam ruchi, vaishnava seva, and jiva daya,
 Explained in the specific context of our temple,
 Strengthened by the four regulative principles
 And the virtue of never ever being critical.
 
 And your re-emphasizing the right mood
 For all services that we perform
 During my second initiation,
 Again in SS Radha Kalachandji temple room,
 By instructing me to chant my first Gayatri
 For the pleasure of Their Lordships' divine form.
 
 5
 Another important of our direct exchanges
 Was during Sadhu Sanga retreat in Boon.
 My boldly bringing a godbrother and sister
 And telling you that they were expecting soon.
 Your acknowledging that fact,
 But at the same time remaining stern,
 And in that grave moment,
 Teaching me a lesson firm
 That the spiritual master is not
 Meant to satisfy our whims,
 But it is for us, in turn,
 To reverentially serve Him.
 
 6
 Subsequently, I have had the good fortune
 Of attending many Kartik yatras
 And witnessing your enthusiasm
 For speaking Sri Hari kathas.
 Your speaking for hours together
 With such details and flair
 That everyone can picture those pastimes
 As if happening right then and there,
 Embellished with special effects of sound,
 Yet, bringing out lessons most profound.
 And with what a delightful kirtan
 Each lecture roaringly ends,
 Making the ocean of devotees
 Jubilantly dance to their hearts’ content.
 
 7
 However, the most endearingly
 Etched in my mind
 Are your visits to our dear
 Sri Sri Radha Kalachandji dham divine.
 
 A
 I will always remember that scene here
 Of your performing arati
 For Srila Prabhupada's guru puja
 With utmost diligence and gravity,
 Showcasing towards His guru
 A disciple's servitude and chastity.
 
 B
 And then your attending so many
 Outreach programs here back to back,
 Without any consideration for health
 Or trace of any slack.
 
 C
 In the disciples’ meetings here both times,
 You shared with us your extraordinary flair
 Of drawing lessons from ordinary things
 In our surroundings that may be there.
 
 The first time, you sighted the Lindsley Park tree,
 Fallen down by a tornado but surviving still,
 And continuing serving others
 Completely at their disposal and will.
 And the next time, you mentioned
 The kadamba tree in Chowpatty temple premise,
 Growing in a peculiar distorted way,
 Bending at random spots seeking sunlight,
 Thus dealing with the darkness
 By putting up a good fight.
 
 D
 And when at one of the meetings’ end,
 Rasaraj Prabhuji announced
 That we all must get back to our respective services
 For your ‘Journey Within’ book launch,
 You melted our hearts by immediately asking
 What services you needed to perform.
 
 E
 And I will always cherish seeing you
 Sitting in our temple chanting the holy names,
 And observing with great interest
 The architectural beauty of this holy place,
 And later glorifying this beautiful offering
 Made to Srila Prabhupada by Srila Gurudev,
 And your dancing in the darshan arati
 With spontaneous feelings and grace.
 
 8
 And then how can I end
 Without thanking you for all
 The mercy, kindness, and love bestowed
 Upon us insignificant souls—
 Your loving embrace to my Prabhuji,
 My father-in-law and father alike.
 Your naming both of our kids and
 Doing their first grain ceremony rite,
 Blessing them with the gentle tap
 Of your fingers on their forehead.
 Your giving my father the cake tray
 And your maha prasad garland.
 My mother and I
 Getting a chance to cook for you,
 And me getting to make
 Garlands for you too.
 Your initiating my in-laws
 As well as my parents,
 And your calling Kirtida back
 To give her prasadam remnants.
 
 Dear Guru Maharaj, as I reminisce about these moments, many more come to mind of receiving your mercy directly and indirectly in many forms. May I never forget how much I have been given. May I always cherish this treasure and always draw nourishment and spiritual strength from it. May my connection with you only grow stronger and stronger with time, and may I get the strength to practice earnestly what you have taught. My heartfelt gratitude to you, Sri Sri Radha Kalachandji, Sri Sri Radha Gopinath ji, and all the devotees who became the via media of channeling this grace.
 Wishing you a very happy 75th appearance day again,
 
 Your daughter,
 Gopi Vallabhi devi dasi

I am not at all qualified to be your disciple, but you have shown your compassion and given me hope by holding my finger and helping me navigate through the strong current of material desires.
 
 When I reflect on your life and teachings, three qualities shine like brilliant gems—your mercy, your gratitude, and your humility.
 
 Mercy -> We all know how merciful you are. You didn’t care about my qualifications. Just to please your godbrother, you accepted me under your shelter because he cares about me. You didn’t think if I would meet the standards your esteemed disciples have or whether I would be loyal to you and your teachings. You don’t see what we are, but just how by Krishna’s mercy, we can grow in our spiritual life and be a soldier in Chaitanya Mahaprabhu’s movement. I had always a desire to be a loyal soldier under this mission, and you kindly gave me my name, which resonated well with what I wanted to be. Who else can know my heart other than my beloved spiritual master?
 
 Gratitude -> Each and every word you speak reflects the depth of your gratitude—to your spiritual master, Śrīla Prabhupāda, to your godbrothers, and to every devotee who renders even the smallest service. By your example, you have taught us that gratitude is the foundation of love.  Humility -> Your humility humbles us all. On this most auspicious occasion of your 75th Birth Anniversary, I am feeling so very grateful to have your amazing and transformational association in our lives.

On this most sacred and auspicious day of your Vyāsa-pūjā, I bow my head and heart at your lotus feet, offering this simple garland of words, insufficient yet sincere, in gratitude for your causeless mercy.

🌺 1. Guru as the Embodiment of Bhagavān’s Compassion

The Bhāgavatam commands:

ācāryaṁ māṁ vijānīyān
nāvamanyeta karhicit
na martya-buddhyāsūyeta
sarva-deva-mayo guruḥ
SB 11.17.27

“Know the ācārya to be My very self.”

When I reflect on this verse, I understand how your presence in my life is Kṛṣṇa’s direct arrangement. You are His compassion incarnate—guiding, correcting, protecting, and illuminating my path with the torchlight of transcendental knowledge.

Without such guidance, I would wander endlessly through countless births, pursuing mirages of material happiness. Your mercy has given direction to a directionless soul.

🌿 2. The Necessity of Approaching Guru

The Bhāgavatam says:

tasmād guruṁ prapadyeta
jijñāsuḥ śreya uttamam
SB 11.3.21

“One seeking the highest good must surrender to a bona fide guru.”

Compelled by suffering, yet pulled by hope, I came to your lotus feet—not knowing what I needed, but knowing you held the key to everything worthwhile. By your instructions, “śreyaḥ” began to awaken within me: a dormant longing for eternal service, a desire to love Kṛṣṇa above all else.

Your words cut the bonds of ignorance, just as the sun disperses morning fog.

🔥 3. The Power of Sadhu-Saṅga and the Guru’s Instructions

Lord Kapila teaches:

satāṁ prasaṅgān mama vīrya-saṁvido
bhavanti hṛt-karṇa-rasāyanāḥ kathāḥ
SB 3.25.25

In your association, your words enter not only my ears but my heart. Your hari-kathā intoxicates the soul and awakens a longing for the path of devotion.

By hearing from you, faith becomes conviction; conviction becomes service; and service becomes love. Thus, as Kapiladeva concludes, śraddhā, rati, and bhakti naturally arise by serving the devotees.

🌸 4. Only by Guru’s Mercy Can One Approach the Lord

Prahlāda Mahārāja states:

naiṣāṁ matis tāvad urukramāṅghriṁ
spriśaty anarthāpagamo yad-arthaḥ
mahīyasāṁ pāda-rajo’bhiṣekaṁ
niṣkiñcanānāṁ na vṛṇīta yāvat
SB 7.5.32

Without the dust of the great souls’ feet, no one can approach the lotus feet of Kṛṣṇa.

It is that dust—your dust—which has sanctified my life.
To be allowed to carry even a particle of your instruction is the wealth of lifetimes.
By bathing in that sacred dust, the stains of anarthas begin to fade, and the soul remembers its true identity.

🌼 5. Guru Opens the Door to Liberation

Ṛṣabhadeva teaches:

mahat-sevāṁ dvāram āhur vimukteḥ
SB 5.5.2

“Service to great souls opens the door to liberation.”

For me, this means that serving you—your instructions, your mission, your devotees—is the only highway to freedom.

Your compassion has opened a door not only to liberation but to something far greater: an invitation to serve in the loving domain of Śrī Śrī Rādhā-Kṛṣṇa.

🌿 6. The Guru as the One Who Awakens Taste for Bhakti

The Bhāgavatam begins its instructions with the foundation of spiritual life:

syān mahat-sevayā viprāḥ
puṇya-tīrtha-niṣevaṇāt
SB 1.2.16

By serving great souls, one gains taste for Vāsudeva-kathā.
It is by your mercy that the holy name has become sweet, the scriptures alive, and service meaningful.

Without your guidance, I would still be entangled in the illusions of material identity, unaware of the treasure hidden within the heart.

🌺 7. My Humble Prayer

Śrīmad-Bhāgavatam often glorifies the disciple's mood:

yasya prasādād bhagavat-prasādo
yasyāprasādān na gatiḥ kuto’pi

“By the mercy of the guru one gets the mercy of Kṛṣṇa; without it, there is no advancement.”

This truth resounds in every step of my life.
If I have any hope, it is because of you.
If I have any strength, it is borrowed from you.
If I have any devotion, it is planted by you.

🙏 8. Conclusion – My Offering at Your Feet

Gurudeva, on this most auspicious day of your Vyāsa-pūjā, I offer:

my mind—though restless, I place it at your feet;
my words—imperfect, yet longing to glorify you;
my heart—impure, yet yearning for your shelter;
my life—may it be used wholly in your service.
Please bless me with:

unwavering faith in your instructions,
the strength to follow your example,
humility in service,
and the aspiration to become a servant of your servants.
May I forever remain a particle of dust at your lotus feet.

Your insignificant servant,
seeking shelter,
Harivallabha Dasa and Kumari Devi Dasi

Dear Gurudeva,
 
Please accept my most humble obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet.
All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 The arrival of this most auspicious day reminds us of the divine words in Śrī-bṛhad-bhāgavatāmṛta which Nārāyaṇa speaks to his devotee Gopa-kumāra who, after his spectacular journey spanning multiple planetary systems and beyond in the search for his desired goal, has arrived in Vaikuntha. Welcoming Gopa-kumāra, Nārāyaṇa sighs anxiously, remarking that until then, how many lifetimes Gopa-kumāra had spent without paying attention to Him. "I was dancing like a fool," Nārāyaṇa, overwhelmed with love, addresses himself so, as He has been waiting lifetimes after lifetimes for Gopa-kumāra. Couldn't He force Gopa-kumāra? No, the Lord never tries to change the nature of the little jīva who seems to prefer bondage from time immemorial, or the nature of māyā who prefers to bind the jīvas for so long too.
 
 Gurudeva, this is the condition of this fallen, wretched servant of yours. It seems as though bahirmukhatā—tendency to turn away from Kṛṣṇa—has become a part of me. Is there any sign of hope?
 
 But Bhagavān is an influencer. The next words Nārāyaṇa speaks in the same passage of Śrī-bṛhad-bhāgavatāmṛta melts my heart in hope. Crying in joy, Nārāyaṇa says, "You showed me no mercy, and as I considered this, I grew impatient, full of anxiety to receive your favor. So, I transgressed my eternal code of conduct and arranged for you to take your current birth. Dear boy, in that divine district of Govardhana, my most beloved abode, I myself became your guru, known by the name Jayanta."
 
 Outcome—finally Gopa-kumāra basks in the loving embrace of Bhagavān.
 
 On this day, remembering this heart-rendering exchange penned by Śrīla Sanātana Goswāmi, my dark heart palpitates with mixed feelings. Gratitude soars in the heart on one hand, that in order to resolve the impasse between my belligerence to remain turned away from Kṛṣṇa and māyā's constant torment, Kṛṣṇa has surely intervened by sending you—the embodiment of His energy and mercy—to take me out of this precarious situation. On the other hand, there is gloom in the heart, that when will I really understand the good fortune that has been bestowed causelessly—of being initiated and allowed shelter under the lotus feet of a perfect spiritual master in a bonafide lineage; of the most rare opportunity to follow in the footsteps of the eternal Vrajavāsī like yourself to reach the perfection of loving devotional service in the groves of Śrī Vṛndāvana as the servant of the servant of Śrī Rādhā.
 
 With straw in my mouth, and kaṇṭha on my neck, I fall at your lotus feet today on the most auspicious day of your appearance. I know my deliverance would be predicated primarily on Kṛṣṇa's mercy coming through you, still, as a fledgling soul with free will, I sincerely recommit to make your instructions the center stage of my life and to the best of my capacities endeavor to that effect, to make your will and not my ego the guiding light of my sojourn in this material world. And in this way, I pray to keep that hope burning, the hope which kept Gopa-kumāra alive in his search for perfection.
 
 I pray to the cintāmaṇi dhāma of Śrī Vṛndāvana and Śrī Vṛndāvanēśvarī Rādhā that they bestow the best of health to you, so that you may be here with us for long and long years, pleasing Śrīla Prabhupāda in leaps and leaps, engaging us in your service to him more and more.
 
 Śrī Rādhe

 In your lectures, we find many instructions which are very crucial for our growth, progress and safety in Krishna consciousness. I remember when we just landed up in the association of devotees, many things were very difficult for us to compile, understand and maneuver through. That time we found a lot of shelter in your lectures, Maharaja - we remember listening to some of the lectures around 10-15 times!!!
