HH Bhakti Vijnana Goswami Maharaja told that you asked him to continue staying in Russia that time because you had stayed back in New Vrindavan, the sole reason being the fact that devotees can have someone to take shelter of. Even in such an environment, you never criticized, complained and offended anyone and carried on with your services. And such incredible tapasya!!! Infathomable!!! When one devotee didn't care for you when you fell down from the pony, you never had grudges against that devotee - this is very, very difficult. That holds true for much of your stay in New Vrindavan. When all your preaching projects in USA were stopped, it must have hurt you - but you never complained. I once heard that you kept records of various ups and downs in New Vrindavan, not because of fault-finding, but because you wanted to keep a record of what not to do in a temple - all those things were incredibly taken care of when you took up and grew ISKCON Chowpatty. When we hear about HG Radheshyam Prabhu, HG Gauranga Prabhu, HG Shyamananda Prabhu, HG Radha Gopinath Prabhu and HG Vrindavan Prabhu regarding the initial days in Chowpatty, we are amazed how you transformed the temple by your example, purity and instructions. When they share about their questions they posed to you and what amazing answers you gave, it's just out of the box; rooted in deep, KC philosophy and practical to the highest degree. Some of them are as follows:
 1 We never thought we are qualified enough to get the personal association of Srila Prabhupada.
 2 Q - Who should we allow to sing in the temple? Ans - If the devotee is very advanced, we should give him singing for the Deities even if he is not such a good singer. But if there are new people around...
 3 Q - How can I know in a particular situation whether I am following what you want me to follow and you are not around for guidance? Ans - If you sincerely follow what I have told you to follow, then Krishna will inspire you to do what I want you to do when I am not available for guidance.
 4 Q - How to tolerate devotees? Ans - Just tolerate them the way I am tolerating you.
 5 We should honestly avoid the association of the opposite sex.
 6 Q - What to do when we know that some devotee is treading wrong trajectories and his downfall is certain? Ans - We should have some means to ensure that he stops doing that. If he is not listening, we can just leave them, and whatever has to happen will happen to them.
 7 Look at any situation from three levels: how it affects the individual devotee, how it affects the society of devotees, and how it impacts the outside people. Then make appropriate decisions.
 8 Q - How do you have so many loving relationships despite having differences of opinion? Ans - I focus on the similarities and do not focus on the differences.
 9 Even if we struggle, foam in the mouth, undergo hardships, to bring just a smile on the face of Vaisnavas, we should happily do it.
 10 If you don't have something to die for, there's nothing you can live for.

This is very distinctly visible in your life.
 
 Your philosophical understanding is amazing. In one of your question and answer sessions during the early days of Chowpatty, you had mentioned that just by our efforts we cannot chant the Holy Names of the Lord. We need the mercy and blessings of Vaisnavas, and we acquire that by serving the devotees, doing Vaisnava seva. This integral aspect of devotional service was not my focus for a long period of time. But when I followed this instruction of yours, to acquire blessings, I found that not only chanting improved but many obstacles I was able to fight. That's when I had a slight understanding of the import of being the servant of the servant of the servant.

This left the devotee spellbound and he happily reverted his decision. You were there for HG Stoka Krishna Prabhu when he needed you the most.
 
 Presently I am serving in Kharagpur. We are engaged in preaching to the first years under the guidance of HG Mukund Lila Prabhu. Also, we are trying to carry out research in the field of consciousness and trying to glorify Bhagavad Gita and Srimad Bhagavatam.

 Dearest Gurudeva,
 
 My heartfelt obeisances at your extraordinarily merciful lotus feet. Glories to Srila Prabhupada and his army of stalwart soldiers like yourself who are absolutely unreal. Majestic.
 
 This year I find myself meditating on the meaning of "lotus feet". We read and hear about it so much and it is used so casually; it's a pet peeve to hear it being used loosely in conversation. A lotus, growing in the muck, rises gracefully and blooms, then sinks silently in the gloom, day after day. Its fragrance unaffected, its beauty unrestricted. The putrid slime rolls off it every dawn, the untainted, delicate wonder of nature. Its roots grow deep and hold the lotus strong—in that murky mess! Oh, why does the lotus not find another home, more suited to match its simple, pure self? Rather, it anchors itself there, thriving, serving to purify the water and soil from excess nutrients and pollutants. It contributes in such a phenomenal way—by being there simply, and adding color and loveliness in an otherwise seemingly unattractive space. Isn't this how you have led your life from your very childhood? You have seen the world, Srila Gurudeva, the great, terrible, and repulsive. The upside-down rainbow of your smile...so innocently charming and unlimitedly compassionate. You're that lotus, dearest Gurudeva.
 
 And your feet have traversed no-man's lands and badlands and lands that take away all the bads, the dhams. A man goes where his feet take him, and yours have been invariably attracted to śrī rūpa mañjarī pada. You have put your unshakable faith and sought shelter in the line of impeccable ācāryas, and that very same sanctuary you have come to transparently extend to us here. Mind-bogglingly unfathomable, yet an irrevocable fact. Each word of the Guru Vandana prayer rings true, and when I can sing, it is a window into Srila Prabhupada's place in your heart and Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's place in the heart of Srila Prabhupada and so on. Yours ARE lotus feet, dearest Gurudeva. I may never conceive the full meaning, though I say with absolute certainty that it is the most freeing truth. I pray to tightly grasp onto it and keep it close to my heart forever.
 ----
 Over five millennia ago, our sweet Lord brought the Vrajavasis to Govardhan for seven days and nights. You also manifested a Yatra that brought us all together, from different corners of the world, for seven days and nights. All our eyes were on the look-out for you, searching, or on you whenever the opportunity would present itself. And you'd reciprocate with us all appropriately, like our sweet Lord did with the Vrajavasis. We've prayed deeply together and danced ecstatically in your offerings of kirtan. You have thoughtfully, prayerfully, and lovingly manifested the Govardhan Ecovillage as a service to our beloved Srila Prabhupada, the service from which I'm certain without a doubt, the universes are benefitting! HG Baladeva Prabhu had shared how the Yatra happening at Govardhan was nothing short of "amazing," beginning with it being a long-standing desire of yours. My tiny heart had also been pining for that place with so much personality...and you're truly a desire tree. I'm reflecting on the Yatra that was, and it is bittersweet; I have such a longing to be back there...in the association of remarkable devotees from across the globe. Such a dream! Like bees drawn to the lotus—YOU drew us to you, sweetest Gurudeva.
 
 To mark your diamond jubilee, my kind senior Godbrothers have made romantic efforts like doing a 75-day glorification countdown to your appearance day, and also 75 lessons to be learned from your life as cited in your autobiography, The Journey Home. All this, to please you of course, and more so to uplift those like myself who are incapable of even scratching the surface of the deep mysteries of your unbelievable magnanimity and spotless character. On this most auspicious and holiest of all days, I celebrate you with a prayerful, gratitude-filled heart. I gleefully rejoice that though you are not of this world, you have appeared at a time when I came to attend to some "unfinished business" on this planet—and by some stroke of luck, mostly your deep concern for aimlessly floating jiva-baddhas like myself, you have showered your benevolent glance at me and accepted me. To me, you're that treasure that has no bounds. I pray for your good health so you may continue to touch thousands upon thousands with your bottomless compassion and unmatched humility. I pray that I may get the eyes to appreciate a droplet of the love and dedication that you have for serving Srila Prabhupada in the mood of *dāsa-anudāsānudāsa* eternally, and that I may experience even a fraction of that dedication towards you.
 
 Your servant and daughter,
 Hladini-gopika devi dasi

Please accept my humble obeisances at your lotus feet. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
Since the time you came into my life, I have understood why it is said that the Guru is Krishna Himself. When Srila Prabhupada teaches us, he explains that we cannot see Krishna with our material eyes. And now I understand—out of His mercy, Krishna sends the Guru into our lives so that through the Guru we can feel His presence. Still, even then, we are not able to truly see you as you really are, but whatever little we can perceive is only by Krishna’s kindness upon us.
That is when I realized why the Guru is said to be Krishna. Earlier, I could not understand this—I just accepted it out of respect but never felt it deeply. Now I feel it—Guru is Krishna, and you are my Krishna.
I’m sorry, Maharaj, but when I feel for you, I even understand the real meaning of some Bollywood songs—for example, “Tera mujhse hai pehle naata koi, yun hi nahi dil lubhata koi.” 😅

You have showered so much mercy on me, Maharaj—more than I could ever expect. You have given me far beyond what I deserve—like putting a diamond in the hands of a beggar.
Now it is my turn, Maharaj. Please bless me so that I can somehow pay back your mercy by walking on your path, always respecting you and everyone else, becoming a good person, and practicing bhakti sincerely. I am not able to do much on my own, but with your help, I know I can.

Maharaj, I sincerely pray that Krishna blesses you with strong health, long life, and unlimited protection. So many people receive mercy, guidance, and hope because of you—including a sinful and fallen person like me. Please stay healthy and strong so that countless souls can continue to receive your compassion. May Krishna always keep you under His divine shelter and give you every strength and comfort.
With all my heart,
Your servant

Last year, on December 27th, after years of waiting, out of your causeless love and compassion, you finally accepted me as a servant. I wish to treasure that day, that moment, forever in the core of my heart. That day, I faced you for the first time ever. I bowed down, hesitant to look right into your eyes, and I offered my vows. While I am sure that you were all cognizant of my wretched, undeserving condition, you extended your hand to bless me with your chanted beads, while HG Radheshyam Prabhu announced my new name - Isvara Mukunda Das. You have always been as worshipable as Bhagavan for me, Guru Maharaj, and HG Radheshyam Prabhu has always been my shiksha guru, the life force in my sadhana bhakti. Nothing could have been more fortunate than to get initiation from you in his presence.

From that day on, I am always restless. Your merciful self and my shiksha guru have done such a great favor on me. What do I do to reciprocate? How do I satisfy you? How do I express my love and gratitude to you, Guru Maharaj? My mind is always questioning my servitude to you. I am chanting. I am reading. I am hearing. I am serving with devotees. I am preaching. Everything is an offering for your pleasure, but I lack contentment. After trying to convince me with several philosophical arguments, I am still striving to offer something tangible to satisfy you, Guru Maharaj. Indeed, a serious lack of sincerity and personal purity are undeniable causes for the same.

A child’s innocence remains protected in its dependence upon the father. To please you also, I am utterly dependent upon your kindness. On this blessed day, I beg for the ability and sincerity to serve you, to please you, to satisfy you. I pray at your lotus feet, Guru Maharaj, that no distraction or disturbance may take me away from the association of your sincere servants. Let me remain loyal to your command, my master! Let me be able to fight my own conditionings and lower self with sincerity in sewa and sadhana! Let me never become forgetful of your ultimate kindness upon my lowly self. Let me never bring any disgrace to your glory or ever discourage devotees with my immaturity in dealings and personal conduct. Please protect me from shadowy motivations, Guru Maharaj. Often, the hidden lust for power, recognition, and prestige takes the garb of devotional service. May your divine example and pure teachings be my guiding light across all these dark lanes.

If it pleases you, dear Guru Maharaj, I beg for the shelter at your lotus feet life after life. Not as a parasite but as an obedient, unpretentious servant of your servants.

Once again, sincerest prayers for your health, Guru Maharaj. It is true that bodily discomforts do not affect your transcendental self, but it does pain your servants to see you go through any external health challenges just to keep us all motivated. May Sri Sri Radha Vrindavanbihari Ji bestow all of us with your merciful, ecstatic presence for eternity!

Your Unworthy Servant,
Isvara Mukunda Das

Dear Gurudev,
 
 Please accept my humble obeisance!
 All glories to Srila Prabhupada!
 
 Time, our greatest silent enemy, relentlessly rushes toward its goal. Sometimes we manage to seize the day and remain dedicated to the mission of Srila Prabhupada, but most often, covered by the illusory energy, we allow time to steal from us the precious moments of Krishna consciousness.
 
 It feels as if yesterday was last year’s Vyasa-puja, when we prayed for health, mercy, and love for our most beloved Gurudev.
 
 Meanwhile, a lot of water has passed through Mother Ganga, and many events have passed through our lives as well. The question of whether we have been better than last year, and whether we are becoming more firmly grounded in Krishna consciousness, will hover constantly — chasing us just as time mercilessly pushes us toward yet another old age, toward yet another departure from this body…
 
 The only light in these conditioned lives of ours — in which we mostly struggle with our own selves — is you, dear Gurudev. Our last meeting with you has kept me for long in an euphoric, transcendental mood. But as time that terrible enemy of the devotees passes, the memories slowly fade, and with them the energy we captured from your presence.
 
 The new times we live in have taken a lot from us, but also have given us a lot. They have given us the opportunity to always be online with you, to hear your transcendental talks, through which again and again you bring us back to the right path — the path toward home, a path on which without your guidance we cannot go far.
 
 Just as Krishna’s calves unconditionally followed Krishna through good and bad, fulfilling all His instructions, so I, the most fallen of your disciples, try to follow your instructions and try to steal at least a small smile of satisfaction from you. The reward of Krishna’s calves for their service is eternal; time can do nothing to them, and again and again — untouched by forgetfulness — they delight in loving service to Krishna. Immersed in their pure love for their Govinda, they receive the mercy to be far from duality, change, and the fleeting nature of this miserable material world.
 
 Happy that I have you as my guiding Vaikuntha star, I celebrate this auspicious day — Vyasa-puja, because for me, Gurudev, you are my Krishna; you are the only light that protects me in the darkness of Kali-yuga and the burdens of everyday material life. Continue to lead us, help us, and be our guide on this unique journey home. Without you we are lost, condemned to defeat by the illusory energy.
 
 I wish you everything that can be wished for the dearest person in this life — love, service, best disciples, companionship with Krishna, health, and the eternal smile on your beautiful face that again and again gives us strength and energy to remain in Krishna consciousness.
 
 Please protect and guide us in the best way you know and can. For me, all that remains is to give my life to this beautiful mission of Srila Prabhupada and to pray again and again for eternal service to you, dear Gurudev, amidst the claws of this material world which only you make transcendental. It does not matter where we may be in service — only keep us within it.
 
 The time is short and precious. I will try to make him my best friend serving your lotus feet.
 I surrender them and rejoice in every new opportunity for service. I once again wish you best on this auspicious day and send all my love to you, dear Gurudev.
 
 Your humble servant,
 Jagajivana dasa

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my humble obeisances at your divine lotus feet. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 Maharaj, your divine appearance day celebration this year is very special and historical.
 This year began with the historical celebration of Maha Kumbha Mela which appeared after 144 years, occurring only once in our lifetime.
 
 This year also marked the 60th anniversary of the historical event of Srila Prabhupada boarding Jaladuta and leaving for the West for creating a worldwide revolution, which is occurring only once in our lifetime.
 
 This year is ending with the historical celebration of the 75th divine appearance day of your holiness who left the Western world to assist Srila Prabhupada in his worldwide revolution, which is occurring only once in our lifetime.
 
 Maharaj, this confluence of Triveni Sangam itself is happening once in our lifetime, and hence we are unlimitedly fortunate and blessed to witness these events unfolding together in our lifetime.
 
 As per the Samvatsar calendar, which has a cycle of 60 years, this year is the same year when Srila Prabhupada boarded the Jaladuta. In the historical year of 1965, when Srila Prabhupada boarded the Jaladuta, the Samvatsar year was “Vishvavasu”. The same Samvatsar “Vishvavasu” has come again this year in 2025 after 60 years. Hence, as per the Samvatsar, this year is the first anniversary of the historical event of Srila Prabhupada boarding Jaladuta, which will indeed be the only anniversary for us in our lifetime.
 
 Srila Prabhupada travelled in different countries across the world as a cultural ambassador with a message of world peace and global unity. Continuing Srila Prabhupada’s legacy, over these decades you have offered your unparalleled contribution in expanding Srila Prabhupada’s message of world peace and global unity across the world.
 
 At a young age of 17, you left the comforts of the Western world with practically no money and resources and hitchhiked to India, risking your life in search of God. In India, you lived a life of a monk and dedicated your life to the welfare of society, as you had promised to the guard while requesting him to allow you to enter the borders of India.
 
 While we are fortunate to be blessed by your holy association, we would like to seek this opportunity to assist you in humbly offering our insignificant contribution at the lotus feet of Srila Prabhupada.
 
 Dear Maharaj, on the occasion of your 75th appearance day, this fallen soul humbly seeks your blessings and begs for your causeless mercy so that we can at least try to offer our insignificant contribution in your service to spread the message of world peace and global unity. While praying for your blessings, we very well know that the contribution which we are trying to offer you is nothing compared to the contribution you have made to the world in service to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 Maharaj, when you came to India for a higher cause, you were alone; we are many. You were penniless; we are earning. You had no place to reside; we have our homes. You physically endured hardships travelling across the world; the world for us is just a click away. Yes, Maharaj, today, with the advancement of technology, we have all comforts and luxuries to assist you in offering our contribution of taking Srila Prabhupada’s message across the world, still our contribution is insignificant because although:
 
 - We do have all the comforts of reaching out to the world from our homes, but we don’t have the compassion which you give to the world in service to Srila Prabhupada.
 - We do have all the luxuries to connect with people through technology, but we don’t have the love with which you connect with people across the world in service to Srila Prabhupada.
 - We do have all the facilities to take Srila Prabhupada’s message across the world, but we don’t have the faith you have in your Guru’s instruction to spread his message across the world.
 
 Maharaj, we have nothing to offer you. We only have Srila Prabhupada’s words in the form of his prayer which we can offer you so that if we receive your causeless mercy then we can at least hope to have some qualification so that we can have something to offer to the world. I don’t have the qualification to offer prayers directly to the Lord, but by your causeless mercy, I know I can offer you Srila Prabhupada’s prayers which he offered to the Lord just before he created a worldwide revolution.
 
 Maharaj, I humbly beg for your causeless mercy so that we can try to assist you in offering our insignificant contribution of taking Srila Prabhupada’s message of world peace and global unity to the world.
 
 I know your causeless mercy can make everything possible because you are the most expert mystic. I am very unfortunate, unqualified, and the most fallen. Therefore, I am seeking your benediction so that I can convince them, for I am powerless to do so on my own.

 Translation
 
 “According to their karma, all living entities are wandering throughout the entire universe. Some of them are being elevated to the upper planetary systems, and some are going down into the lower planetary systems. Out of many millions of wandering living entities, one who is very fortunate gets an opportunity to associate with a bona fide spiritual master by the grace of Kṛṣṇa. By the mercy of both Kṛṣṇa and the spiritual master, such a person receives the seed of the creeper of devotional service."
 
 We wander through this world, and by the mercy of the Lord, this world is blessed by the presence of saintly, divine souls — the beloved of the Lord, the beloved of Lord Krishna. Such souls are exceedingly rare and difficult to find, and even more difficult to associate with. They are powerhouses of mercy, kindness, and divine qualities.

 Your long lectures and teachings, infused with love, care, and compassion, give us life, hope, and knowledge — without which our spiritual journey would be unthinkable. Sometimes, just a few minutes of your time are enough to protect a devotee from the danger of going astray. You never hesitate to walk long distances to visit a disciple in the hospital, or to call and speak with someone in the moment they need you most. The sacrifice of your precious time for our enlightenment is the pinnacle of your mercy.

Although your presence in this world is rare, Krishna allowed our paths to cross, so that ordinary, insignificant, and fallen souls like us could receive a chance — a priceless opportunity. On this auspicious day of your anniversary, we pray that you continue to grant us this chance, and that we may never fail to use it properly.

We pray, our beloved Gurudev, that whatever we receive on our spiritual journey may be used wisely, and only for the purpose for which it was intended. 
 
 Your servants,

You are so present through your *vani* form and also through the sweet memories of all your reciprocations that you kindly offer. Srila Prabhupada, during one of his last days on this planet Earth, said to his disciples: “It is my duty to increase your love for me.” You are also doing this with all of us disciples. My life is yours; please make me dance.
I also pray that Sri Sri Radha Gopinath will always protect you physically, mentally, and spiritually.
Your insignificant and grateful servant,

Dear Gurumaharaj,
 
 Please accept my humble obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet, all glories to Srila Prabhupada!
 
 This is a very special occasion of your 75th birthday. I wonder what you may be contemplating for this occasion, and your meditation has always been about how to serve Srila Prabhupada and how to spread Krishna Consciousness all over the world. Your entire life is an example of sincerity, devotion, and service. Gurumaharaj, I have made a humble effort to write a poem for you. I am not a poet, but I felt inspired to write for you. Please forgive me as my poem may sound childish. Kindly accept it as an insignificant offering at your lotus feet.
 
 ‘An ode to divine’
 
 My dear spiritual master, o magnanimous ocean of mercy,
 Inconceivable for me to write your eminence, as I feel unworthy.
 
 Pen in hand and a humble prayer in my heart,
 May the ink flow by Lord’s will, as he does the best art.
 
 Hitchhiking from the west to the east, your divine pastimes unfold,
 All through teaching lessons, my mind’s eyes behold.
 
 Young Richie wandered, in search of truth,
 Seeking meaningful shelter, for soul to soothe.
 Quest through countries, teachers, and faiths,
 Absorbing jewels of wisdom, as humble swathe.
 Sincere prayers and an ode to divine,
 United with Prabhupada, paths intertwined.
 Wandering sadhu was called on to the stage,
 “You can touch my feet,” swamiji’s kind grace.
 “This is my master, I am here to stay,”
 Heart echoed sincerely, a rhythmic sway.
 Punch holes in magazines, service by Giriraj brahmachari,
 First ever halwa explosion, plate full of sweets and savory.
 
 Richard transformed into Radhanath Das,
 Sincerely chanting maha mantra,
 Milking, sandesh, cooking, and worship,
 Loving Service to Radha Vrindavan candra.
 
 At the lotus feet of Radha Gopinath,
 Miracles uncover,
 You raised and inspired an army of
 Exemplary warriors.
 
 Each of them formidable, empowered by your grace,
 Gopinath, Govinda, Gauranga, Baladev,
 
 Satyavati, Jahnavi, Shyamananda, Radheshyam,
 Illustrious sadhu names, like Visnu sahasranaam.
 
 Thoughtfully and kindly, penned journey home,
 Millions finding path to Krishna,
 Radhanath Swami’s devotional epitome.
 
 In dark hours of looming despair,
 Your example shines lightning bright,
 In tardy moments of lingering doubts,
 Your resolve evokes an eagle’s flight.
 
 I pray not to dwell on the negative and hard,
 And recollect the mercy I am showered upon.
 I pray not to dwell on the external and scarred,
 And count the blessings in your divine form.
 
 Let lament and fear be taken over by glee,
 In your divine presence, anarthas surely flee.
 
 Relentlessly you taught timeless wisdom,
 Beyond actions, Krishna sees heart’s intention.
 Victory is in conquering the self within,
 Pleasure buried deep inside, not in the things.
 Only to love and be loved brings satisfaction,
 Gratitude makes hardships a meaningful traction.
 Selfless service, kind concern for others,
 Dive deeper for Krishna, what truly matters.
 
 Heartfelt prayers for you, my father,
 Live healthy, live long,
 Spreading the message of Chaitanya,
 Up to the moon and beyond.
 
 A small flower, kindly accept,
 And forgive me, my childlike blabber.
 Only prayer at your lotus feet,
 Let me always be safe in your service and your shelter.
 
 With Grateful heart,
 Your insignificant daughter,
 Kamesvari Devi Dasi

Dear Gurudeva,
 
 All glories to Śrīla Prabhupāda.
 
 Today, the world rejoices. Or perhaps it only feels so to those who have experienced the shelter of your presence. As the sacred mark of your seventy-fifth year shines upon us, my heart does not leap with pride. Instead, it bows lower. I feel the quiet weight of my unworthiness and the immeasurable grace you have showered upon us.
 
 I remember that day like it was yesterday. Wednesday, the second of September 1992. It was a stormy monsoon evening in Bombay. Black clouds rumbled overhead. They threatened to burst at any moment, yet not a single drop had fallen all day. A thirteen-year-old schoolboy, young and bewildered, had wandered into the Rādhā Gopīnātha temple hall. Was it accident or fate? I cannot say.
 
 Lightning split the sky. A small crowd of perhaps a dozen guests had gathered in the temple room. The curtains were about to open for the evening ārati. You sifted through the crowd and walked straight towards the boy. Taking his hands in yours, you asked gently, as if enquiring on behalf of some divine power itself: "Are you here to stay?"
 
 He did not know what 'stay' truly meant. To stay with saints. To stay with a path. To stay with the calling of one's own soul. Yet he answered, "Yes, I will stay."
 
 As soon as he spoke these words, you smiled, showered him with a few more graceful words, and folded your hands. At that very moment, thunder rolled across the sky. The clouds, as if holding on till that sacred exchange, parted and poured torrential rains. Just as clouds give way and causelessly shower their mercy in the form of life-giving water, you showered the mercy of Lord Caitanya upon me, a soul bereft of it for many lifetimes.
 Now, more than three decades later, here I am. Still staying.
 
 As I reflect, I see that I did not stay out of strength. I clung. I leeched on. Still clumsy. Still learning how to be a gentleman, how to be a servant, how to be grateful. If I am still here, if any fragment of sincerity has survived the storms of my mind, it is only because your words carried a potency beyond sound. It is in your sound form that you are constantly with us.
 In your physical presence, you are like the sun. When you are out of sight, some cry that the sun has set. They no longer feel its warmth directly upon them. But the sun never sets. It simply shines elsewhere, nurturing another horizon. As you travel the globe, giving your physical presence to everyone, you are not always visible. Yet you are never absent in sound.
 In the year 2000, you offered me a few instructions for life. I truly cherish them, meditating on them daily. I foolishly thought those were ‘the instructions’. With time, I learned otherwise. Every glance held guidance. Every silence spoke. Even moments where no word passed between us carried more teaching than I had space to store.
 
 Being in your presence is illuminating. Forgetting your words is error. Remembering you is embracing grace.
 
 Gurudeva, I cannot claim understanding. Nor progress. Nor qualification. But if a student's worth is measured not by brilliance but by longing, then perhaps one day even my hesitant heart may learn to walk rather than cling.
 
 Until then, let me remain dust beneath the feet of those who follow you with clarity. Whilst I stumble and crawl behind them. Not out of despair, but out of stubborn hope.
 May your compassion remain the compass. May your words remain the oar. May this unrefined soul continue, somehow, to remain near your light.
 
 On this sacred day, I offer no achievement. Only gratitude. And a desire to be shaped by your grace, even if I take a lifetime to become worthy of it.
 
 Your insignificant servant,
 Kartik Candra dāsa

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Maharaj, as time is passing in KC, I am gradually coming to understand and realize your role and contribution as the most rare and valuable fortune I could ever receive. Although physically distant, I feel your deep concern and love for me through your words, devotees, and your example.
 
 Maharaj, the most beautiful aspect is your love for Srila Prabhupada. I am amazed that every action of yours is in complete absorption of Srila Prabhupada's pleasure. Every seva initiated and manifested by you, be it Bhaktivedanta Hospital, Govardhan Ecovillage, yatras, or Western preaching, is with the deep desire to love and please Prabhupada. Maharaj, your love for Prabhupada manifests as your deep respect, appreciation, and gratitude for other Prabhupada disciples. Years back, on Prabhupada's disappearance day, when your Godsister was giving her offering for Prabhupada and time went beyond 7:20 pm, you considered allowing her to continue glorifying Prabhupada as greater seva than singing *Je anilo* at 7:20 pm! Your offering of gratitude to Gopal Krishna Goswami Maharaj through book distribution, keeping your head at the lotus feet of your Godbrothers, keeping their instructions as the topmost priority, and always emphasizing cooperation shows how deeply you love Srila Prabhupada. You are the best gift of Srila Prabhupada in my life. Please bless me with genuine appreciation and love for Srila Prabhupada, for you, Prabhupada's disciples, and for devotees all around me. In one lecture, you answered that for us, along with appreciation for Prabhupada's disciples, it is so important to increase our appreciation for the love and service offered by each devotee around us.
 
 Your emphasis on devotee care is so deeply evident in yatra, projects, and devotees taking your instructions to their hearts. "Part of devotee care is to allow devotees whom you care for to serve you" is so deep and profound, Maharaj. Mukhwas seva in yatra, encouraging matajis to cook chapattis, and appreciating devotees cooking on chulhas for Govardhan brings out that what you truly appreciate and value are devotees and their coming closer to Krishna. Maharaj, one statement by you hit me so hard: when our legs were jammed, sitting in one position from Mangala arati till class, the first statement you said was, "The association where devotees are coming together to call out to and hear about Krishna is the rarest! What you are getting now, please understand, is the rarest thing even demigods are desiring for!" Maharaj, please bless this wretched soul with the understanding and appreciation of devotees in my life. Please bless me with the intelligence to be able to respect everyone properly and serve accordingly.
 
 Maharaj, the most beautiful and rarest thing you are offering us is your absorption in Krishna. By your mercy, this was my first yatra, and we all could feel your deep, ecstatic love for Krishna in your kirtans and kathas. Time really became conspicuous by its absence as you went on glorifying Govardhan. In your calling out to Krishna, you gave us an indescribable experience of Krishna and the spiritual world, Guru Maharaj. When you mentioned chanting as if this is your last moment on your deathbed, between you and Krishna, in the association of devotees, for those few moments, a conditioned soul like me could call out to Krishna with deep emotion and intention. Maharaj, please bless me with the understanding that what you are offering us in the form of love for Krishna is the rarest, and let me never leave this for the petty allurements of maya. Please give me strength to choose Krishna, and if I shake, please hold me, Guru Maharaj. I am very weak and helplessly being dragged by maya again and again.
 
 Maharaj, you are most accessible in my life through your lectures and devotees. Your lectures are deeply personal; I feel your genuine love and deep concern for me in your lectures. The best part is when, through your lectures, you make us realize and feel the situation of the characters, be it Prahlada, mother Kunti, Vrtrasura, or Gajendra. Hearing from you, I am able to increase my appreciation for the surrender of various characters in their circumstances. Maharaj, your lectures are my lifeline. Please help me realize and understand that your lectures are your personal association for me, and the more I imbibe and follow your vani in my life, the more intimate connection I can develop with you and please you. Maharaj, you are offering your love in the form of beautiful devotees in my life: mature seniors, intimate friends, enthusiastic juniors, and loving parents. Please bless me with obedience to seniors, intimacy and non-envy among friends, and genuine selflessness and compassion for juniors.
 
 Maharaj, I feel deeply amazed by your appreciation and gratitude for every person who is even slightly willing to appreciate and accept the gift of bhakti in their lives. You are a touchstone; everyone you come in contact with is touched with Krishna's love. Through your small gestures and dealings, you are offering us access to Krishna. Please bless me, Guru Maharaj, to become a transparent via medium of the mercy of Guru parampara and share this rarest gift of bhakti with each and every person I come in contact with.
 
 Guru Maharaj, as time is passing and the defensive nature of my false ego, envy, jnani, and yogic contaminations—anarthas—are getting revealed, I feel helplessly dragged by them. I lack words to express gratitude to you for offering me the best gift. Please help me realize its value and strive to maintain and preserve this.  I have poor writing skills and limited knowledge, but I still wish to glorify you with this offering, in the hope that remembering you at every second while writing will make me pure.
 I have heard from many ISKCON lecturers that there is no difference between Krishna and Guru. Previously, when I was very new to ISKCON—which I still consider myself to be—I wouldn’t fully believe this. However, the day I heard about you for the very first time, through H.G. Amogh Lila Prabhu, I have believed the same.
 
 The very first time I saw you was on September 29, 2024, in Surat, Gujarat. It has always been my habit whenever a sannyasi comes to our temple, I would ask myself if he could be my Guru Maharaj. That day, when I first saw you, I asked myself the same question, and my heart did not immediately respond.
 
 However, December 7, 2024, became a special day. Unaware that it was the Vyasa Puja of my Guru Maharaj, I was casually listening to the glorification of a Prabhupada disciple. I heard a lecture from H.G. Amogh Lila Prabhu in which he was glorifying Guru Maharaj. That day will always remain special to me, especially hearing about your struggles to reach India.
 You are like a huge ocean, and I am a drop of water coming from far away just to mix with you. Just like the ocean, you have qualities I cannot describe in a single day. Your humbleness towards everyone keeps me motivated in my daily sadhana. Your watery eyes just like Prabhupada's show compassion towards everyone, and your welcoming smile makes the devotees' hearts melt. The way you join your hands and greet every single devotee will always be in my core memory, and the way you sit so steadily, just like what Prabhupada said in his lectures about sitting straight, is truly inspiring.
 
 I have accepted you as my father, mother, my Guru, and my master, and I am your insignificant servant. Whenever I see you, I wish I could touch your lotus feet, and I cry my heart out, knowing only you would listen.
 I am learning to be compassionate and humble from you.
 Sometimes I feel that you have descended to this material world just to free me from its grip and take me back with you, Srila Prabhupada, and Krishna.
 
 On the day of your Vyasa Puja, I have nothing material to offer you. I can only promise that I will always be loyal to ISKCON and our beloved Prabhupada. I am eagerly waiting for the day when you will give diksha to me and bestow upon me my new name. Guru Maharaj, I am very far away from you, but please bless me so that I can see you in my heart every minute, every second. I am eagerly looking forward to your upcoming Vyas Puja so I can have your darshan again. I have a wish to meet you personally, but most importantly, I want to hear your lectures very carefully and accept every word as it is in my life.
 
 Happy 75th Vyasa Puja, Guru Maharaj.
 I will miss you every day until December 7, 2025.
 
 Your Servant,
 Komal

Dear Gurudev,

Please accept my obeisances unto your Lotus Feet.
All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

Nowadays I’m aligning myself to follow your teachings with more emphasis on Vaani than Vaapu. Once Govind Prabhu said Guru Maharaj is someone for whom you don’t have to die for or give your life for. He meant that he is not a leader of a mission where you have to give up your life. He is a teacher. This understanding took me time and now I have realized that I need to understand your message and follow that. Your emphasis on cooperation and how Krishna consciousness is NOT a game of numbers is coming to my limelight. I want to please you and Krishna.

From a cooperation front, it’s not only with devotees and the temple, but also with family members and relatives. It’s definitely a challenge, but I want to exercise with your blessings and mercy.

Mahavishnu Maharaj was sitting in a corner in a temple in London and reading Srimad Bhagavatam. He was unnoticed. Simply absorbed. Not wanting any recognition. He was simply relishing Srimad Bhagavatam.

Following that, Gurudev, I’m seeking your blessings to simply be absorbed in Krishna, not seeking any recognition of any kind, and only to improve my love for Krishna.
I’m trying to follow your teaching of not judging anyone. Behind each person, there may be a story of abuses, bruises, difficulties which only Krishna knows as the personalized localized super soul. Gurudev, I love you and want to love you more and more.
I want to hear more and more of your teachings and be a good student.
I’m grateful for the association extended to us in Mumbai. With the nuclear family model, it’s working out well for our emotional support. We have highly mature counselors who truly care for us to please you and Krishna.

Bless me to get more opportunity and mindset to spend more and more time to the point of whole day and night where I can be absorbed in Krishna. Content, intent, and result to all be aligned to please you and Krishna. I need your blessings for the same. Also, I request you to initiate my daughter Rasika Ranganathan, who is a Gopal's Garden student, and bless my son Jaydev Ranganathan, who is in 3rd standard in Gopal’s Garden, to lead a responsible life with LOVE for Krishna. I also beg your blessings for the good health of my son Jaydev Ranganathan and my wife Ayodhyarani devi dasi. With all the good health, we should be able to serve you better and better.
With your prayers, we got Jaydev Ranganathan, our son, in BhaktiVedanta Hospital while serving there. We want him to be a devotee of Krishna.

Your Servant,
Kripa Sindhu Das

Hare Krishna. Dandavat Pranams, my beloved Gurudev.
I am deeply grateful to have you in my life. Truly, you are a divine gift to humanity, sent by the merciful hands of Sri Sri Radha-Gopinath. Gurudev, I cannot express in words how much love and gratitude I hold for you. You are an ocean of mercy, a storm of blessings, and the very embodiment of humility, compassion, and unconditional love.

Once, when Srila Ramanujacharya asked Kuresh to take darshan of Sri Ranganath Swami, Kuresh replied, “I have already taken darshan, for my Ranganath stands before me.” In the same spirit—not out of imitation or pride, but from my heart without duplicity—I can humbly say that you are my Radha-Gopinath. You are my only shelter, my hope, and my life.

Gurudev, I am burdened with countless anarthas, yet my deepest desire is to please you and surrender completely at your lotus feet. Just as you once told Srila Prabhupada, “My life is dedicated to you,” I too wish to dedicate this entire life to your service. Krishna has kindly given us a little freedom, but today I offer even that freedom to you. Everything I have is already yours; now I have nothing left to call my own.

I may not yet know Sri Sri Radha-Gopinath directly, but I know the path of Guru Parampara that leads to them. My only wish is to follow your footsteps and the footsteps of all our acharyas, until the day I attain Radha-Krishna prema.

Gurudev, I have committed many aparadhas, but I am not hopeless. I only beg for your mercy to purify me and help me become a true devotee. Your qualities are divine and beyond imitation, yet I pray for the strength to reflect even a drop of your compassion and humility in my character. You are a valiant soldier of His Divine Grace Srila Prabhupada, and every action of yours reminds the world of his instructions and his mission.

Please keep me always under the shade of your lotus feet. I hold tightly to them, for they are my only refuge. As the Vaishnava song says,

kṛṣṇa se tomāra, kṛṣṇa dite pāro,
tomāra śakati āche
āmi to' kāṅgala, 'kṛṣṇa' 'kṛṣṇa' boli',
dhāi tava pāche pāche :

“Krishna is yours. You have the power to give Him to me. I am simply running behind you, crying out, ‘Krishna! Krishna!’”

By seeing you, Gurudev, I receive hope, strength, and courage in my bhakti. Please let me become like you—without selfish desires, independent motives, or pride. If you examine me, you will find no qualities, only faults. My entire existence depends on your mercy. Without it, I cannot survive even a moment.

O Gurudev, I thirst for just one drop of your mercy. You know all my weaknesses—my lack of taste for japa, my absence of seva-bhava, and my deficiency of love for Sri Sri Radha-Gopinath. But one thing I possess gives me hope—my unbroken faith in you. I know that by sincerely surrendering to you and striving my best, one day I will attain everything.

I promise to try my utmost to chant my sixteen rounds with full attention, to serve consciously, to remember you and Radha-Gopinath in all my actions, and to remain sensitive and harmonious with all Vaishnavas. I will do my best to please my authorities, avoid prajalpa, and stay away from anything that may displease you or hinder my bhakti.

Whatever offenses I have committed in the past, I beg for your forgiveness at your lotus feet. Please accept me, Gurudev. Without you, I have no one. I offer you all my love, awe, and reverence. Kindly give me shelter under your lotus feet forever.

Please never leave me.

Your insignificant servant,
Krish Jain

O ocean of grace, with heart so pure,
You walk this world with love so sure.
Seventy-five years, yet youth divine,
Shines through your eyes that always shine.

You showed us how a soul can roam,
And still be steadfast—Journey Home.
Through forest paths and crowded streets,
Your heart stayed fixed at Krishna’s feet.

Your words ignite the sleeping soul,
Each tale of Krishna makes us whole.
For hours you speak—Hari Katha streams,
Awakening hearts from worldly dreams.

Your life’s a lesson, calm yet strong,
In truth and faith where we belong.
Your sadhana—so deep, so vast,
Each breath reminds us, “Hold fast, hold fast.”

So humble still, though all revere,
You serve the Lord, with heart sincere.
Each detail watched, each task refined,
You mirror Krishna’s perfect mind.

O Maharaja! Pillar of grace,
May Krishna keep you in His embrace.
Grant us strength to follow your way,
To serve with love, both night and day.

As we bow at your lotus feet,
Our hearts resound with joy complete.
For one who lives to make us see,

Dearest Gurudev,
 
 Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 As I sit to write my Vyasa Puja Offering to you, my mind goes back to the late evening in 2002 when some of us were with you at Udupi at the residence of Dayal Chandra Prabhu, and we had come to your room to see you sitting before your laptop, to see you and your laptop fully covered by thousands of small insects of all types and shapes, and you were typing something fully engrossed. Looking at our enquiring faces, you responded, "I am finishing my Vyasa Puja offering to Srila Prabhupada, and today is the last day for submission." I was thinking, "Oh my Lord! Maharaja is so much engrossed in his writing of his Vyasa Puja offering to his spiritual master that he is completely oblivious to the thousands of insects literally covering his face and his head, and maybe even biting him." I was completely overwhelmed by your absorption, and the same thing I observed during the daily lectures at Govardhan during the Kartik Yatra. Your shawl was literally covered with hundreds of insects, and there must have been much more buzzing around you, but you were completely oblivious to them as you were diving deep into the nectar of the holy names during Kirtan and pastimes of Lord Caitanya Mahaprabhu during your classes. I pray at your lotus feet, Gurudev, please shower me with a drop of this absorption in the holy names and the pastimes of the Lord.
 
 It was at the same residence of Dayal Chandra Prabhu that one morning when we came to your room, we could see that you had barely slept the whole night, and as soon as we settled into your room, you said, "Have I come to Udupi to die? I was kept awake the whole night because of the dogs barking. This is so very disturbing. Let us go back to Bombay immediately." We all panicked, and then we told you that we had alternative accommodation a few kilometers away which you should please try for a couple of days and then decide. Fortunately, that house was much more peaceful, and you settled down to a couple of weeks of rest and peace.
 
 We are extremely grateful to you, Gurudev, for all that you are giving us: all the love and affection, the devotee association, the ever-increasing bliss of participating in yatras with all the devotees, and of course, the home that you had made for us at Govardhan Eco Village. I was struck by your two words, "Welcome Home," during the opening of Govardhan Kunj, after which you gave us a very elaborate purport and then once again concluded with the words, "Welcome Home." Of course, this was not the first time we had heard these two words. You have repeated to us these two words again and again over the last twelve years since you got involved with the development of Govardhan Eco Village to drive home the point that this is your home, and it is yours for your taking. What a great fortune you have created for us!!!! This project is touching the hearts of each and everyone who comes here and creating lasting memories in their lives.
 
 Once you made Govardhan Eco Village the oasis that it is to the worldwide congregation of ISKCON devotees, you turned your mind to Radha Gopinath Temple once again, and I remember the conversation that we had on Janmashtami day of 2024 when a few of us were sitting with you in the courtyard. You were relaxed and peaceful, and in a very casual way, you remarked, "Radha Gopinath temple is the parent of all the temples that have emerged through the efforts of the brahmacaris and congregation so very naturally, you did not include yourself in this, and how can we have it any less beautiful than any of the other temples? The kitchen is so shabby, and it needs to be completely refurbished, and so do Bhaktivedanta Hall and Bhakti Siddhanta Hall. It would be so wonderful if we had stone cladding in building numbers 1 and 2 so that we can have a proper synergy between the temple building and the two buildings by its side." You told us how you would like the Laxmi Narayan Courtyard to be renovated, and it was on this day of Janmashtami that you said that the Laxmi Narayan Deities should be named as Sri Sri Radha Paitha Bihari, and with a hearty laugh, gave us the purport with the pastime of Lord Vishnu having his two extra hands disappear due to the love of Shrimati Radharani at Paitha.
 
 We are seeing so many miracles taking place on the eve of your 75th appearance. Flats in Radha Gopinath Mandir where we have been having court cases going on for years with no end in sight were miraculously getting settled out of court with the tenants themselves coming forward with reasonable requests for settlement, and many, many more which I am not able to spell out here. On this most joyous occasion of the 75th appearance of Your Divine Grace, I pray at the lotus feet of Srila Prabhupada, our parampara, and Sri Radha Gopinathji to give you a long and wonderful life ahead in the service of your loving Spiritual Master, Srila A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada, and continue to be a beacon of hope in this miserable material world to thousands of more Vaishnavas to bring them to the lotus feet of Shrimati Radharani.
 
 Your servant,
 
 Krishna Naam das

Dearest Gurudev,

Please accept my most humble obeisances at your divine lotus feet. All glories to you, and all glories to Srila Prabhupada.
On this sacred occasion of your 75th Vyas Puja, my heart overflows with gratitude and remembrance. I am reflecting on those golden days of my childhood at the Matunga program, when you would shower everyone with your warm, affectionate hugs. Those moments were filled with a sweetness and purity that words can hardly capture.
I still remember how lovingly you would tap or punch my forehead. It always felt like a “reset button” that instantly cleared all my worries. And when you would wrap me in your saffron shawl, though nothing else was visible, it felt as if I was completely protected, sheltered under your love and care.
As children, we didn’t realize the immense fortune we had of being in your presence, receiving your blessings. We were too absorbed in our little games of cricket, not recognizing that the greatest treasure of our lives was right before us. Now, as I look back, I realize how precious those moments were, a golden opportunity that I did not value enough then.
I also feel deeply grateful for the mercy you have showered upon my parents and sister. Whatever little spiritual inclination and values I have today are only because of the association and guidance you have so kindly given to them. You have not only transformed their hearts but also given our entire family a purpose and direction centered around Krishna. The care and compassion you have shown to them over the years is something I can never repay.
Over the years, so many things have changed in ways I could have never imagined. This year’s Kartik Yatra I attended after 11 long years, which felt like a forgotten blessing returning to life. There was a time when I couldn’t even think of missing a single Yatra, and would attend all Sunday programs in a year at the temple, and now, even to attend one in a year feels like a rare and precious gift.
Today, I feel deeply unfortunate to be living away from your heart, Sri Sri Radha Gopinathji, and to be deprived of your direct mercy. Yet, as you have taught us, I continue to have faith that somehow, by following your instructions, I may be of some use in Srila Prabhupada’s divine mission. Your teachings, your example, and your compassion constantly inspire me to stay steady on the spiritual path and not to deviate, no matter how challenging life becomes.
I am also very grateful for the kindness and inspiration you have shown to my wife, Kirti Sundari Devi Dasi, and our daughter, Vrindapriya. Whatever little harmony and spiritual strength we have in our family is purely by your grace. You have given us the understanding that family life can also be centered around devotion, service, and gratitude. I pray that our home may always remain connected to your lotus feet and that we may serve your mission together with sincerity and humility.
We hanker for your darshan like the chataka bird hankers for the pure raindrops from the sky, with the same intense longing and hope. On this auspicious day, I sincerely pray to Sri Sri Radha Gopinathji to bless you with strong health, vitality, and endless strength to continue spreading the divine message of Lord Krishna, Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu and Srila Prabhupada to the world.
And, Gurudev, I have one small, childlike prayer: please, at least once a year, bless me with one of your loving hugs. That single embrace has the power to dissolve all my suffering and remind me that I am forever under your shelter.

Awaiting for the drop of your mercy and that loving hug,

Your eternal servants,
Kumar Sundar Das, Kirti Sundari Devi Dasi, & Vrindapriya

Hare Krishna, dear Maharaj. Please accept my most humble obeisances.
 All glories to Srila Prabhupada. All glories to your divine service.
 
 On the auspicious occasion of your divine appearance day, I am trying to offer a few words from my insignificant heart.
 
 For me, you are truly one of the great pioneers of Srila Prabhupada’s Hare Krishna movement in this world. Through your tireless efforts, compassion, and unwavering faith, you have carried Srila Prabhupada’s message to countless hearts. I feel immensely grateful and fortunate to accept you as my śikṣā-guru and to look up to you as my guardian and guide in spiritual life.
 
 After my beloved spiritual master, His Holiness Gopal Krishna Goswami Maharaj, departed from this world last year, I was feeling completely lost and orphaned. But just before leaving, Gurudev instructed us to take shelter of a senior Vaiṣṇava in our movement. Following that instruction, the only person my heart naturally turned towards was Your Holiness. Somehow, by your causeless mercy, I have always felt a deep connection with you for many years through your lectures and Hari-kathā, and that connection has only grown stronger since Gurudev’s departure.
 
 By Srila Prabhupada’s and Guru Maharaj’s mercy, I had the great fortune of receiving your darśan twice—once last year and once again at the beginning of this year. You were so merciful, Maharaj: you not only gave your darśan but also spoke a few kind words to me. In those moments, I strongly felt in my heart that my Guru Maharaj wanted me to take shelter of you, his dear Godbrother. I feel very, very blessed to be somehow associated with Your Holiness.
 
 I am endlessly grateful that we have an unlimited treasure of your lectures, kirtans, and recordings available to us. Because of this, I can daily increase my śravaṇam and hear Hari-kathā from you, even without being in your physical presence. Your Vāṇī gives me strength and guidance at every step and allows me to feel your association wherever I am.
 
 Maharaj, you have completely transformed my heart and vision. Earlier, although I was practicing Krishna consciousness externally, internally I was in darkness. I was very judgmental and critical, always searching for faults in devotees and proudly thinking that I alone was following the standards properly. But by observing your profound humility, your genuine respect for every devotee, and your deep compassion, over time I began to realize how wrong I was.
 
 I especially remember one pastime narrated by HG Gaurang Prabhu: when some brahmacārīs came to you and complained about their fellow brahmacārīs not practicing properly, you did not encourage their fault-finding mentality. Instead, you began to speak about the good qualities of those devotees. You taught them to see the positive side of others, to take what is good, and to learn from that, rather than criticizing and trying to bring others down.
 
 Through such examples, you are teaching all of us how to truly live the mood of tṛṇād api sunīcena and amāninā mānadena. If there is anyone in this movement from whom I wish to learn real humility, genuine respect for others, and the art of not finding faults in devotees, it is you, Śrīla Radhanath Swami Maharaj. For this, I am forever indebted and grateful to you, Gurudev.
 
 From the core of my heart, I offer my repeated thanks to you, dear Maharaj. I address you as Guru Maharaj because, in terms of tattva, guru is one, and I feel such deep connection, guidance, and shelter coming from you. I feel that my Guru Maharaj, His Holiness Gopal Krishna Goswami Maharaj, continues to live in his Vāṇī and also through you—his dear most Godbrother who always had so much love, honor, and respect for him. When I see you, I am reminded of him, and I feel that in serving your instructions, I am also serving his desire.
 
 On this sacred day of your appearance, I offer my heartfelt prayers at the lotus feet of
 Śrī Śrī Rādhā-Śyāmasundar,
 Śrī Śrī Kṛṣṇa-Balarām,
 Śrī Śrī Gaura-Nitāi,
 Lord Nṛsiṁhadeva,
 and at the lotus feet of Śrīla Prabhupāda,
 that They kindly keep you healthy, strong, and protected, so that we may have your association and guidance for many more years to come. Your presence in this world is a great hope for fallen souls like me.
 
 I also humbly pray at your lotus feet, Maharaj, that you kindly bestow your mercy upon my younger sister and accept her as your disciple. The only aim of my life is that she may find complete shelter at your lotus feet and be delivered by your causeless mercy. If you accept her, I will consider my life successful.

Dear Gurudev,
 Please accept my humble obeisances.
 All glories to Sri Guru and Sri Gauranga.
 
 Sometimes I don’t realize what great fortune I have received by getting shelter at your lotus feet. I have understood that I may never get the opportunity to meet you in person, but whenever I hear from other devotees describing your wonderful pastimes in this material world, I am immediately reminded of the great fortune I have received.
 You have saved me from falling into maya many times. As soon as you had accepted me as your disciple, I could get transferred to Kolkata where I am able to do my part in fulfilling your dream by assisting in establishing a temple in the Newtown area. Due to your mercy only, we can serve in the birthplace of Srila Prabhupada and become instruments in your hands to assist you in your service to your Guru Maharaj.

I can only imagine the pain your body went through while carrying out that seemingly impossible service. I can never think of myself being in such a situation. So, I pray that you can bless me to have the same obedience to my superiors as you had.

 Everywhere His presence.

And then I realize — mercy never checks qualifications. It simply flows… just like your compassion that has touched millions of hearts.

⸻

When you smile, hope awakens in the darkest hearts.
And when you cry while speaking about Krishna or the devotees — we all cry, because we feel what love truly means.

Your tears are our teacher.
Your laughter is our lesson in lightness.
Your silence is our reminder that God lives in the heart.

⸻

I have seen you carry mountains of responsibility with the softness of a flower.
You have turned pain into prayer, and suffering into service.
You’ve shown us that devotion is not about escaping the world — it’s about transforming it with love.

How can I ever repay a father who gave me my real identity?
How can I thank a Guru who pulled me out from the whirlpool of illusion and placed me on the path of bhakti?

All I can offer, Maharaj, is this small, trembling heart —
imperfect, inconsistent, but yours.

⸻

not only as my Guru,
but as the embodiment of love in action,
the living expression of Lord Chaitanya’s mercy.

Please keep me near your lotus feet,
always learning, always serving,
always remembering that the greatest gift in all universes
is simply to be yours.

With tears, laughter, and infinite gratitude,
Your insignificant servant,

Hare Krishna dear Guru Maharaj November 11th, 2025
 Please accept my deepest obeisances. All glories to our most beloved Srila Prabhupada!
 
 Not a day goes by that I do not think of you or dream of you. I was still fortunate enough to meet you in person this year in Villa Vrindavana. Oh, what a joy it is to be in your *vapuh* association and the association of all my god-brothers and sisters. The heart jumps in joy to be able to sit directly at your feet and listen to your exposition of Krishna *katha*. It’s an extra perk and privilege in my life to see you in person. I have also just finished watching your Govardhana Kartik Yatra. I felt so deeply in your presence, as if I was one of those 12 thousand devotees there. Often when you spoke, tears would come to my eyes to see the magnitude of your preaching and the impact it has on us all. And here we are trying to canvas you to come to visit us in Radhadesh with only 120 devotees. Are we out of line, I wonder?
 
 Even though your *vapuh* association is so precious to me, I don't feel separated from you, as I carry you in my heart throughout the day. We have recently finished studying the 3rd Canto of Srimad-Bhagavatam in our Bhakti-vaibhava study group here in Radhadesh. There, in the verse 3.25.21, Kapila Muni explains the characteristics of a *sadhu* to his mother Devahuti. The line *suhṛdaḥ sarva-dehinām* caught my attention, and I went on a small journey of discovery, diving deep into this topic, which I then developed into a small presentation for my fellow study-buddies. I learned that there are different levels of friendships, and they are represented by different Sanskrit terms: from *bandhu*, *mitra/sakha*, *priya-sakha*, all the way to *suhṛt*. *Suhṛt* is one in a million, a friend who never lets you down, who loves you unconditionally, who is there with you no matter what, who always makes time for you, and who never judges you. He walks with you till you reach your goal. This friendship is so deep that many times words do not need to be expressed for the other to understand. It’s such a rare bond, which is hard to achieve, and not every person may be fortunate to get a friend of this level throughout their life. *Suhṛt* is your best well-wisher. The conclusion of this presentation was that I feel extremely fortunate. Meeting devotees has opened the door for me to finally meet my *suhrts*. To meet Krishna as my *suhrt*, to get Srila Prabhupada as a *suhrt*, having you as my unique *suhrt*, and to have my husband, Visnu Murti, as my *suhrt*. These are four principal persons in my life who want to see me succeed on this journey of life and death.
 
 This deeper study of just this one line of Srimad-Bhagavatam has been very revealing for me; it left a profound impression on my heart, and it certainly brought a deeper understanding of who a *sadhu* is, and how Srila Prabhupada has pushed himself into our lives to take us out of this world of *kunta*. This is who a *sadhu* is: the best well-wishing friend of all. You are this *suhrt* to me, Guru Maharaj. So close to my heart that I don't feel separated from you.
 
 I bow down to you with utter gratitude and pray for the qualities and abilities for being able to assist you and serve you in your service to Srila Prabhupada’s mission, that you can be proud of.
 Your aspiring servant
 Laksmipriya dd

Lalitha Priya was attending Mangal Aarti daily from mid-1994 and would leave after Tulsi Aarti. At home, my father was perturbed seeing our growing involvement in the temple activities. He said, "I am not against God or religion, but against the institutionalization of religion. 10 or 20 minutes is all it takes to pray; the rest of the time should be for children and business." Of course, we were not neglecting our duties, but our engagement in the temple activities was steadily rising.

Like we see in movies, when everything was just fine according to us, he felt we were going overboard. He ordered us to go and stay at a spare flat we had at Dahisar, almost 50 kilometers away. Our concern was the children's schooling. We were in a fix. Our counselor, HG Adikeshav Prabhu, brought us to you and said, "They have become dear to Krishna." I was puzzled. He explained the situation to you.

You just thought it over for a minute and said, "You go by your father's instruction. It will be better for your spiritual life." It was a tough choice. Your guidance gave us strength, and we went ahead. Daily, we brought our children to school and attended the temple too. We also had a few satsang programs in our house at Dahisar.

By the year, we were called back home. Parents' health started failing. Later, we had an astrological consultation and were told that in that period, father and son would not be able to stay under the same roof. So, Maharaj, you guided us perfectly and protected our spiritual life.

We are ever indebted to you not just for this but also for taking our son Radheshlal under your personal care and being a pillar of strength to our daughter Radha Preeti in her period of challenge.

You have given us a home beyond dreams in the family of your devotees.

To The Lotus Feet of,
HH Radhanath Swami Maharaj.

Blessed is that rock upon which you meditated.
The sacred vibrations of the Maha Mantra penetrated your soul as the waves of the Ganga cascaded.
You embarked on such a remarkable journey all those years ago.
For us, you left your dear family who loved you so.

“Go to India,” the voice instructed in the cave of Crete.

However, certain individuals could not check their inherent propensities of deceit.

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my humble obeisance at your lotus feet.
 All glories to you, all glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 The vyasapuja offering means glorification of the spiritual master. Actually, the disciple's only strength is contemplating the glories of a spiritual master. That is the only saving grace for the disciple. Otherwise, he has to glorify Maya. The disciple receives mercy from the spiritual master through his instructions and conducts his life by that instruction, then he will get realization. So, the vyasapuja day is an opportunity to share that realization with the spiritual master, so that the spiritual master will be pleased. When the spiritual master is pleased, then the disciple's spiritual life will be successful. Yasya prasadat bhagavat prasado, yasya prasada na gati ki topi.
 
 Guru Maharaj, the more I am hearing from different sources, the more I am able to understand the importance of the association of sadhus. Without hearing from a sadhu, one cannot understand the glories of devotional service. That is why the Vedas are called Shruti. The purpose of Vedic literature is to awaken the relationship with Krishna. But it should be understood by hearing from a pure devotee. Even though I am not able to get your physical association, through your different lectures like S.B. Classes or yatras or seminars, by your teachings, I am able to see and connect to Krishna through my life, or to this world. Without approaching the sadhu or hearing from him, human life is meaningless. Srila Prabhupada, in every purport, he mentioned that one should approach a bonafide spiritual master and hear from him and follow his instructions.
 
 Guru Maharaj, I am experiencing that unless one comes to the association of sadhus, his real spiritual life will not begin. One may be very austere, one may be very expert in Vedic literature, one may be very pious, still, one must approach a sadhu. In the present situation, people are not very austere, not very inquisitive, and not interested in reading scriptures, but they want to see role models in society. It means by seeing an exemplary person, one may become interested in spiritual life, then they will approach a sadhu. You are one of the exemplary sadhus to this world. Recently, in the Kartik yatra, devotees from all over the world came to Guriraj Govardhan just to take association from you and hear from you. All types of devotees are children, youth, old, and women. Just by seeing you, people think that here is a religious person; he brings us to a spiritual platform. Actually, your lifestyle and your speech are most important to this society. Just by seeing you and hearing from you, they will connect to God and they will be happy. The six days during the yatra, we completely forgot our household activities, our material life, and all our domestic activities. You made us absorbed hearing about the Lord, worshipping the Lord, taking darshan of the Lord, and engaging in the service of the Lord. We felt so happy. You showed us during this yatra how we can live our whole life in the association of devotees and at the same time how to live in this world. You said that the actual yatra begins after we leave, during this 6-day yatra. So, this is how I am understanding the importance of sadhus, Maharaj.
 
 Guru Maharaj, you left home from your childhood, you left your most loving parents, you left the worshipable land, and you met so many babas, saints, renouncers, and you met many monks, just to find a guru. To meet a genuine sadhu, you did so much austerity in your life. You walk towards a sadhu, but Krishna walks towards a sadhu like you. You reached the lotus feet of a pure devotee, that is Srila Prabhupada, and Srila Prabhupada gave you the holydham of Goloka Vrindavan. Guru Maharaj, you came to India to give the association of sadhus; Srila Prabhupada went to America to teach the value of saintly person association to people in general.
 
 Guru Maharaj, your heart is filled with the glories of Srila Prabhupada. Whatever you do, whatever you speak, and all your actions are representative of Srila Prabhupada. The success of a person in spiritual life is attached to sadhus. Acharya also says that to become a sadhu, one should associate with sadhus. To become a pure devotee, one should associate with pure devotees. It is always touching my heart that in all your lectures, there is a glorification of Srila Prabhupada. That is how you are feeling grateful and how you are blessed by Srila Prabhupada and all the Acharyas in the disciplic succession. In the same way, you are teaching me how I should be grateful in the association of your lotus feet and rendering some service to your lotus feet.
 
 Regularly hearing from you, I am able to experience the happiness that comes from pure devotional service. Krishna consciousness is such a blissful process one can experience in the beginning itself. In other processes, it is only fruitless labor. A person may follow different religions, one may be very austere, he may be a much-influenced person, he may be a very scholarly person, he may worship different demigods, but unless one comes to the association of a pure devotee, he will not be successful. In the association of a pure devotee, one can be protected by Maya, one can be happy, one can understand the relationship with Krishna, and one can develop love for Krishna. In the association of a pure devotee only, one can be free from sinful activity. I am very grateful to you, Maharaj; by your causeless mercy, today I am able to understand the glories of Srila Prabhupada.
 
 A true sadhu always exhibits all the qualities in all circumstances. From his point of view, there is no good or bad, pain & pleasures, heat and cold, and happiness & distress. Just by seeing you, one will develop all these qualities. Darshana Pavitra koro-ei tomara guna. Actually, a sadhu is living Bhagavata. Just by hearing from you, just by serving you, one will understand the book Bhagavata. A living bhagavata and book bhagavata will give only qualities and devotion. I am experiencing there is no difference between book bhagavata and person bhagavata. When I contemplate all your qualities, my heart moves to devotional service. Bhagavatam explains about the Mrigari hunter. Just by association with Narada Muni, he became such a wonderful saint. There are so many examples in the Srimad Bhagavatam. Guru Maharaj, you are like that; you are always giving challenges to become humble, but I am failing in that area. How many times have you told me, trnadapi sunechana taroriva sahisnuna, amanena manadena kirtaniya sadahari. When circumstances come in such a way, I am a victim of a false ego. As you said, the quality of a sadhu is always looking for descending mercy. That means one who is in love with his spiritual master, he can conquer anything. Sadhu means cutting the knots of the disciple. The more a disciple gives an opportunity to a sadhu by means of surrender, the more he will be free from sinful activity.
 
 Guru Maharaj, on this very auspicious occasion, I am deeply praying at your lotus feet; please give me your blessing to understand the qualities of your heart. Let me become more and more humble. Let me cooperate with everyone; this is Srila Prabhupada's desire, not to compare anyone, rather cooperate with everyone. And engage me in the service of Srila Prabhupada's mission and your lotus feet.
 
 Thank you so much, Guru Maharaja.
 
 Please forgive all my offenses at your lotus feet.
 Your insignificant aspiring servant,
 Lokeshwar Govinda dasa.
