Dear guru maharaja:
On this memorable day of your auspicious appearance, I'd like to express my great admiration for your tireless preaching, for your wonderful way to present KC, and for your great love you distribute on the journey through this world.
It has been over 20 years since I last saw you physically, and we exchanged a few words in regard to my commitment as your servant, and you very kindly gave me instructions about my responsibility as a member of the Mexican yatra, which is under the care of your dear godbrother, his holiness Guru Prasad Swami.
Although I have been a bit neglectful, I keep my connection with them through Zoom, and when I have the chance to visit the yatras, we try our best to engage in some way while we are there.
For the time being, we are residing in the city of Edmonton, Canada, in the wonderful association of the local Vaisnavas, and getting lots of inspiration from them.
The congregation is so eager to learn what Srila Prabhupada established. They are always inviting the devotees for home programs. On festival days, most of the congregation gets involved in some way or other in performing devotional service.
We can't really express the great joy we experience trying to follow your footsteps.
By seeing your tireless efforts in developing the wonderful congregations like Chowpatty under your care, the projects like the Bhaktivedanta Hospital, Govardhan Eco-Village, and many others, I get amazed in seeing your dedication, care, and guidance you spend on every member, making them feel included in their respective yatras.
In order to start my days, the first thing I do after paying obeisances to you, SP, and to our home Deities, is to hear a brief class from SP, from you, or your amazing godbrothers while I prepare the paraphernalia for such home worship.
It's just so nectarean to hear from great and advanced devotees like yourself about Krishna katha, that once you take SP’s books and read them, all that has been heard from you resonates clearly, making the contents of it total sense.
Now, after a break we had in performing temple devotional service, by the kind mercy of our wonderful temple president and the congregation of devotees here in Edmonton, we are making an attempt to please you, SP, and Their Lordships Sri Sri Radha-Govinda.
It’s very encouraging to see my dear wife eagerly serving in the pujari department, and my kids immersed in the different activities at the temple, dedicating their different talents to the service of the Lord. Please keep showering us with your kind mercy so we can keep up with the requirements to qualify as an
aspiring servant at your lotus feet.
Lord Krishna says in BG 18-66: sarva-dharmam parityajya, mam ekan saranam vraja, aham tvam sarva-papebhyo moksayisyami ma sucah.
The last sentence, ma sucah, "do not fear, don't worry," really resonates in the heart of the devotees. Lord Krishna is giving assurance so we can gain confidence that all we need to do is to surrender to Him through the parampara system, very well established and carefully guarded by our acharyas.
We pray to the Lord to bless you with health and long life, so we can get your mercy and purify our existence as far as possible to properly serve you and SP.
Your insignificant servant: Madhukantha das.

Dearest HH Radhanath Swami Maharaja,
 
 Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

Your ability to love and accept all beings is just as Radha and Krishna have hoped for us all. The ways in which you can hold space for each person who approaches you, changes people’s lives. The love of the Divine flows through you as a conduit of eternal embrace. The gentleness that you provide is the touch that souls need in this darkened world of chaos to soften and land in the safety and security of our Beloved Lord.
 
 Your essence is that in which trust is built, through love and acceptance. The foundation for a deeper surrender is continually provided through your glance, love, teaching, and living example. Ultimately, you have built a space within my heart that allows for me to move closer to the truth of who I am, as an eternal being, outside of the confines created in this lifetime. And it is through your shelter that I understand that there is always opportunity to listen and grow in such a way I can continually evolve on this path.
 
 When I reflect on this beautiful offering you provide for us all, I am reminded of the story you shared in a lecture at GEV the day after I aspired to take shelter with you. The story of the pigeon and the king. When you looked my way and shared just how much one would give for each and every one of God’s children that have been entrusted in one’s care. I offer my gratitude to you for helping me in my life and driving me closer to Krishna. I am very grateful to the wonderful **counseling** system and **for** growing such a community where we are feeling **sheltered**.

First time I have visited GEV this year and I can see how much you cherish Vrindavan. I ask some attachment to Vrindavan from you like the way you have it. By your mercy we got a chance to stay under Govardan hill; it was really like a dream of being in Goloka and experiencing Govardhan lila during the yatra this year.

Some of the points that touched my heart from your class in yatra this year are:

1. All the animals danced, giving up their past conditioning and cooperated. Not only that, but they went to the extreme of a tiger kissing a deer. Similarly, in **sankirtan**, we all should cooperate with each other. What are those **petty** small conditions in front of the power of **sankirtan**?

2. One pure chanting of Hare Krishna mantra is enough and is the same as the 9 processes of **devotional** service.

3. Indra thought the people of Vrindavan were very proud, but the world is a reflection of our own mind, and Indra was proud himself. We should not find fault in others.

4. Sanatan Goswami took service from Srimati Radharani, and devotees may have emotional, physical needs. We should not tell them to be transcendental like the Goswamis, but we love Krishna. Krishna loves everyone, everyone is Krishna's children, so we should love everyone.

5. Krishna is more pleased when we serve devotees than directly serving Him.

6. Be kind to everyone and, in a small or big way, share this love of Krishna consciousness to others. Take **shelter** of the holy name.

I personally felt, Maharaj, like a father sending his children on a difficult work for a long time with so much love and care. I felt you sent us back from the yatra with those loving words. It was very difficult to be separated from that experience. I felt very safe being with you.

I hope I continue to follow your instruction to take **shelter** of the holy name and be kind and share this with others in whatever way I can. By doing this, I feel I am always with you.

Thank you very, very much for everything, my Dear Guru Maharaj.

I have accepted you as my spiritual master, and I pray to the Lord Radha Shyam-Sundar for the day when you will accept me as your disciple.

Devotion teaches us something from every Vaishnava, but from you, I have learned selfless love for the Lord. You always speak about the welfare of humanity, and the true welfare, as you teach, is to bring every living being closer to Radha & Krishna. Your compassion for all living entities and your continued efforts for the welfare of society, even while facing ill health, are a great source of inspiration for every disciple.

You have taught that all living beings, no matter what body they inhabit, are parts and parcels of the Supreme Lord, and to harm them is to cause pain to the Lord Himself. This is the true mark of a pure Vaishnava. You have shown me the right path to live by, and I know that countless lives have been transformed through your guidance. You are very dear to Srila Prabhupada, and by receiving your mercy, we too can become dear to the great Acharyas.

Whenever I see you, I am reminded of the teaching of Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu — “तृणादपि सुनीचेन, तरोरिव सहिष्णुना, अमानिना मानदेना, कीर्तनियः सदा हरिः।”. Your example constantly inspires me to live by these words and to cultivate true humility, tolerance, and devotion in my life.

Guru Maharaj, I know that your daily life is filled with countless responsibilities, yet you still take out your precious time to shower mercy upon the devotees. If this is not your causeless mercy, then what else could it be?

I pray to Sri Sri Radha Parth-Sarathi that They bless you with good health and strength so that all of us, your aspiring followers, may continue to receive your association and develop pure love for the Supreme Lord Krishna.

Guru Maharaj, I offer this humble plea at your lotus feet. I was never qualified to perform bhakti, but by being attracted to you and through the association of devotees, I have somehow come to the path of devotion. Please bestow your mercy upon me so that I may also make this human life successful and attain the ultimate goal of life: "pure devotional love".

On this sacred day, I pray to the Guru Parampara and the Pancha Tattva for your good health, and I also pray to Lord Narsimha Deva to remove all obstacles in your life and bless you with strength and protection.

Your servant of the servants.

Manish Tiwari
East of Kailash
Sant Nagar, New Delhiè

Dear Guru Maharaj,
Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

Over the last couple of years, I have been listening to your lectures with more regularity and more eagerness than ever before. As part of my service to Sri Sri Radha-Kalachandji, I am now regularly scheduled to give Srimad-Bhagavatam class, and I feel deeply grateful to be able to repeat even a drop of what I have heard from you.

Some of the teachings that have settled deepest in my mind and heart this year include:

• Why Lord Chaitanya chose Ishvara Puri as His guru—because of Ishvara Puri’s unparalleled humility and his willingness to perform the most menial personal service for his own spiritual master. This teaches us that a spiritual master’s true qualification is not their learning or eloquence, but their loving service to their own guru. Your unwavering dedication to Srila Prabhupada—your life of service, sacrifice, and loyalty to his mission—constantly reminds me what real discipleship looks like.

• Gratitude requires humility—that we are only grateful for things we feel we do not deserve.

• Real advancement happens when we serve even when we don’t feel like it. When the mind wants to “do something else,” but we choose Krishna anyway, that is the moment we truly take a step forward on the bhakti path.

• Remember every good anyone has done for you, and forget the rest.

• If we want Krishna’s forgiveness, we must forgive others—be mindful of how many lifetimes of offenses we have committed before being given even the smallest spark of bhakti.

• Grihastha life as a partnership—that Krishna conscious marriage should not be something we merely tolerate due to vows, but something dynamic, alive, and centered on service to Krishna. When husband and wife help each other advance, their home becomes an ashrama, a place of purification.

One teaching in particular touched me very deeply. In a 1990 Q&A session in Mumbai, you told the story of your days in New Vrindavan—when you were getting only a few hours of sleep, working constantly, and had almost no time for reading. You described how you would rush your prasadam, then force yourself to read while walking quickly and reading aloud just to stay awake. Because you approached the Bhagavatam with such eagerness and sacrifice—tapasya—you learned more during those difficult days than at any other time. You taught that Krishna reciprocates not with our intellect or memory, but with our sacrifice, our earnestness, and our hunger to understand even one line of His message. That one story changed the way I approach my reading, my hearing, and even my attempts to teach.

Thank you, Maharaj. Your words continue to guide me, challenge me, and steady me. I pray to develop a fraction of your hunger to serve Srila Prabhupada and the Vaishnavas in this lifetime. I know that I am a fool, an imposter, and have no qualification to speak on the scriptures, but whatever little I am able to share in classes is only because of what I have received from you. Please bless me to always listen with eagerness, to practice with sincerity, and to serve Sri Sri Radha-Kalachandji and the devotees in the spirit of the teachings you have given.

Your servant,
Manjari Gopika

Hare Krishna! All glories to Srila Prabhupada!
 Please accept my humble obeisances, dear Guru Maharaj.
 On this, my dearest day, your appearance day, I want to express my deepest gratitude for your mercy, your example of pure devotion to Srila Prabhupada, and your commitment to his mission.
 Almost a year has passed since the initiation you bestowed upon me on Srila Prabhupada's behalf.
 Throughout this time, I have tried to follow your instructions and your example.
 This year has been a very difficult test for our family.
 My husband nearly lost his life. He spent three and a half months in the hospital, and only thanks to your prayers and the prayers of devotees was he able to overcome his illness and is now in rehabilitation.
 Just before Anantatma Prabhu was released from the hospital, our son Nimai Krishnachandra was drafted into the army. And only thanks to the prayers of devotees is he alive and continuing his spiritual practice in military conditions.
 Dear Guru Maharaj, once, in Chowpatty Temple, in answer to my question: Can a person with my past hope for salvation? You said, "Serve the devotees, serve the exalted devotees, that will save you."
 Since then, I have tried to follow your words, and by the grace of HH Keshava Swami, Anantatma Prabhu and I perform any service that Maharaj tells us.
 For three years, we've been organizing trips around India for him and his disciples, including pilgrimages to Vrindavan, Puri, and Mayapur. In November, he'll be bringing groups to Govardhan Ecovillage.
 Maharaj provides much service through caring for devotees, and every time, in different situations, I remember your example, Guru Maharaj—how you care for devotees and how you teach us to treat them.
 It can be very difficult in situations of injustice to remember Krishna and the soul, and at such moments, a phrase you said in one of your lectures comes to mind: "If you're right, you're still wrong."
 This helps to soften the situation and maintain relationships.
 I won't take up much of your time, dear Gurudev.
 I'll conclude my letter with words of immeasurable gratitude for all the lessons you've taught me.
 Especially the lesson of your faith in us disciples, when on May 4, 2024, we sat in the Moscow temple with new kanthimalas around our necks, awaiting initiation, and you informed us of Gopal Krishna Goswami's grave condition and the cancellation of the initiation.
 At that moment, a cry of "Jai, Gurudev!" burst from my heart.
 I felt that, despite being one twenty-thousandth part of a family of disciples, you spiritually love and believe in me—in my strength and steadfastness, in my ability to understand you without words.
 And at that moment, I also understood the true meaning of your words, "We are Prabhupada's family."
 I felt that it was at that moment that you united me with this family.
 By denying me the ritual of initiation, you initiated us into the original essence of the science and practice of bhakti.
 You taught me a second, very important lesson without words when, after a week at Ecovillage, I left for Puri to continue my service to Keshava Swami and my husband, Anantatma Prabhu.
 When you heard about my plans, you made a gesture with your hand as if you were touching the ground and smiled approvingly.
 At that moment, I realized what was truly dear to your heart was not my presence, but my unceasing service to the Vaishnavas—those dear to the Lord and Srila Prabhupada.
 Thank you so much, dear Guru Maharaj, for your mercy and generosity toward me.
 I think of you in every event, every day, no matter what happens.
 I remember your words and your example first and foremost.
 In this way, I learn to live as you once told me: "No matter how far we may be, we must learn to live as if I were always near."
 This year, the Tomsk Yatra organized a wonderful Ratha Yatra festival, and evenings dedicated to Srila Prabhupada continue to be held.
 Every day, the temple prepares a beautiful bhoga offering to Sri Sri Nitai Gaura Chandra, and every evening of the week, interesting programs are organized for the parishioners.
 Bowing at your feet, I tearfully pray:
 Please bless me with pure love for Radha and Krishna,
 An unbreakable connection with the mission of Srila Prabhupada,
 And a strong taste for serving the Vaishnavas...
 Your obedient servant,
 Ananta Devi Dasi

Dear Maharaj, 
 There's a famous quote which many of us young people love to cite: "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind."
 
 When I was a kid, in passively hearing your lectures with my parents who are your dear disciples Radhacaran Prabhu and Ujjvala Sakhi Devi, one word always stood out: compassion. I did not know what it meant, but I could tell it meant a lot to you.
 
 In your glorious 75 years on this planet, of which today I have spent 23 as a product of that same compassion – I know that compassion is something you not just speak of, but truly live. And by trying to follow your example, I know that one day even my mean self can begin to understand what compassion truly means.
 
 When a devotee was once almost crying for not being able to practice bhakti as much as they would like, you lovingly told them to just try and keep trying. You chose kind.
 When a simple village lady prayed for your blessings for an upcoming surgery in Hindi/Marathi, you not only understood but also deeply reciprocated to her in the best language possible. You chose kind.
 When people judged or mistreated you, you never said one bad word about them. And when people were not so nice to each other, you taught them how to love and respect. You chose kind.
 When managers for a new project could not make it work with each other, you told them to just meet ever so often and not even discuss any work. You chose kind.
 When someone once lost a lot of money for the society, you gave him a second chance - outvaluing the person beyond the possession or property. You chose kind.
 When given any opportunity to speak, you adjusted your language and manner so people can genuinely assimilate the teachings of our tradition. You chose kind.
 When your humility makes you uncomfortable at even the smallest of attention to yourself, you wrote your entire story just to help a whole world of seekers in their journey home to God and Guru. You chose kind.
 When guests were to come to GEV, instead of asking the captive audience to chant, you captivated your audience to come forward and sing on their own. You chose kind.
 When people thought to optimise for who is most important, you said that everyone who comes to Chowpatty is a VIP guest of Sri Sri Radha Gopinath. You chose kind.
 When devotees pushed for pragmatism and scale, you had an eye for every little detail which is immeasurable by any scale. You chose kind.
 When others felt that donkeys serve no utility, you asked them to take care of them in your farm. You chose kind.
 And whenever a donkey like me makes an ass of himself and does not love and serve enough, you still tap his head and give him a hug. You choose kind.
 
 Thank you Maharaj for teaching us how to be kind – for every time you chose to be kind, you were actually the most right. And in my aspiration to be a beneficiary of the compassion of Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, Srila Prabhupada and Your Holiness, I pray I always remember and do what is right – being kind.
 
 Your servant,
 Mukund Hari

You revealed to me that you are always with me, watching over this struggling soul. You taught me that bhakti is not about convenience; it is about consciousness. It is about offering our full, undivided attention to the Holy Names. That day, you didn't just give an instruction; you gave me the profound realization of your ever-watchful presence. It is not easy to always follow, but by your mercy, everything is possible.
 
 My Shelter and My Family
 
 Where would I be without the shelter of your words? Your lectures are my solace, my guiding light in the darkness of this age. And in your divine arrangement, you have given me another great gift: my senior godbrothers. Seeing their unwavering faith, their humility, and the way they carry you in their hearts is my constant inspiration. In their association, I feel I am always with you, for they are your true servants, fully surrendered to your mission. They are living proof of your transformative power.
 
 My Humble Prayers
 
 My only prayer, my dear Maharaj, is for your long, healthy life. Please stay with us for many, many years to come. Please continue to uplift us, to tolerate our mistakes, and to purify our duplicitous hearts. Our only responsibility is to be sincere and humble, and even that we borrow from you.
 
 I know I am the most fallen. I know I will always be the last in the queue of your followers. But I pray that you never let go of your shelter. Without it, I am nothing.
 
 Please bless me that I may someday develop a shred of genuine devotion that is pleasing to you and to Sri Sri RadhaGopinath.
 
 Your eternally indebted servant,

Hare Krishna Maharaj.
 Please accept my most humble obeisances at your transcendental, merciful lotus feet on this most auspicious occasion of your divine and glorious Vyasa Puja. I also offer my most respectful humble obeisances at the dust of your exalted parents’ lotus feet for giving us this matchless gift of your divine personality.
 
 The spiritual master comes to this material world to deliver the conditioned souls and help them on their journey back home, back to the spiritual world. Maharaj, from the very early days of your life, you exhibited the qualities of a very, very exalted, liberated soul. When you were very young, I think your father had bought a new car, and you didn’t think yourself qualified to sit on the seat, so you sat on the floor of the car. I can’t even imagine such humility in a child so young. That just goes to show how elevated and how renounced your consciousness already was. And as you grew, you progressively showed so many other qualities of a resident of the spiritual world.
 
 I offer my heartfelt thanks to His Holiness Bhakti Tirtha Swami Maharaj for lovingly asking you to write about your spiritual journey, because through your book *The Journey Home*, we get a glimpse into your wonderful characteristics. I liked the book so much that I couldn’t put it down.
 
 There are so many devotees from all over the world who want to glorify you. I would like to say that one of the highlights of my life was when I met you at one of the kirtan programs that you held. My mother had come to India at that time, so she also came to the program with me, and my Guru Maharaj introduced her to you. That was a very historic moment for both of us, my mother and me.
 
 While I was serving in Bombay, whenever my Guru Maharaj returned from traveling, and if you were also in India, there would be some big sankirtan program somewhere, or one at Chowpatty Temple. You also held many programs in Pune where I learned so much. You gave us a real taste for hearing, chanting, and kirtan. Of course, I couldn’t keep up with everybody there, but I learned that this is what real kirtan is meant to be.
 
 Maharaj, I feel that you are a real sadhu. When I stand in front of you, I know you can see right through my contaminated, dirty heart. I feel very unqualified to be in your presence, but I also feel that your presence is necessary to purify my heart, because by associating with you:
 
 sādhu-saṅga’, sādhu-saṅga’ — sarva-śāstre kaya
 lava-mātra sādhu-saṅge sarva-siddhi haya
 
 I am very grateful for your association over the years, and for the association of your disciples, who are also exemplary and very kind. I remember when I first came to India, I was the only disciple of my Guru Maharaj here. Then one or two disciples came—Kunti Devi, then Vishakhapriya. Later Siddhi Lalasa also came, but that was further down the line.
 
 Your disciples used to be so kind to us, because we didn’t know how things worked in India. It was difficult for us to have a Vyasa Puja for my Guru Maharaj, but your disciples agreed to have a small program. Lalita Sakhi had a quite big boat, and it was decided that your senior disciples and a few disciples of my Guru Maharaj would have a small program on the boat consisting of kirtans, bhajans, katha, and then, of course, prasada.
 During prasada, My Guru Maharaj was speaking to one of your disciples, and when you were going past me and you stopped where I was sitting, near the end of the boat, and you bent down a little so that I could hear you. You said, “Nama Chintamani, don’t jump off the boat.”
 I was so shocked and surprised to hear that, because at that time I was having difficulty adapting to India, and there were many challenges. I was feeling very overwhelmed. When you said, “Don’t jump off the boat,” I understood you meant, “Don’t jump off the boat of ISKCON.” So I asked you, “Maharaj, what did you say?” And you looked at me very gravely and said, “I think you heard.” You gave one of those very deep, transcendental glances and walked past. And that was the end of my peace of mind! I couldn’t eat or concentrate on anything. Those words were just reverberating in my mind: “Don’t jump off the boat.” I added in my mind, “of ISKCON.” That instruction helped me so much. It made me think about what was actually happening and realize that my problems were not so great that I needed to jump off the boat of Lord Caitanya’s movement.
 
 When you came to stay with my Guru Maharaj at Carpentaria, and it was Tamal Krishna Maharaj’s disappearance day celebration, which we celebrated at Kandarpa Manjari’s and Krishna Kirtan Prabhu’s home, about an hour’s drive from where we stayed. I think HH Niranjan Swami Maharaj was also there. I’m not sure if, at this program, Mother Yamuna and Mother Dinatarini also came, because they were living just down the road from Kandarpa Manjari’s.
 
 When it was my time to speak, I mentioned the incident where I had cooked for Tamal Krishna Goswami Maharaj and the devotees going on parikram — my Guru Maharaj’s disciples and Tamal Krishna Maharaj’s disciples during the VIHE. On Saturday, it was our day when we went on parikram. I felt that I should do some service, so I tried to make a preparation. I could see that there were too many devotees and I wouldn’t be able to manage, but I still tried, and it wasn’t such a success. I had made poha, but there was no chutney with it. And, in India, everybody knows that some preparations have to have chutney or some wet accompaniment with them.
 
 Tamal Krishna Maharaj asked, “Who cooked?” because there was no chutney. He commented, “Giriraj Maharaj should beat his women disciples — and especially Nama Chintamani. He shouldn’t let her put a foot in the kitchen.” Everybody was laughing, and my Guru Maharaj leaned over to Niranjan Swami Maharaj and you and said, “I wish I knew this earlier.” And there was more laughter.
 
 Later, another time I glorified Kunti Devi for how selflessly she served my Guru Maharaj. And on the way home, you told me that you liked my offering the best. I felt so enlivened by that. Because honestly, I didn’t think it was anything special. Yet your encouragement meant so much.
 
 I also remember that sometimes I don’t follow proper protocol. When my Guru Maharaj became very ill and had to have a bypass surgery, I was so hysterical and disturbed that I phoned the Chowpatty temple and asked to speak to you. By Krishna’s arrangement, you happened to be near the phone. I think you even picked it up. You were so calm. You said, “Don’t worry, we are all praying.” All the godbrothers were praying. Your assurance gave me so much relief, and by the mercy of the Vaishnavas my Guru Maharaj recovered.
 
 Maharaj, I want to say so much about your preaching and how you are such an exemplary devotee. You are always thinking about how to expand Srila Prabhupada’s mission and how to cultivate Vaishnava qualities in your disciples. By your example, we learn these qualities ourselves. Once HH Bhakti Charu Swami Maharaj mentioned that when he visited somewhere in South India, the devotees were so humble and wonderful. He said, “They remind me of someone, but I can’t think who.” He asked one of them, “Who is your spiritual master?” The brahmachari said, “His Holiness Radhanath Swami.” Maharaj said, “Oh! How could I not have guessed?”
 
 Your projects—GEV, the Bhakti Center in New York, and so many others—are all such incredible contributions. There are so many efforts you make that we don’t even know about, all to secure the future of Srila Prabhupada’s movement so that for the next 10,000 years, the preaching will continue to expand. Even at the cost of your health, you are ready to do anything and everything for Srila Prabhupada.
 
 I must also mention this—otherwise this offering cannot be complete. When I was in Carpinteria and you visited, I had just had a hip replacement surgery. I was moving around with a walker. After lunch one day, you saw me and asked how I was doing. You know my heart, and you knew how anxiety-stricken I was about being able to walk again. I was thinking, “How will I serve if I cannot walk?” You told me, “Don’t worry. My father had two knee replacements and He said, ‘Now I can do any damn thing I want.’” Meaning I would also recover fully. I had dreams about walking again, going up the stairs, and your words helped remove my anxiety. You encouraged me so much.
 
 I miss your personal association. Even one or two minutes with you gives me so much strength and happiness. You have been in India, and I have also been here since the end of 2023. In January 2024 I had a procedure on my spine, and now I live right opposite Bhaktivedanta Hospital. You have visited this place many times, but because of my condition, I have not been able to meet you personally. Still, I know that you know everything that is going on, and that your blessings are always with me. I thank you very much once again for your ongoing support, encouragement, and kindness.
 
 And I also dream of you sometimes.
 
 Maharaj, I thank you so much for all the wonderful association I have had with you and my Guru Maharaj. It is one of the most inspiring things in my life. Please bless us that we can develop even one drop of your amazing qualities. Thank you so much, Maharaj, for being part of my life.}}

Hare Krishna, Dear Guru Maharaj,
Please accept my humble obeisances.
All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
Dandavat pranams.
On this most auspicious occasion of your 75th appearance day, I find myself at a loss for words, unsure where to begin or how to fully express my feelings. There is so much I wish to convey, and the list could go on endlessly. I am deeply grateful for everything you have done for me, my family, the ISKCON movement, and countless devotees around the world. You have become a beacon of hope for so many, serving as a shining, living example of a true and genuine follower of His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada—firmly rooted in the blossoming devotee tree of his spiritual legacy, as a radiant branch of Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu’s tree of love.
Your personal association, inspiring lectures, and exemplary actions—especially in how you interact with devotees and others—are truly remarkable. You speak exactly what others need to hear, connecting heart to heart with compassion, empathy, and sensitivity. People are naturally drawn to your personality, as you embody and radiate the all-attractive nature of Krishna.
From my own interactions with you, as well as the experiences of others, I have realized that you are a bona fide ambassador of the great mahajans, carrying Krishna within your heart. It feels as though you are directly connected to the Supersoul, speaking and acting in perfect harmony with divine guidance. Your thoughts, words, and actions are perfectly synchronized, reflecting the mood and consciousness of Srimati Radharani—ever compassionate, always appreciative, seeing only the good in others, and constantly encouraging everyone. You never write anyone off, but instead offer chance after chance for improvement. The way you truly "walk the talk" brings everyone closer to the loving Divine Couple, following the directions of the Goswamis in pleasing service to Mahaprabhu.
Your yatras reverberate with the mercy and compassion of Sri Nityananda Mahaprabhu. The way you guide everyone to the Dham allows us to truly see and experience the spiritual world, its divine activities, and the lilas of the Divine Couple—through your vision and presence, you become a window for us to witness what you see, as you embody compassion for countless souls and for Krishna Himself.
The many projects you have initiated—temples, new centers, farm communities, hospitals, eye camps, and more—are beautiful expressions of your love and dedication to your Guru Maharaj. Through these endeavors, you are setting new heights and boundaries, inspiring others to follow in your illustrious footsteps.
It is truly amazing, Maharaj, how you have dedicated your entire life as an Akhanda Brahmachari, like Bhishma Dev, never deviating from love and service to the mission of your Gurudeva. The example you set is extraordinary and will inspire generations to come. Though it may take me many lifetimes to follow in your footsteps, with your help and mercy, I pray that you hold me close so I may walk behind you. Perhaps one day, I will be able to do something that sincerely, selflessly, and without ulterior motives, pleases you.
Your ever-smiling face, combined with a lion-like sobriety while serving devotees and thunderous determination in carrying forward the mission, is truly remarkable. You possess an ever-accommodating nature and a heart as soft as butter when dealing with devotees, yet you are uncompromising and disciplined with yourself, steadfast in your sadhana and principles. Your selfless giving, without expecting anything in return except the opportunity to serve, beautifully embodies the Acintya Bheda Abheda Tattva of Mahaprabhu—the sweet and loving contradictions that harmonize shastra, tattva, and rasa as illustrious ornaments.
These qualities attract the mood and mercy of the previous acharyas, offering hope, purpose, direction, and meaning to the lives of conditioned souls, and providing a path for them to stay and grow in spiritual life. How do you achieve this? Perhaps, with your blessings, I may one day understand a little and carry your mood as your servant of the servant.
You never speak of your own achievements as service to your Guru; yet, like the fragrance of a flower that cannot be hidden, your accomplishments naturally shine forth. Krishna Himself reveals you and your services to the world, showcasing your greatness even as you choose to remain humble and in the background. People from all over the world are drawn to you, just as honeybees are irresistibly attracted to nectar.
I observe that your own godbrothers and godsisters regard you as a beacon of hope—a true preceptor and representative of His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. The way you interact with them, and the loving reciprocation you share, reminds me of the affectionate exchanges in Gaura Lila between Mahaprabhu and His intimate devotees. It is as if the Srimad Bhagavatam is coming to life through your actions. Despite your busy schedule, you always make time for your godbrothers and godsisters, while also maintaining a perfect balance in caring for your own disciples and the disciples of other gurus.
Many devotees share their personal observations, interactions, and experiences with you across various situations and circumstances. The common thread in all these accounts is your unwavering consistency—always grateful, humble, and eager to serve, without any conditions, reservations, or limitations.
On a personal level, my interactions with you during your visits to Columbus—whether staying at our home, driving you locally, or going out for walks—are cherished memories that I will relish for the rest of my life. These moments are truly your causeless mercy, which I feel undeserving of, yet I continually hanker for them, as they keep me alive on the path of Bhakti, inspiring me to remain enthusiastic, grateful, and determined to continue, no matter what challenges arise. Your prayers for our family Vrajabhakti, Narahari Rupa, and Parikshith, and your kind support during times of need, though we may not deserve them, are like a lighthouse guiding our boat through the storms of life.
I pray to Lord Narasimha Deva for your health and physical well-being, asking Him to grant you a long, healthy life so that you may continue to save and guide countless souls who are searching for Krishna, yearning to advance on the path of Bhakti, and struggling for strength, hope, and direction to make their lives meaningful.
Maharaj, I am eternally grateful to you. No matter what I do, I can never repay you for all that you have given me, though I do not deserve it. Please bless me so that I may always remain connected to you and your mission, stay steadfast on the path of Bhakti, and continue to serve you in a way that pleases you, no matter what challenges arise.
Thank you very much.
Your servant of servant,
Naveen Krishna Das
ISKCON Columbus
Board of Directors and Temple Management

Dear Guru Maharaja,
Please accept our humble obeisances at your divine lotus feet.
All glories to Sri Guru, Gauraṅga, and Srila Prabhupada!

Dear Gurudeva,

We were recently hearing your lecture from the Govardhan Yatra, where you narrated the profoundly touching pastime of Siva Koṛi—the helpless she-jackal who was chased, beaten, and trapped in a pit of fire by cruel boys, only to be saved by the compassionate glance of Srimati Radharaṇi and Lalita Sakhi.

This narration deeply moved our hearts and revealed several transformative lessons:

1.        The Jackal Is Our Condition
You explained that the jackal represents us—the conditioned souls lost in the dense forest of material existence, scavenging for fleeting pleasures amidst decay. We are pursued by the three modes of nature—the boys symbolizing our lust, anger, and greed—who pelt us with anxieties and beat us with the stick of repeated birth and death. Finally, we fall into the pit of illusion, surrounded by the flames of samsara, burning with regret, fear, and unfulfilled desires—utterly helpless.
2.        The Fire Is Our Existence
The blazing fire around the pit is the samsara-davanala—the all-consuming forest fire of material life. From within that pit, our cries for help are weak and distorted, just like the jackal’s painful howls. We cannot save ourselves.
3.        Lalita Sakhi Is the Guru
Just as the jackal’s cry reached the merciful ears of Srimati Radharaṇi, our sincere—though feeble—prayers reach you, Gurudeva. You, as Lalita Sakhi, respond to our cries, dispelling the boys of material attachment, extinguishing the fire of suffering with the cool water of your instructions, and lifting us from the darkness of ignorance. Your compassionate glance alone purifies our hearts and fills them with hope.
4.        Transformation Through Service
The jackal did not become a lion or a swan; she was transformed by mercy into an eternal attendant in Radha-Govinda’s pastimes. Likewise, you teach us that spiritual transformation does not lie in becoming great scholars or powerful preachers, but in embracing our humble position as servants of the servants—finding joy in assisting the Lord’s devotees and delighting in the service of Sri Sri Radha-Govinda.
Gurudeva, just as the jackal was uplifted by the merciful glance of Srimati Radharaṇi, we too—though distracted and undeserving—are being rescued by your compassion and guided by your kirtan. You are personally leading us from the darkness of selfishness into the light of selfless devotion.

We pray that, like that jackal, we may gain the humility to bow before the devotees, to receive their merciful glance, and to be eternally engaged in the loving service of Srimati Radhika.
We have no qualification, no devotion, and no love—but we have your mercy. Please allow us to remain, always, in the mood of that jackal: helpless yet hopeful, unworthy yet uplifted, forever aspiring to be the humble servants of the servants of Srimati Radharaṇi.

The Soulful Call of Your Kirtan
We also wish to offer our heartfelt gratitude for the kirtans you led during the Yatra. They were not mere melodies but divine invocations—soulful calls that pulled our distracted minds toward the Lord. We were reminded of the pastime of Srila Prabhupada in Tompkins Square Park, where through three hours of kirtan he opened his eyes to find hundreds of souls gathered—the holy name itself having awakened their dormant devotion. Similarly, your kirtans are spiritual lifelines; they purify the atmosphere, exhilarate the heart, and connect us to you, to Srila Prabhupada, and to Sri Gauraṅga in shared transcendental joy. Through them, we feel inspired, grounded, and eager to serve Sri Guru and Gauraṅga.

Your insignificant servants,
Navin Gopal das, Swamini Radhika Devi dasi, and Ishwari

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my most humble and repeated obeisances at your divine lotus feet.
 All glories to Śrīla Prabhupāda.
 
 On this sacred occasion of your 75th Vyasapuja, I bow with a heart filled with deep gratitude. Whatever I express here is only a very small attempt to glorify you, for your qualities are unlimited, while my ability is extremely limited. Still, the Gaudiya Vaishnava tradition teaches that glorifying the spiritual master is a sacred duty of the disciple, and therefore I offer this humble submission at your lotus feet.
 
 This past year has been the most transformative year of my life. By your causeless mercy, I received initiation from you on Dussehra day in Nashik. The four days of your association during that time were deeply life-changing. Your kīrtans, your gentle presence, and your compassionate dealings with each devotee made me feel that Krishna’s kindness was directly touching my heart. Although many devotees were gathered, you made each of us feel personally acknowledged. Such attention and affection are the true signs of a pure Vaishnava.
 
 Receiving your shelter opened my eyes to my own weaknesses. I see how restless and proud my mind often is, how easily I become distracted, and how quickly I forget spiritual priorities. Yet, instead of discouragement, your example fills me with hope. Your teachings guide me in every area of life—whether in my duties at MSEDCL, in family responsibilities, or when I attempt to preach in villages with hesitation and lack of confidence. Your words and actions show me how to live with sincerity, humility, and dedication.
 
 Guru Maharaj, on 7th August 2025, by your blessings and by Krishna’s mercy, my wife and I were gifted with a baby boy. We feel that he has come into our lives through the prayers and blessings of Vaishnavas. Our sincere desire is that he may grow up imbibing the qualities you embody—compassion, simplicity, gratitude, service, and devotion to the Holy Name. We pray that our home becomes a place where your teachings are practiced daily and where the Holy Name remains the center of our lives.
 
 Your life, Guru Maharaj, is a living example of Gaudiya Vaishnava philosophy. The scriptures declare sākṣād-dharitvena samasta śāstraiḥ—that the guru is the transparent representative of the Supreme Lord—yet simultaneously the most humble servant. Both these truths shine beautifully in you. Your humility reminds me of Haridāsa Ṭhākura, who considered himself lower than the straw in the street. Your compassion echoes the boundless mercy of Nityānanda Prabhu. Your unwavering dedication to Śrīla Prabhupāda’s mission reflects the spirit of the Six Gosvāmīs, who lived only for Mahāprabhu’s purpose.
 
 Your kīrtans awaken devotion.
 Your lectures illuminate the heart.
 Your personal example inspires transformation.
 
 Through your life, I understand in a practical way the qualities that Śrīla Rūpa Gosvāmī described in a pure Vaishnava—expert engagement, gentleness, gratitude, and boundless compassion. To witness these qualities in a living person is the greatest fortune of my life.
 
 Despite your mercy, I remain full of shortcomings. My chanting often lacks depth, my mind becomes restless, and my service attitude is inconsistent. Yet I continue to hold on to your teachings with sincerity, hoping to grow steadily in spiritual life. I pray that I may develop deeper devotion, humility, and steadiness in my practices.  3. Speak without offending — showing sensitivity

Dear Guru Mahārāj,
 Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to You and Gaurāṅga. All glories to Śrīla Prabhupāda.
 
 On this most auspicious day of Your 75th Appearance, I feel deeply fortunate and grateful to have received this opportunity to express even a drop of appreciation for Your boundless compassion, love, and care.
 
 During the recent Kārtik Yātrā, I witnessed Your care in a way that touched me profoundly. You envisioned and arranged every detail with such thoughtfulness that every devotee — young, elderly, or physically challenged — felt personally embraced by Your affection. The separate prasādam arrangement for senior devotees, where they could sit peacefully without any anxiety, reflected the compassionate heart with which You lead us. I could see how much ease and dignity it brought to them, and it reminded me that real spirituality expresses itself through practical, heartfelt compassion.
 
 The care You arranged for the children was equally heart-warming. The dedicated play-area brought them so much joy, allowing them to feel at home in a spiritual environment. It also allowed their parents to hear Your nectarean kathā peacefully, without worry.
 
 Your compassion extended even into the realm of health and well-being. The medical seva arranged under Your guidance was a blessing for many of us. I personally experienced its value during my leg injury. The timely attention, the gentle care, and the genuine concern shown by devotees brought me so much relief. I also witnessed devotees with serious health conditions receiving whatever care and treatment they needed from doctor-devotees. That entire arrangement radiated Your spirit — where every devotee’s pain is Your pain, and every devotee’s comfort is Your comfort.
 
 One of the most wondrous moments of the Yātrā was the complete absence of rain, even though it was expected. It felt as though Girirāja Himself was sheltering us because of Your divine presence. It allowed all of us to experience the Govardhan pastime in a way that felt divinely orchestrated. Walking under the clear skies, hearing the sweet kīrtans, and seeing thousands of devotees moving together in harmony felt like a miracle You personally gifted us. It was only because of Your mercy that I could witness the beauty and sweetness of that sacred pastime right there in Govardhan.
 
 Throughout the entire Yātrā, You held us together like a loving father — guiding, protecting, and inspiring us at every moment. Your presence softened every hardship and transformed every moment into a spiritual treasure. The way You personally observed every detail made each one of us feel valued, cared for, and deeply sheltered.
 
 Mahārāj, today I offer something from my heart. I humbly beg for Your blessings to help me remain steady in the vows I took at my initiation on December 27th at Govardhan Eco-Village. Please give me the strength and sincerity to live those vows — not mechanically, but lovingly, with full surrender to Your instructions.  Guru Mahārāj, whatever spiritual progress I have made is only because of Your mercy. Whatever I may become in the future will also be by Your grace alone. On this sacred day of Your Appearance, I pray to remain forever under the shelter of Your lotus feet.

Dear Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my most humble, prostrated obeisances unto your lotus feet.
 
 It is our great fortune to witness your 75th birthday. From the time we met you first, you have been the same changeless personality, encompassing great humility, tolerance, respect to others, and absorption in Krishna consciousness. It is difficult to find even a single small event of any deviation from true Vaishnava behavior. By your personal example, you have shown modern and often impatient devotees how a genuine Vaishnava lives and behaves.
 
 I feel grateful that such an illustrious example exists in the present time. You show how Bhakti can be lived with balance, intelligence, emotional maturity, respect, inner depth, and steady dedication to the holy name and the mission of Srila Prabhupāda. Your life teaches me that true greatness does not need any display. It shines quietly through your character, your conduct, and your consistency.
 
 You are very different from guru personalities who depend on scholarship, complex philosophy, or impressive spiritual presentations. Your strength does not come from dramatic stories or usage of esoteric language or higher realization stuff. It comes from the quiet purity of your heart. You carry a heart of gold—simple, compassionate, respectful, and sincerely dedicated to serving others without any desire to show yourself.
 
 What I admire most is that your devotional life stands firmly on the essentials: deep attachment to the dhāma, sincere respect for the holy name, heartfelt honor for Srila Prabhupāda and especially his disciples, and genuine affection for the simple Brajvasis. Their natural devotion matches your inner nature. Your connection with them is not external. It is deep, personal, and full of affection.
 
 One quality of yours that inspires me again and again is the way you give complete attention to anyone who comes before you. Whether it is a senior devotee or a new Vaishnava, you give the same calm and full presence. Even a short moment with you makes a person feel valued and respected. There is no hurry, no distraction, and always full presence of mind and heart.
 
 Your eagerness to improve your service, refine your interactions, and deepen your sincerity is adorable and amazing. You do not present yourself as someone with extraordinary access. Your preference for honest, grounded Bhakti over philosophical show makes you easy to trust and relate with.
 
 When I watch you, I understand that real devotion does not need to look extraordinary. It only needs to be true. In your presence, I feel that Bhakti is not something to perform. It is something to live—quietly, sincerely, and every day. Your example reminds me that true greatness hides itself in simplicity, service, steadiness, and a deep connection to the holy name.
 There are some recent interactions with you where I have experienced the greatness of your good self:
 A During the construction of New Hospital in Barsana, your good self visited when the structure was complete and internal works were pending. There was a delay in the timeline for completion of the project. When you arrived, you wanted to use the washroom, and I took you to a temporary setup. Feeling responsible, I said, “Maharaj, I am sorry the project is delayed and not completed on time.”
 Your reply was spontaneous and a few words only, and that pierced my heart. You said, “I see more than the timeline whether bhakti is growing or not.” I became speechless. In that moment, I understood what you wanted me to focus on, beyond deadlines and external achievements.
 
 B Last year, I was in a very introspective and remorseful state. Sachinandan Prabhu had unexpectedly left all of us in August 2024. He was my partner during my early preaching days in Nashik. His sudden departure left me sad and withdrawn. I often reflected on our early days together and wondered how my leaving Nashik had affected so many devotees. Every day I was simply expressing my feelings to you in my heart.
 
 In October 2024, by your mercy, you visited Nashik after a long time. I also happened to be in Nashik and was invited to a private gathering of devotees. I sat quietly in a corner. When you entered and sat on the vyāsāsana, one devotee pulled me closer.
 As soon as you saw me, you smiled brightly and said, “Welcome home.”
 Those words melted my heart. They carried acceptance, affection, and genuine happiness. When you later asked me to speak, I became unusually emotional in front of the devotees. That moment healed me deeply. I felt your love and care in a very real way.
 
 C Soon after Nashik, in the same month, I again had the opportunity to meet you at GEV. You met the CEO of Vaidyaratnam and his wife. I was there with my wife, Haripriya Gopi Devi. You were relaxed, happy, and fully available that day.
 After their meeting, I gently asked if we could speak with you for a few minutes. You immediately agreed. You spent around 45 minutes listening to our difficulties, our challenges, and our concerns. During this meeting, we felt so much of your affection. You kept giving us gifts, four in total for our two daughters who were not present.
 When we came downstairs and waited for the cart, you came again, plucked two small flowers from the garden, and said they were for our daughters. As you walked ahead, you kept looking back at us with a warm smile. That moment was a complete mercy package. Even today, remembering that, we feel overwhelmed by your unconditional love and acceptance.
 
 All these experiences remain etched in our consciousness and keep reminding us of the true nature of a sadhu—full of genuine love and compassion.
 
 Dear Gurudev, we are very fallen and disoriented. We are still struggling to completely follow all instructions given by you, still preparing to surrender, and hope that one day we can genuinely follow the mood and example set by you in a small capacity. Our children also aspire to imbibe your mood and sincerely serve your instructions and your devotees.
 
 Your unworthy servants,
 Paramahamsa Das and Haripriya Gopi Devi Dasi.

**Vyāsa–pūjā Poem in Glorification of His Holiness Radhanath Swami Maharaj**
 
 
 From Chicago’s shores a seeker arose,
 a gentle heart the whole world knows;
 Though born amidst comfort, privilege, and grace,
 You longed for truth — for Krishna’s embrace.
 
 Leaving home at nineteen, with courage untold,
 you crossed many lands, both scorching and cold;
 Europe, the deserts, the Himalayan air,
 each step a prayer, each moment a dare.
 
 In holy Vrindavan Your heart found its door,
 at the feet of Prabhupada — you needed nothing more.
 His loving glance, his mercy so bright,
 became the compass guiding Your life.
 
 In the spirit of a monk, humble and mild,
 You served every soul like a parentless child;
 With folded hands and compassionate eyes,
 You show us where true greatness lies.

This verse from Siksastakam truly defines the real characteristics of our beloved Guru Maharaj – HH Radhanath Swami. He is the living encyclopedia of sastras – the personified ‘Vyakti Bhagavatam’. Still, he is as humble as a blade of grass on the street which does not want any recognition. Guru Maharaj is a true role model when it comes to humility, and he wants his disciples and followers to keep the humble attitude no matter how elevated he or she becomes in practicing Krishna Consciousness principles.

Our Guru Maharaj is transcendental to the three modes of material nature, beyond the bodily concept of life. Therefore, he remains equipoised amidst the dualities of life: happiness & distress, heat & cold, profit & loss, honor & dishonor, etc. He is as tolerant as a tree and preaches the same tolerant attitude to his disciples and followers.

Our beloved Guru Maharaj is ready to offer all respects to others and expects none for himself. He is a true Vaisnava who considers any respect offered to him as a hot potato and does not keep the same to himself.  The Caterpillar Metamorphosis
 
 Creeping and crawling from branch to branch
 Feeding voraciously on the leafy greens
 The caterpillar lives a greedy life
 Munching and chewing from dawn to night
 
 Moving surreptitiously with his multifarious limbs
 “I am the lord of all I survey,” he thinks
 He devours all there is in sight
 Ne’er pausing to see the light
 
 Then one day, he beholds a butterfly
 And wonders what it’s like to have wings and fly
 With some remorse, he retrospects his gluttonous life
 Full of will-o'-the-wisp joy and endless strife
 
 Now he deems he has had too much
 Pleasures and pains of the world galore
 “Is this what I am meant to do?
 Eat, excrete, and cry for more!”
 
 “What, indeed, will set me free?
 What am I really meant to be?”
 He begins to see how futile
 Is the Ferris wheel he’s been riding for a while
 
 He stays, he rests, he retracts his limbs
 He suspends his game and then pupates
 He builds a wall between him and ‘the world’
 He now sees his sins; he contemplates
 
 Edged on by the vision of the liberated one
 Seeking to overhaul himself to the core
 Flaw by flaw, he does his bit
 But then he waits for the divine to restore
 
 He lays himself bare with all his faults
 To the scalpel of exacting reformation
 He submits to the ways of his guiding star
 And patiently awaits merciful transformation
 
 And one day, as the sun returns
 A crack appears in his rusted cocoon
 An eternal creature of beauty and bliss
 Opens his eyes to the timeless moon!

My most humble and heartfelt obeisances at the lotus feet of His Holiness Radhanath Swami Maharaj. Gurudev, on this sacred occasion of your 75th Vyas Puja, my heart is overflowing with emotions that are difficult to express in words. Your divine life, your compassion, your humility, and the unconditional love you shower upon every soul inspire the deepest gratitude within me. Yet, with trembling words and a prayerful heart, I attempt to place my feelings before your lotus feet.

My spiritual journey truly began on the 5th of October 2024, the day when I first received your divine darshan at Govardhan Ecovillage. That blessed moment transformed something within me in a way I had never experienced before. Your serene presence, gentle glance, and the quiet strength of your love awakened an indescribable attraction in my heart. From that very moment, an earnest desire to one day be accepted as your disciple silently took root within me. That day marked not merely a meeting—but the birth of a new longing, a new direction, a new life.

Last year, I received only a few sacred moments of your association. Even those brief interactions left a deep and lasting impact on my heart. But this year, by your causeless mercy and by the love of the devotees, I was blessed with the extraordinary fortune of spending seven full days in your divine company during the Kartik Govardhan Yatra 2025. Those seven days were not ordinary days; they were divine blessings that cleansed, nourished, and uplifted my soul. Your profound teachings, your heart-melting kirtans, your affectionate glances, and your boundless compassion created a transformation inside me that words cannot fully describe. Each moment in your presence felt like receiving new life. Your association dissolved confusions, quieted anxieties, and filled my heart with devotion and hope. In your presence, Gurudev, I realized that you are not only a teacher—you are the embodiment of pure love, humility, compassion, and Krishna consciousness. Your life itself is a scripture that guides, elevates, and purifies all who come in contact with you.

In preparation for your Vyas Puja, I took a heartfelt vow to read your sacred autobiography “The Journey Home” three times. Every page of this book reveals the depth of your devotion, the sincerity of your heart, the courage of your spiritual search, and the divine grace that protected and guided you. Reading it does not merely inspire me—it reshapes my inner world. It strengthens my longing to walk the sacred path you have shown, and it fills me with reverence for the journey you undertook for the sake of seeking God.

My time with you in Vrindavan also remains one of the most precious gifts of my life. Your presence there felt like a gentle breeze carrying the sweetness of Krishna’s eternal abode. Your 75 years of divine life have brought guidance, love, and Krishna consciousness to thousands of souls around the world. I am one among those souls who has found direction, purpose, and meaning because of your mercy. Your presence is a lamp that illuminates countless lives, and I feel eternally grateful for the light you have brought into mine.

On this sacred day of your Vyas Puja, I pray from the core of my heart that your health remain strong, your life continue to shine with divine radiance, and your compassion flow forever upon all the souls seeking shelter at your lotus feet. Gurudev, may my life become an offering to your mission. May every breath of mine remember your kindness. And may I always remain your servant.

Your aspiring servant, your aspiring disciple,
Prathamesh Digambar Adhav

 Dear Guru Mahārāja,
 
 As you always emphasize, humility is the core principle of spiritual life.
 Authority, honor, power, beauty, money, and strength often make a person proud—yet in the life of a true devotee, these are not ornaments of ego but sacred responsibilities bestowed by the Supreme Lord to be used in His service and in service to His devotees.
 
 You have perfectly embodied this principle, Guru Mahārāja.
 Through every action, word, and interaction, you have demonstrated the qualities of a first-class disciple of Śrīla Prabhupāda, carrying forward his mission with purity, gravity, dedication, and deep humility.
 
 I am reminded of an example shared by HG Amogh Līlā Prabhu. Speaking of Śrīla Rādhānātha Swāmī Mahārāja, he explained how such an exalted speaker—learned, realized, empowered—does not need to prepare for any class, yet still dedicates hours to research, references, notes, and insights from our ācāryas.
 
 When asked why, Mahārāja replied:
 “There are so many people who come to listen to Kṛṣṇa-kathā. This is a very precious time of their life. It is my responsibility to ensure they receive the best possible benefit. They could spend this time elsewhere, yet they choose to hear Kṛṣṇa-kathā.”
 
 This profound sense of responsibility—rooted deeply in humility—is exactly what we witness in you, Guru Mahārāja.
 
 I vividly remember your powerful class on Balarāma Pūrṇimā, when you said with complete honesty:
 “I have not prepared to give this class.”
 Such transparent humility can arise only from one who is truly sincere. Although honored, respected, and spiritually empowered, you never use these gifts for self-glorification. You use everything solely in the service of Guru, Gaurāṅga, and the Vaiṣṇavas.
 
 Last year, during a Vyāsa Pūjā offering, Śrīla Bhakti Vijñāna Goswāmī Mahārāja shared the beautiful analogy of the vatsa, the small calf.
 
 A mother cow’s love is spontaneous, overflowing, unconditional.
 Her milk flows joyfully simply because her calf needs nourishment.
 
 Similarly, a genuine Guru showers his disciples with unending, selfless love—vātsalya-rasa—constantly desiring their spiritual upliftment, protection, and eternal welfare.
 
 In return, the disciple must develop the same pure, simple dependence that the calf has for its mother—
 following naturally, trusting completely,
 receiving guidance with gratitude and surrender.
 
 But there is also a solemn warning in this analogy:
 When the calf grows horns and begins to poke the mother’s udder, she understands that the calf no longer needs her milk. Naturally, the flow becomes less.
 
 Likewise, when a disciple begins to think—
 “I know more than my Guru Mahārāja…”
 “I no longer need his mercy…”
 “I can advance on my own…”
 
 —then the flow of blessings and mercy becomes thinner.
 
 Gurudeva, on this sacred day, we pray sincerely that
 we may never grow such horns.
 May we remain forever as humble, grateful calves—
 fully dependent on your love, protection, and guidance.
 
 May we always honor your humility, your dedication, your sincerity, and your unwavering commitment to the mission of Śrīla Prabhupāda.
 
 Our Collective Prayer

 Thank you, Gurudeva.

गुरुदेव, मेरे प्रिय गुरुदेव, आप हैं कृष्ण रूप।

आप हैं करुणा सागर, कृपा निधान।
आपके नेत्रों में दिखती सभी जीवों के प्रति करुणा और उद्धार।
आपकी मुस्कुराहट है सभी कष्टों का निदान। आप बताते हैं कि आत्मा का आनंद समस्त सृष्टि के प्रिय प्रभु की महिमागान में है।
मेरे प्रिय गुरुदेव, आपके लिए सबसे मधुर कृष्ण नाम।
आपने बताया कि भक्ति के मार्ग में हमें एक विनम्र जीव बनने की तीव्र अभिलाषा करनी ही चाहिए।

आप भक्ति और ज्ञान के सागर हैं।
आप हृदय का अंधेरा दूर करने वाले ज्योति हैं। आपने ही बताया कि निःस्वार्थ जीवन, भक्ति पूर्ण जीवन, करुणा का जीवन ही वास्तविक खुशी है।

हे गुरुदेव, आप ही इस भवसागर से पार कराने वाले नाविक हैं।

गुरुदेव, आपका हृदय है वैष्णव-सेवा।

गुरुदेव, आप अपनी वाणी से बताते हैं और क्रियाकलापों द्वारा बताते हैं कि वैष्णव की सेवा के बिना, नम्र हुए बिना, सहनशील हुए बिना और कृतज्ञता के बिना शुद्ध भक्ति नहीं कर सकते हम भगवान के प्रति।

आप प्रेम की मूरत हैं। आपकी वाणी है सब कुछ, और वाणी में ही आपका संग है। हे मेरे परम पूज्य गुरुदेव, आपको शत-शत कोटि-कोटि प्रणाम। आपके चरणों में मेरा सिर नतमस्तक है।

मैं हूं आपकी दासी, भक्तों की दासी, भगवान की दासी। सेवा भाव हो बस मेरा धर्म और कर्म। कृपा करिए, दया करिए, करुणा करिए। हे परम आत्मा, मैं हूं गुणहीन, पतित जीवात्मा। कृपा करिए, सेवा दीजिए, अपनी शरण दीजिए, अपनी शरण दीजिए। कृपा करिए, गुरुदेव।

मैं याचना करती हूं, गुरु महाराज, मुझे ज्ञान, बुद्धि और दृढ़संकल्प दीजिए, जिससे कि मैं सभी प्रकार की इन्द्रिय तृप्ति को त्याग दूं, सभी अनर्थों को त्याग दूं, और भगवान कृष्ण के पवित्र नाम का जाप करने, श्रील प्रभुपाद जी की पुस्तक पढ़ने और भक्तों की सेवा करने के प्रति अत्यधिक लगाव विकसित करूं।

गुरुदेव, आप अपनी शरण में हमेशा रखिए। अपने इन चरण-कमलों की सेवा दीजिए। आप हमेशा स्वस्थ रहें, ठीक रहें, बस यही प्रार्थना है श्री श्री राधा-गोपीनाथ जी से।

हे मेरे आध्यात्मिक पिता, आप हम सब शिष्यों और सभी भक्तों पर अपनी कृपा दृष्टि बनाए रखिए और हमें यह आशीर्वाद दीजिए कि हमारे जीवन का लक्ष्य हो सिर्फ और सिर्फ सेवा, भगवान के प्रति, भक्तों के प्रति और आपके प्रति।

O my beloved Gurudev, you are the very form of Krishna.

You are the ocean of compassion, the treasure of mercy.
In your eyes shines compassion and deliverance for all living beings.

Your smile is the cure for all suffering. You teach that the soul’s true joy lies in glorifying the Supreme Lord of the entire creation.

My beloved Gurudev, for you the sweetest sound is the holy name of Krishna.

You have taught that on the path of devotion we must cultivate a deep longing to become humble beings.

You are the ocean of devotion and knowledge. You are the light that dispels the darkness of the heart. 

You have explained that a selfless life, a life full of devotion and compassion, is the only real happiness.

O Gurudev, you are the boatman who carries us across this ocean of material existence.
Your heart is dedicated to Vaishnava service.

 Through your words and actions you teach that without serving the Vaishnavas, without humility, tolerance, and gratitude, we cannot attain pure devotion to the Lord.

You are the embodiment of love. Your words are everything, and in your words lies your association. O my most worshipful Gurudev, I bow my head countless times at your lotus feet.

I am your servant, the servant of the devotees, the servant of the Lord. Let service alone be my religion and my duty. O Supreme Soul, please bestow mercy, compassion, and kindness upon me. I am a fallen soul without qualities—please grant me service, grant me shelter, grant me your refuge, O Gurudev.

I beg you, Guru Maharaj, to give me knowledge, wisdom, and firm determination so that I may renounce all forms of sense gratification, abandon all unwanted habits, and develop deep attachment to chanting the holy name of Lord Krishna, reading the books of Srila Prabhupada, and serving the devotees.

Gurudev, always keep me in your shelter and grant me service to your lotus feet. May you always remain healthy and well—this is my prayer to Sri Sri Radha Gopinath Ji.

O my spiritual father, please keep your merciful glance upon all of us disciples and devotees, and bless us that the sole aim of our lives may be service—service to the Lord, service to the devotees, and service to you.

All glories to Srila Guru Maharaj! 
All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

Your insignificant servant daughter

75th VYAS PUJA OFFERING 2025 TO H.H. RADHANATH SWAMI MAHARAJ

 Please accept my most humble obeisances.
 All Glories to Sri Guru and Gauranga. All Glories to Srila Prabhupada.
 
 I seek the blessings of all the Vaishnavas to express few words on this auspicious occasion.
 Maharaj, this year 2025, Kartik Yatra to Govardhan was amazing and well planned. To organize a yatra for 12,000+ devotees with so many facilities is not possible, and that too for 7 days. But due to your desire and empowerment, the yatra happened in a grand way videos are available to witness, and the whole Vaishnava community, including devotees from other Parampara, were amazed to witness and very appreciative. The desire of Srila Prabhupada, Guru Parampara, Lord Caitanya Mahaprabhu to spread the Holy names all over the world must have surely been fulfilled, and they must have showered their blessings. This is just not my opinion; we have all witnessed this grand event without any untoward incident. The Vrajwasi who offered his 9-acre agricultural field to make a pandal in Govardhan; the preparations started a few months earlier. At that time, it was raining in Vrindavan. A thought came, "What will happen if it rains during the yatra? Everything will collapse, and there will be lots of difficulty managing such a huge event." It appeared very difficult and impossible. But the Vrajwasi said, "Depend on Krsna. The Lord will protect the yatra against rains as He protected the Vrajwasis 5,000 years ago." Wow, truly the Lord protected the yatra, and immediately after the yatra, the rain showered. This is the power of a pure devotee. Maharaj, your lectures during the yatra took us to the pastimes of the Lord live, and the kirtans were amazing. We all have witnessed your deep absorption both in katha and kirtan. Personally, I felt your personal association was available to all your disciples, just like all the Vrajwasis were having personal association with the Lord during the Govardhan Lila. I offer my deepest gratitude to all the devotees who were working day and night for months to organize this yatra. The management was absolute because it is not humanly possible to meet the needs of all individual devotees so precisely.
 
 Maharaj, your Krsna katha during the yatra was not only narrating the pastimes of the Lord but revealing subtle instructions. In all your lectures, while narrating the sweet pastimes of the Lord, you give instructions. On this occasion, I would like to cite a few lectures of yours for the pleasure of all Vaishnavas and to ponder over the subtle instructions given by you for all of us to follow carefully.
 
 1. Amanina mana dena – We give all respect to others and expect none in return, that we do our service not for recognition but for the purification of our heart.
 2. Ahankar: Ahankar is removed by the mercy of the Lord and not by our efforts. It may take time, but not much time considering millions and millions of births we have been working on it and chanting its glories. We have created a monster, but Krsna can kill that demon, and He will through His holy names, through the blessings of Guru, through seva. If we have sincerity, gradually it will happen. It may take your whole life, but that’s not too much time considering you have been building it, nourishing it for many lifetimes. But in the process, you have to be willing to fight the lower tendencies. First thing, do not find faults in others. Krsna curbed the false pride of Kaliya. Krsna curbed the ego of Indra. First, He cleansed the ego of a great demon, and now He is about to cleanse the ego of a great demigod. Indra is actually a devotee; we should never insult Indra because he is a great devotee, but somehow He uses this particular devotee to show by example how careful we should be.
 
 3. Enthusiasm and patience = True surrender: We have to be patient, but at the same time, we have to work very hard with great enthusiasm. And if we are enthusiastic and patient, which is based on faith in the words of God, with the mercy of God, then with the combination of two is surrender.
 
 Maharaj, on this auspicious day, we all seek blessings from you for full protection, as we are all like crying babies, very close to Maya, and bound to do nonsense. We request you to forgive us and continue to shower your causeless mercy, and we all will try our best to serve you and Srila Prabhupada.
 Praying to all Vaishnavas to bless, so that I shed down my enjoying spirit and develop the service attitude in the mood of a servant of servants.
 
 Your insignificant servant,
 Premkirtan das
