Dear Śrī Gurudeva,
 I offer my respectful obeisances at your lotus feet.
 You are dear to my heart, for you have stirred within me the inspiration to yearn for Śrī Kṛṣṇa. You are dear to my heart, for you have opened your life and the secrets of your heart for the world to see, allowing me, through your Journey Home, to understand what a true Vaiṣṇava feels and endures in his journey toward attaining bhakti.
 “Just like merciful persons, the clouds gave their lives for the pleasure of this world.” – Śrīmad Bhāgavatam 10.20.6.
 Your love for Śrī Kṛṣṇa pierces my heart again and again: when the mahā-mantra, out of its own sweet will, arose from the depths of the Gaṅgā to you; when the blue boy playing a flute appeared from a stack of prints in New Delhi; when you cried out, “Kṛṣṇa! His name is Kṛṣṇa!” upon seeing His name for the first time at Cross Maidan in Śrīla Prabhupāda’s Kṛṣṇa Book; when you trembled in gratitude as Prabhupāda’s unspoken words “Kṛṣṇa is waiting for you” entered your heart; when you listened to the pastimes of Kṛṣṇa stealing butter and being caught by Mother Yaśodā from Nārāyaṇa Prasād; when Lord Rāma appeared to Rāma Sevaka Swami and instructed him, “This young boy is a devotee of Kṛṣṇa; speak to him only about the glories of Kṛṣṇa”; when you arrived in Mathurā on Janmāṣṭamī day, only to be lovingly tricked by Kṛṣṇa to keep you in Vṛndāvana; when you witnessed the spontaneous love of Kṛṣṇadāsa Bābājī, who chanted Kṛṣṇa’s names day and night; when you heard of Kṛṣṇa calling out to the gopīs with the sweet songs of His flute, and how they abandoned everything to run toward Him on that rāsa-pūrṇimā night; when you fixed your heart upon the enchanting sight of Śrī Rādhā and Kṛṣṇa dancing beneath the moonlit sky as described by Bon Mahārāja; when you received the most confidential secrets of Śrīmatī Rādhārāṇī’s love from Viśākhā Śaraṇa Bābā; when you closed your eyes in Rādhā’s forest Barsānā and felt the love of Śrī Rādhā and Kṛṣṇa showering upon you; and when you received the invisible, mystical blessings of Śrī Rūpa Gosvāmī at his samādhi.
 “My dear friend, if you are indeed attached to your worldly friends, do not look at the smiling face of Govinda as He stands on the bank of the Yamunā at Keśīghāṭa.” – Caitanya-caritāmṛta, ādi-līlā, 5.224
 Mahārāja, you have taught me countless lessons throughout your life.
 From your dealings with sādhus of various sampradāyas, such as Bon Mahārāja, Kṛṣṇadāsa Bābājī, Ramesh Bābā, Ghanasyām, and much more, you have taught me the principle of seeing the hearts of devotees beyond sectarian boundaries, never becoming crippled by the small-mindedness of building walls of division. Even harboring a trace of hatred toward a Vaiṣṇava in the mind is detrimental to one’s own bhakti. May I etch this truth deep within my heart and never forget it.
 “If by chance the offense of hatred, malice or criticism of a Vaiṣṇava occurs, the person should be repentant, recognizing his own low nature in having committed the offense, and should nullify the offense by lamenting, resolving to come before the Vaiṣṇava, fall at his feet, and satisfy him by offering his obeisances, praises and respects.” – Mādhurya-kādambiṇī, third shower.
 When you once felt remorse for imitating a camera click to help a friend, realizing later that it hurt a Vaiṣṇava’s heart, you taught me the gravity of never causing pain to any devotee, whether in the name of preaching, philosophical argument, missionary activity, or trying to shove my own understanding of Kṛṣṇa consciousness into someone’s throat to choke him.
 “Nor should one think that the offense of sādhu-nindā operates only in relation to a Vaiṣṇava who is fully and perfectly endowed with all the qualities mentioned in scripture, such as tolerance, mercy and kindness to all living entities. Such a person attempts to minimize his own offense by pointing out some defect in the Vaiṣṇava.” – Mādhurya-kādambiṇī, third shower.
 When you resisted pressures from disciples of various gurus who sought to impose their own dogmas upon you, you taught me “resistance”, and taught me to follow one’s own inner calling, of fanning the spark of love for Kṛṣṇa that arises uniquely in each heart.
 “So different devotees have different inclinations to offer his service to different features of God.” – Śrīla Prabhupāda, December 15th 1966, New York
 Through your resolve to serve within ISKCON and your endeavors to associate harmoniously with your godbrothers despite differences, you taught me that the real unity of devotees lies not in uniformity but in cooperation, serving Śrī Śrī Rādhā-Kṛṣṇa according to one’s own calling under the guidance of Śrī Guru, in the movement of Śrīla Prabhupāda.
 “Advanced devotees can understand and appreciate the different varieties of devotional service reciprocated with the Supreme Personality of Godhead.” – Caitanya-caritāmṛta, madhya-līlā, 23.99.
 When you changed the spirit of book distribution, urging that we strive to distribute more and yet pray to “come last”, you taught me a very important principle to focus on humility and the genuine fruits of bhakti in the form of one’s own attraction to Śrī Rādhā and Kṛṣṇa, rather than nourishing the ego by chasing the honour from others by so-called “spiritual” achievements.
 “Humility means the freedom from the anxiety of having the satisfaction of being honoured by others.” – Śrī Guru
 Through your life, you have shown that both bhajanānandīs and goṣṭhyānandīs are exalted in their own ways, and that you yourself embody both aspects in your personality. This teaches me the greatness of our paramparā, where some ācāryas are immersed in deep internal bhajana, while others are dedicated to preaching and outreach—each perfectly serving Śrī Kṛṣṇa according to their nature.
 “The best devotional service for a devotee is that by which he attains complete satisfaction and joy. He should do it with full faith, for it will bring the desired result since it is done with affection. The saintly authorities consider that service to be the essence of a devotee’s goal for it will manifest prema.” – Bṛhad-bhāgavatāmṛta 2.3.152
 As the years carry us further from the time of Śrīla Prabhupāda’s earthly presence, we risk drifting from the full, multifaceted, all-accommodating vision of his personality. Therefore, I pray at your lotus feet: may I develop ever-deepening love and understanding of Śrīla Prabhupāda; may gratitude and affection for the Vaiṣṇavas ever increase within me; may I cultivate a thirst for śāstric study and, if you so desire, share that understanding with others; may I awaken intense greed for the divine service of Śrī Rādhā and Kṛṣṇa in the mood of Śrī Rūpa Gosvāmī. And may I realize the true meaning of the name you have so mercifully bestowed upon me.
 “Taking straw in my teeth, I pray again and again: May I become a piece of dust at the lotus feet of Śrīla Rūpa Gosvāmī, birth after birth.” – Mukta-carita
 I pray to Śrī Kṛṣṇa for your long, healthy life, Gurudeva, so that you may continue to inspire millions of souls like my fallen self.
 Your servant,
 Vraja Jīvana Dāsa

Hare Krishnas Respected Gurumaharaj,
 
 Please accept my respectful obeisances
 All Glories to Sri Sri Guru and Gauranga
 All Glories to Srila Prabhupada
 My heartfelt prayers for Your good health and long life.
 
 Today I would like to express my deepest gratitude for one of the qualities which is very rare and is the only hope for a disciple. I would like to describe the protection aspect of Guru.
 
 Guru-tattva — The Principle of the Spiritual Master
 Guru-tattva means understanding the truth or principle of the spiritual master. The Guru is not an ordinary person; he represents Krishna’s mercy in the most tangible way.
 
 Bhagavad Gītā 4.34
 tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā
 upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ
 
 “Approach a spiritual master, inquire from him submissively and render service unto him. The self-realized soul can impart knowledge unto you because he has seen the truth.”
 
 Srila Prabhupāda’s purport:
 The Guru is tattva-darśī — one who has seen the truth. He connects the disciple to Krishna through śabda-brahma, the sound vibration of transcendental knowledge.
 Śrīmad Bhāgavatam 11.17.27
 ācāryaṁ māṁ vijānīyān nāvamanyeta karhicit
 na martya-buddhyāsūyeta sarva-deva-mayo guruḥ
 “One should know the ācārya spiritual master to be My very self and never disrespect him in any way. The spiritual master should never be considered an ordinary man, for he is the sum total of all the demigods.”
 Explanation:
 Here, Krishna declares that the Guru is His representative, carrying His potency. Through the Guru, Krishna manifests His mercy —
 Kṛṣṇa-śakti vinā nahe tāra pravartana CC Madhya 8.128.
 
 Gurumaharaj would say,
 “Just as a child holds the hand of the father to cross a busy street, the disciple holds the hand of the Guru through faith and service. That hand is strong because it is Krishna’s own hand reaching out to us.”
 
 A true spiritual master doesn’t make us depend on him — he teaches us to depend on Krishna.
 Through His example, Gurumaharaj awakens our faith that Krishna is our eternal protector.
 How the Guru Protects His Disciples
 The Guru’s protection is spiritual, not merely physical. It is the protection of consciousness — protecting the disciple from māyā, illusion, and helping him stay fixed in bhakti and remembrance of Krishna.
 
 Let’s look at how this protection operates:
 
 a Protection through Instruction — Jñāna-rakṣaṇa
 The Guru gives divya-jñāna, transcendental knowledge, which destroys ignorance.
 Just as a lamp protects one from darkness, knowledge from the Guru protects one from illusion.
 
 Srimad Bhāgavatam 11.22.10
 jñānaṁ vijñāna-sahitaṁ yadā guhyatamaṁ mama
 tad vedituṁ bhavān arhati śraddhāvān anasūyakaḥ
 By giving jñāna and vijñāna, the Guru protects the disciple’s buddhi from being stolen by māyā.
 
 Gurumaharaj’s example:
 He protects his disciples by constantly reminding them of Krishna-centered consciousness, through scriptural classes, personal instructions, and his own life of humility and service. His teachings always center around “Remember Krishna, serve others, and stay under the shelter of the holy name.”
 That remembrance itself is protection.
 
 Gurumaharaj often explains that the Guru protects us by reminding us of who we really are.
 “The world tries to make us forget.
 Maya whispers, ‘You are the controller, you are the enjoyer.’
 But the Guru whispers Krishna’s name into our heart.”
 This whisper of divine remembrance — this śabda-brahma — is the Guru’s shield of protection. It’s not the kind of protection that removes every storm; it’s the kind that gives us shelter within the storm.
 
 He says,
 “When the storm comes, don’t pray for the storm to stop — pray for the strength to hold on to Krishna’s lotus feet.”
 The Guru gives us that strength.
 
 b Protection through Prayer — Kṛpā-rakṣaṇa
 A pure devotee prays for his disciples constantly.
 The Guru’s heart is linked to Krishna’s heart; he begs Krishna to protect those who have taken shelter of him.
 
 Srimad Bhāgavatam 10.2.31
 ye 'nye 'ravindākṣa vimukta-māninaḥ ... patanty adho 'nādṛta-yuṣmad-aṅghrayaḥ
 Even a learned person can fall down without shelter of the Lord’s lotus feet.
 The Guru ensures the disciple always remains under those feet through his prayers and mercy.
 
 Gurumaharaj’s Example:
 He often says, “I pray for you all every day.”
 This prayer is not sentiment — it’s spiritual intercession. Just as a father prays for his children, the Guru holds the disciple in his heart and connects them to Krishna through his compassion.
 
 Gurumaharaj sometimes describes how the Guru feels toward his disciples:
 “The Guru prays for his disciples even when they forget to pray for themselves.
 He stands before Krishna like a mother before a doctor — begging, ‘Please save my child.’”
 
 This is *kṛpā-rakṣaṇa* — protection through compassion.
 The Guru may be far away physically, but his prayers travel faster than thought.
 A sincere disciple is never alone.
 
 Srimad Bhāgavatam 11.17.27 says:
 ācāryaṁ māṁ vijānīyān nāvamanyeta karhicit...
 “Know the ācārya to be My very self.”
 
 Gurumaharaj explains,
 “It means Krishna is personally guiding us through the Guru’s words, through his example, and sometimes through his silence.”
 
 c Protection through Example — Ācāra-rakṣaṇa
 The ācārya protects by living the teachings.
 Seeing the Guru’s example strengthens the disciple’s faith and determination.
 
 Bhagavad Gītā 3.21
 yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ
 “Whatever great men do, common men follow.”
 
 Gurumaharaj’s Example:
 His humility, forgiveness, simplicity, and deep compassion inspire devotees to face challenges without losing faith. His life itself becomes a shield — reminding disciples that bhakti is not theoretical; it’s lived sincerity.
 
 In Gurumaharaj’s life, we see that his teaching and living are one.
 He sleeps little, eats simply, travels tirelessly — just to help souls reconnect to Krishna.
 
 Once he said:
 “If my life can help even one person remember Krishna, then my life is successful.”
 That example is protection — because it shows us what bhakti looks like when it is lived with love.
 By seeing how the Guru faces pain with gratitude, we learn how to face our own challenges with faith.
 By seeing how he forgives, we learn what forgiveness means.
 By seeing how he serves, we learn what real happiness is.
 
 This is ācāra-rakṣaṇa — protection through example.
 
 d Protection through Disciplic Connection — Paramparā-rakṣaṇa
 The Guru gives protection by connecting the disciple to the paramparā — to Krishna’s unbroken current of mercy.
 When we are connected to this current, māyā cannot touch us.
 
 Bhagavad Gītā 4.2
 evaṁ paramparā-prāptam imaṁ rājarṣayo viduḥ
 The chain of disciplic succession protects the purity of knowledge and the consciousness of those within it.
 
 Srila Prabhupada says:
 “A disciple connected to the bona fide Guru is connected directly to Krishna.”
 Thus, following Guru’s instructions keeps one under Krishna’s direct protection.
 The Guru’s real protection is not just emotional shelter — it’s spiritual connection.
 
 In Bhagavad Gītā 18.66, Krishna promises:
 sarva-dharmān parityajya mām ekaṁ śaraṇaṁ vraja
 ahaṁ tvāṁ sarva-pāpebhyo mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucaḥ
 
 Gurumaharaj explains,
 “The Guru’s greatest gift is to bring us to that verse — to help us take shelter of Krishna without fear. When we surrender to Krishna through the Guru’s instructions, Krishna personally takes the responsibility to protect us.”
 So, when a disciple sincerely follows the Guru’s instructions, Krishna Himself guards that devotee’s heart.
 
 That is the perfection of Guru’s protection.
 
 e Protection through Chastisement — Śāsana-rakṣaṇa
 Sometimes, the Guru protects by correcting or chastising the disciple — not out of anger, but mercy.
 
 Bhāgavatam 4.8.34
 guruḥ sākṣāt hariḥ ity uktaḥ ... kintu prabhor yaḥ priya eva tasya
 The Guru is as good as God, but his chastisement or correction is a form of divine love.
 If the disciple accepts such correction, he becomes purified and protected from downfall.
 
 Gurumaharaj once said,
 “When a Guru points out our faults, it is not to make us feel small — it is to help us become who we truly are: servants of Krishna.”
 Like a doctor, he identifies the disease of ego and prescribes the medicine of humility.
 That correction, though uncomfortable, is an act of deep protection.
 Because without it, we might wander away from the path of bhakti.
 
 f The Guru Protects through the Family of Devotees
 Gurumaharaj often emphasizes that the Guru’s protection also manifests through the devotee community.
 “We protect one another when we live in the spirit of service.
 Krishna’s love flows most beautifully through relationships.”
 So when disciples cooperate, forgive, and care for each other, they are living under the Guru’s protection.
 
 He says,
 “When you water the root of the tree, every leaf and branch is nourished.
 When you serve the mission of your Guru, you are nourished spiritually.”
 
 3. The Heart of the Guru — Gurumaharaj’s Mood
 Gurumaharaj embodies the protective compassion of the Guru in several ways:
 He nurtures the hearts of disciples with affection and patience.
 He teaches balance — to be strong in sādhana but gentle with others.
 He inspires service — by teaching that serving devotees and humanity is real protection of the soul.
 He creates community — spiritual family as an extension of his protection.
 
 He often quotes:
 “When we take shelter of Krishna and the devotees, Krishna protects us more than a mother protects her child in the womb.”
 
 Essence
 The Guru-tattva is the manifestation of Krishna’s heart of mercy.
 Through his words, actions, prayers, and presence, the Guru protects the disciple’s faith, bhakti, and connection with Krishna.
 
 As Srila Prabhupada said:
 “The spiritual master is the external manifestation of the Supersoul, and he protects the disciple from falling again into the ocean of birth and death.”
 
 In Gurumaharaj’s words:
 “A real Guru doesn’t claim to be God — he connects you to God.
 He doesn’t make you dependent on him — he teaches you to depend on Krishna.
 And he doesn’t remove the storms — he teaches you how to dance in the rain of Krishna’s mercy.”
 
 So I am very grateful to Gurumaharaj for giving this protection to us. As a disciple, I cannot repay the debt of Gurumaharaj, but would like to pray that if He feels happy, He can engage me in some service so that I can continue to serve Him.
 }}
 Your eternal servant,
 Vraja krishna das

 Dearest Guru Maharaj,
 Please accept my respectful obeisances.
On this auspicious day of your Vyas Puja, I wish to take a solemn vow to become a better devotee. Through your exemplary life and profound instructions, I have come to understand so many divine qualities that a sincere sadhaka should aspire to cultivate. These qualities not only please You, Srila Prabhupada, our Acharyas, and Krishna, but they also open the doors to the infinite grace and mercy that the Guru Parampara is constantly showering on us. Yet, due to my hard-heartedness and false ego, I often fail to taste or even desire that mercy.
 
 Guru Maharaj, you repeatedly emphasize the importance of humility. I must strive to be humble like a blade of grass—simple words, yet so challenging to live by. True humility is not feeling low or discouraged; it is the awakened realization of the Supreme Lord’s greatness and the exalted position of His devotees and my insignificance. Genuine humility will free me from envy and pride, allowing my heart to rejoice in and appreciate the wonderful qualities of devotees around me.
 
 Another quality I deeply desire to cultivate is gratitude. You teach us that a grateful heart is like fertile soil in which the creeper of bhakti can grow strong and flourish. Real gratitude means sincere reciprocation—offering back everything I have received. Gratitude to the spiritual master is not limited to a yearly “thank you”; it means, “You have given me everything, and if I am truly grateful, I want to offer my entire life in return.” Guru Maharaj, I want to do whatever will please you. I want to dedicate every moment of my life to assisting you in serving Srila Prabhupada’s mission.
 
 You also teach that sincere service attitude is essential for a sadhaka’s spiritual advancement. Through service—service to Krishna and to the great souls who have taken exclusive shelter of Krishna—I can develop genuine eagerness to hear about Him. The service attitude I cultivate becomes the very basis by which I can attract Krishna’s mercy. I pray to imbibe this true spirit of service, where no obstacle, excuse, or hesitation can impede my execution of Your Divine instructions.
 
 In your recent lecture on Srila Prabhupada’s disappearance day during the Kartik Yatra at Govardhan, you explained that when a disciple sincerely follows the vani of his spiritual master, then the vapuh of the Guru manifests within the disciple’s heart. Such a disciple never feels separated from his Guru, not even for a moment. Guru Maharaj, I long to purify my heart so that I may truly invite you to reside there.
 
 I have a long journey ahead, yet I aspire to progress steadily on this path. Your love, shelter, and blessings are the anchor that will help me become receptive to the boundless mercy of our Acharyas and transform my heart, develop the love for Krsnas holy names, pastimes, his abode, his devotees and his seva.
 
 Thank you is a small and insignificant word. Yet I offer this from the deepest cores of my heart. I feel immensely blessed and loved as I write this heartfelt offering. I pray that I never fail you and that you never give up on me.
 Your daughter,
 Vrajabhumi Devi Dasi

 Dear Gurudev, I make this humble offering to You of my heartfelt resolve:

Your love, your mercy, your warm embrace.

May I forever chant and serve your feet,
Till this heart and soul in you complete.

Your insignificant servant,

Dear Gurumaharaj,

Please accept my humble obeisances at your divine lotus feet.

Gurudev, for some years, we have been showing an animated short film to college boys in our preaching program. It shows the rat race for material happiness and reveals the truth of material happiness as illusory and temporary. Whenever I see this video, I think that most people in this world don't know that they are suffering. Some of them know that they are suffering, but for them, it is just an unavoidable part of life. And very few of them feel frustrated with suffering, but they don't know how to get out of it. And very, very few know that spirituality can help, but they get misdirected. And in all this, very, very, very few get the rarest opportunity to connect with the bonafide disciplic succession and get saved by substituting material happiness with spiritual happiness through service to the Lord and His devotees. In all this, I don't stand anywhere because I have got this opportunity not because of my inquisitiveness, but it's the rarest causeless mercy of yours that has saved me.

In one class, you were saying that Lord Gauranga gave mercy to the animals of Zarikhand forest, but the animals had to accept that mercy before they got it. After hearing this, I was questioned philosophically because, as per my tiny knowledge, animals don't have the capacity to accept or reject anything beyond their destiny. I asked this to HG Vilas Vardhan Prabhu at Govardhan. Prabhu told me that in such cases, the Lord also gives the capacity to accept the mercy with the mercy. Prabhu said that just like animals, we have to consider ourselves like animals who are unqualified but have been blessed with mercy, and in that mood, we shall pray to Lord Giriraj. When I heard this explanation, I was humbled and started reflecting that, actually, before coming to VOICE, I was just an animal, but by your mercy, through various devotees, I got the opportunity to save myself.

Since the last Kartik Yatra at Shridham Mayapur, I was eagerly waiting for this year's Kartik Yatra. One thing I was convinced of was that as in Mayapur, I was not able to always remain conscious of the greatness of holy places, of holy dham, and pray properly there, so visiting holy places used to become a very mechanical activity for me. Hence, I was simply waiting to give my best to hear your classes. When you sang the disappearance song for Srila Prabhupad, you made me cry in gratitude and humility for some moments in my life.

Gurudev, I was hearing your glories from many devotees and was moved to understand what kind of mercy I have received. In various departments of Dham Darshan, there was a Crowd Care department, and as HG Achyut Mohan Prabhu mentioned that your mood of love and care is reflected in the whole Yatra, I had seen the word "Crowd Control" but not "Crowd Care" until now, anywhere. But for the first time, I saw this as a reflection of your mood.

Gurudev, your love and loyalty for Srila Prabhupad inspire me deeply. I remember hearing how you were attentive about which places in Prayag various pastimes of Srila Prabhupad had happened, and you told HG Achyut Mohan Prabhu to research it. You revived Ultadanga Junction at Kolkata as one of the most important places for ISKCON. You served Srila Prabhupad wholeheartedly at New Vrindavan and later created Vrindavan at Wada.

Gurudev, your Vani gives me true shelter and strength. I have not been able to do any tangible service to you, Gurudev. Whatever devotees say about me is not actually done by me. It is just the desire of devotees, the support of devotees, the push of devotees, done by devotees, and at the end, credited to me just out of their compassion. I am simply a fortunate fool who has been immensely blessed.

Gurudev, you know me in and out and how much degraded my consciousness is, but at Govardhan, while glorifying Srila Prabhupad, you said that "Srila Prabhupad will never leave anyone even if one leaves Srila Prabhupad." Similar is the hope for me that You and Srila Prabhupad will never leave me. And my sincere prayers at your lotus feet are that I may never forget you and Srila Prabhupad and always remain grateful to all who have, who are, and who will help me in remaining Krishna Conscious.

insignificant servant of your servants

75th Vyāsa Pūjā Offering
Respected Gurudev,
Please accept our obeisances.
Your untiring efforts at guiding thousands in the path of Krishna Consciousness and fanning the spark of spiritual endeavor are exemplary.
You have taken up the task to care for and stimulate the vast number of your disciples and to maintain a very high standard for each one. Your finesse and success at accomplishing this task borders on the artistic.
You are extremely personal when it comes to dealing with individuals, be they your disciples or your godbrothers, or even the person who has come in contact with you for the first time. This is an extremely rare quality in such a fast-paced time and age.
You have nurtured Thought Leaders, Creative Leaders, Administrative Leaders, Preaching Leaders, Management Leaders, Spiritual Leaders, Popular Leaders—and the list goes on.
Creating the next rung of leadership is an extremely Herculean task, and you have done it so amazingly—without any hurry and without a shout.
I am joined by my family in expressing a very deep sense of gratitude for all that we have received from you. I pray that our minds and bodies be utilized in serving you, so that you could serve the mission of your dear spiritual master Śrīla Prabhupāda, in a way that is most pleasing to you and to Śrīla Prabhupāda.
Your servant,
Yudhisthira Dāsa

Dear Gurumaharaj,
Hare Krishna!

On this most auspicious day of your Vyasa Puja, I offer my heartfelt wishes for your good health and for an ever-increasing abundance of Krishna’s divine love — so that it may continue to overflow upon fallen souls like myself, who are still striving to strengthen our faith in the Supreme Lord.

Through your eyes and your enlightening lectures, we are able to experience the boundless love Krishna bestows upon His devotees and learn how to improve our sādhana. Through your tireless efforts in organizing the Dham Yatra, we are also blessed with the merciful glance of Śrīmatī Rādhārāṇī.

This year again, by your causeless mercy, I was fortunate to meet my long-lost friend during the yatra — the very friend who, twenty-five years ago, first gave me the Bhagavad-gītā. It is only by your divine grace that I came across her twenty-six years ago. She has always embodied the love and humility that you so perfectly represent.

I am deeply grateful that your blessings to her, and through her to me, have silently guided my life all these years — leading me to the association of many wonderful senior devotees and, once again, to her during this sacred yatra.

I remain an undeserving, disillusioned, egoistic, and materialistic being — yet, time and again, your compassion and blessings help me become a little better and draw closer to the path of devotion.

With folded hands and a heart full of gratitude, I pray for your continued mercy and good health.

Your insignificant servant,
Yukti Nautiyal Jaguri
